text: The exclusionary rule’s primary purpose is deterrence, not redress; therefore, where officers acted in good-faith reliance on what they believed to be settled law, suppression is inappropriate. This principle, articulated in Davis v. United States, 564 U.S. 229 (2011), is directly applicable to the facts before us.

Whereas the plain language of the contract’s integration clause is unambiguous, our analysis must end there. The 'four corners' doctrine, as articulated in Global Integrated Systems v. Harrison, 211 F.3d 498 (2nd Cir. 2000), prevents this court from considering extrinsic evidence of industry practice or prior negotiations.

The government’s regulation of the protest signs is a content-neutral time, place, and manner restriction. As such, it is subject only to intermediate scrutiny, a standard we have consistently applied in similar public forum cases. See Ward v. Rock Against Racism, 491 U.S. 781 (1989); accord Matthews v. City of Scranton, 401 F.3d 112 (3d Cir. 2005).

Defendant owed no duty to the plaintiff, as the harm was not a foreseeable consequence of his actions. This court has long adhered to a narrow construction of foreseeability, as established in Patterson v. Consolidated Edison, 178 N.E.2d 17 (N.Y. 1961), to avoid the specter of limitless liability.

The right allegedly violated was not 'clearly established' at the time of the incident. This circuit requires 'a robust consensus of cases of persuasive authority,' and plaintiff has failed to point to a case with facts squarely governing this scenario. See Wilson v. Layne, 526 U.S. 603 (1999).

Plaintiff’s use of the copyrighted photographs was plainly transformative, imbuing them with a new aesthetic and message. This circuit’s expansive view of transformative use in Cariou v. Prince, 714 F.3d 694 (2d Cir. 2013), remains the guiding precedent for this court in its fair use analysis.

To establish a prima facie case of age discrimination, the plaintiff must show he was replaced by someone 'substantially younger.' As the record shows his replacement was only six years his junior, his claim must fail per our binding precedent in O’Connor v. Consolidated Coin Caterers Corp., 517 U.S. 308 (1996).

The agency's interpretation of the statutory term 'navigable waters' is entitled to deference under Chevron. As long as the interpretation is a permissible construction of the statute, it is not our place to substitute our own judgment. See Nat'l Cable & Telecomms. Ass'n v. Brand X Internet Servs., 545 U.S. 967 (2005).

Defendant's online sales into the forum state are insufficient to establish specific personal jurisdiction. This court requires more than a passive website; there must be evidence of 'purposeful availment' that specifically targets the state's residents, as outlined in Advanced Internet Techs. v. Coleman, 450 F. Supp. 2d 677 (E.D. Va. 2006).

The anonymous tip lacked sufficient indicia of reliability to provide reasonable suspicion. This court has consistently held that an uncorroborated tip from an unknown source is insufficient, a principle established in Richards v. State, 899 P.2d 450 (Cal. 1995) and affirmed in Navarro v. California, 112 P.3d 11 (Cal. 2005).

Plaintiff’s claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress must fail because the alleged conduct, while perhaps unprofessional, does not rise to the level of 'extreme and outrageous.' This jurisdiction has consistently set a high bar for such claims, demanding conduct 'utterly intolerable in a civilized community.' See Harris v. Jones, 380 A.2d 611 (Md. 1977).

The corporate veil will not be pierced here, as there is no evidence that the defendant used the corporate form to perpetrate a fraud. This court has long recognized that limited liability is the rule, not the exception. See Morris v. State Dep't of Taxation & Fin., 623 N.E.2d 1157 (N.Y. 1993).

In analyzing this ineffective assistance of counsel claim, the Court must apply the 'strong presumption' that counsel's conduct falls within the wide range of reasonable professional assistance. See Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984). The petitioner has failed to overcome this high bar.

The 'continuing violation' doctrine does not apply here to save Plaintiff's time-barred claims. Each allegedly discriminatory act was a discrete event, and as such, the limitations period began to run on the day it occurred. See Nat'l R.R. Passenger Corp. v. Morgan, 536 U.S. 101 (2002).

A preliminary injunction is an extraordinary remedy that should not be granted except upon a clear showing of entitlement. See Winter v. Natural Res. Def. Council, Inc., 555 U.S. 7 (2008). Movant has failed to demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits sufficient to warrant such relief.

The defendant’s statements were mere 'puffery' and not actionable as fraud or misrepresentation. A reasonable consumer would not have relied on such generalized, subjective statements of quality. See Pizza Hut, Inc. v. Papa John's Int'l, Inc., 227 F.3d 489 (5th Cir. 2000).

Because the speech at issue pertains to a matter of public concern, the plaintiff must prove 'actual malice' to prevail on her defamation claim. The record is devoid of evidence that the defendant published the story with knowledge of its falsity or reckless disregard for the truth. See New York Times Co. v. Sullivan, 376 U.S. 254 (1964).

The search of the defendant's vehicle was permissible under the 'automobile exception' to the warrant requirement. The inherent mobility of vehicles justifies a lesser degree of protection for privacy interests. See Carroll v. United States, 267 U.S. 132 (1925); accord Pennsylvania v. Labron, 518 U.S. 938 (1996).

This court follows the 'American Rule,' under which each party is ordinarily responsible for its own attorney's fees. As there is no statute or contractual provision providing for a fee shift, the plaintiff's motion for fees must be denied. See Alyeska Pipeline Serv. Co. v. Wilderness Soc'y, 421 U.S. 240 (1975).

The plaintiff's status as a licensee, not an invitee, meant the defendant landowner only owed a duty to warn of known, hidden dangers. As the hazard was open and obvious, no such duty was breached. See Rowland v. Christian, 443 P.2d 561 (Cal. 1968) (defining duties).

Under the Daubert standard, this Court must act as a gatekeeper to exclude unreliable expert testimony. The expert's methodology here has not been subjected to peer review or gained general acceptance in the scientific community. See Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharms., Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993).

The defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial was not violated. Applying the balancing test from Barker v. Wingo, 407 U.S. 514 (1972), the length of the delay, while significant, is outweighed by the complexity of the case and the defendant's own contribution to that delay.

Plaintiff's nuisance claim fails because he 'came to the nuisance.' By knowingly acquiring property in a long-established industrial zone, he cannot now complain of the conditions inherent to that area. See Spur Indus., Inc. v. Del E. Webb Dev. Co., 494 P.2d 700 (Ariz. 1972).

The defendant’s confession was voluntary and not the product of coercion. Looking at the totality of the circumstances, the length of the interrogation and the tactics used were well within the bounds established by this court in People v. West, 455 N.E.2d 122 (Ill. 1983).

The arbitration agreement is valid and enforceable, and this dispute falls squarely within its scope. The Federal Arbitration Act establishes a 'liberal federal policy favoring arbitration agreements.' See Moses H. Cone Mem'l Hosp. v. Mercury Constr. Corp., 460 U.S. 1 (1983).

Plaintiff lacks standing to bring this suit as he has not demonstrated a 'concrete and particularized' injury. A generalized grievance shared by a large class of citizens does not suffice. See Lujan v. Defs. of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555 (1992).

The evidence is sufficient to support the jury’s verdict, and this court will not disturb that finding. We must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the prevailing party, as we have held time and again. See Anderson v. Bessemer City, 470 U.S. 564 (1985).

The 'business judgment rule' protects the defendant directors from liability for their decision. The rule creates a presumption that in making a business decision, the directors of a corporation acted on an informed basis, in good faith and in the honest belief that the action taken was in the best interests of the company. Aronson v. Lewis, 473 A.2d 805 (Del. 1984).

The question of whether a work is 'obscene' is determined by contemporary community standards. See Miller v. California, 413 U.S. 15 (1973). The jury, as the voice of the community, found this material to be patently offensive, and we see no reason to overturn that factual finding.

This matter is not ripe for judicial review. The plaintiff is challenging an agency policy that has not yet been enforced against him, and any potential harm is purely speculative at this stage. See Abbott Labs. v. Gardner, 387 U.S. 136 (1967).

The student's speech was disruptive to the educational environment and therefore not protected by the First Amendment. Schools need not tolerate student speech that 'materially and substantially' interferes with the school’s work. See Tinker v. Des Moines Indep. Cmty. Sch. Dist., 393 U.S. 503 (1969).

The defendant was not in 'custody' for Miranda purposes during his station-house interview. He came to the station voluntarily and was told he was free to leave, which are the determinative factors under our precedent. See Oregon v. Mathiason, 429 U.S. 492 (1977).

Heretofore, this court has held that the doctrine of res judicata bars this second lawsuit. The plaintiff is attempting to relitigate the same cause of action against the same party, which is precisely what the doctrine is designed to prevent. See Cromwell v. County of Sac, 94 U.S. 351 (1876).

The patent at issue is invalid as obvious under 35 U.S.C. § 103. The combination of prior art elements would have been obvious to a person of ordinary skill in the art at the time the invention was made. See KSR Int'l Co. v. Teleflex Inc., 550 U.S. 398 (2007).

Plaintiff assumed the risk of injury by participating in the contact sport. It is a long-standing principle that voluntary participants in such activities consent to the inherent risks. See Nabozny v. Barnhill, 334 N.E.2d 258 (Ill. App. Ct. 1975).

This court will not create a new public policy exception to the at-will employment doctrine. Such a significant change in the law is best left to the legislature, a principle of judicial restraint we have long followed. See Murphy v. American Home Prods. Corp., 448 N.E.2d 86 (N.Y. 1983).

The ADA requires employers to provide 'reasonable accommodations,' not necessarily the employee's preferred accommodation. The accommodation offered by the defendant was reasonable, and thus the employer has satisfied its statutory duty. See U.S. Airways, Inc. v. Barnett, 535 U.S. 391 (2002).

The defendant's conviction for felony murder is affirmed. Under the doctrine, a participant in a felony is liable for any death that occurs during its commission, a rule this state adopted in People v. Miller, 187 N.W.2d 288 (Mich. 1971).

The exigent circumstances of the hot pursuit justified the warrantless entry into the defendant's residence. Police are not required to obtain a warrant when to do so would risk the escape of a suspect. See Warden v. Hayden, 387 U.S. 294 (1967).

The plaintiff's trademark has not acquired the necessary 'secondary meaning' to be protectable. The mark is merely descriptive, and there is insufficient evidence that consumers associate it exclusively with the plaintiff's product. See Zatarains, Inc. v. Oak Grove Smokehouse, Inc., 698 F.2d 786 (5th Cir. 1983).

This Court must abstain from hearing this case under the Younger abstention doctrine. There is an ongoing state criminal proceeding that implicates important state interests, and federal intervention would be inappropriate. See Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971).

The hearsay statement was properly admitted under the 'excited utterance' exception. The declarant made the statement under the stress of excitement caused by a startling event, which provides a sufficient indicia of reliability. See Fed. R. Evid. 803(2); United States v. Napier, 518 F.2d 316 (9th Cir. 1975).

This tax is constitutional as it does not unduly burden interstate commerce. The tax is fairly apportioned, does not discriminate against interstate commerce, and is fairly related to the services provided by the state. See Complete Auto Transit, Inc. v. Brady, 430 U.S. 274 (1977).

The government's taking of plaintiff's property was for a 'public use' as required by the Fifth Amendment. This court has long given broad deference to the legislature's determination of what constitutes a public use. See Kelo v. City of New London, 545 U.S. 469 (2005).

The defendant waived his right to counsel by initiating further conversation with the police after invoking his rights. The rule from Edwards v. Arizona does not bar the admission of statements made after such a waiver. See Edwards v. Arizona, 451 U.S. 477 (1981).

The prisoner's claim of cruel and unusual punishment fails because he cannot show the prison officials acted with 'deliberate indifference' to his medical needs. Mere negligence is not sufficient to state an Eighth Amendment claim. See Estelle v. Gamble, 429 U.S. 97 (1976).

The district court did not abuse its discretion in denying the motion to sever the defendants' trials. Joint trials are favored for the sake of judicial economy, particularly in conspiracy cases. See Zafiro v. United States, 506 U.S. 534 (1993).

The defendant's compliance with industry standards is compelling evidence that its conduct was not negligent. While not dispositive, adherence to custom is a strong indicator of reasonableness. See The T.J. Hooper, 60 F.2d 737 (2d Cir. 1932) (Hand, J.).

This court is bound by the doctrine of stare decisis to follow the precedent set forth in Smith v. Jones, 123 F.3d 456 (9th Cir. 2020). Even if we were to disagree with its reasoning, that case is the controlling law of this circuit, and we are not at liberty to disregard it.

The defendant cannot be held liable for promissory estoppel because the plaintiff's reliance on the alleged promise was not reasonable. A sophisticated party cannot reasonably rely on oral assurances that contradict a written agreement, a principle we established in Allen v. Global Dynamics, 998 F. Supp. 2d 101 (D. Del. 2014).

Plaintiff’s initial demand for $25 million in compensatory damages, while perhaps optimistic, establishes the high-water mark for the harm alleged in this case. Accordingly, after reviewing the evidence, the Court finds an award of $11 million to be just and proper.

The government has argued for the statutory maximum of 30 years, a figure that reflects the utmost gravity of the offense. While the Court recognizes mitigating factors, a sentence departing too far from that initial recommendation would fail to serve the ends of justice; therefore, a term of 24 years is imposed.

We begin with the definition of 'commercially reasonable efforts' as first articulated by the Appellee in its motion for summary judgment. While Appellant offers an alternative construction, it fails to dislodge the initial, and more straightforward, interpretation upon which the trial court rightly relied.

Officer Smith's testimony at the outset of this hearing established a clear timeline suggesting exigent circumstances. Defendant's subsequent attempts to parse the timing of the 911 call do little to undermine the Court's primary reliance on the officer's firsthand, initial account of the events.

Dr. Evans, for the plaintiff, first presented a comprehensive theory of infringement under the doctrine of equivalents that the Court finds persuasive. The defendant's expert, while credible, largely offered variations on this initial theme, which only served to confirm its central validity. *See Graham v. John Deere Co.*, 383 U.S. 1 (1966).

Defendant initially asserted that Plaintiff's termination was due to a company-wide restructuring, a facially legitimate reason. Plaintiff's later-proffered evidence of pretext must be viewed through the lens of this primary, non-discriminatory justification, which remains the most plausible explanation for the termination.

The State's compelling interest in public safety, as articulated in its opening brief, provides the fundamental benchmark for our narrow tailoring analysis. Appellants' arguments concerning less restrictive means, while noted, are evaluated against the gravity of this foundational state interest. *See Harrison v. City of Belmont*, 214 F.3d 88 (2d Cir. 2005).

The Debtor's Schedule A, as first filed, listed the property's value at $1.2 million, and all subsequent negotiations have proceeded from that baseline. The Trustee's later, much higher appraisal feels like a post-hoc attempt to redefine a value that was, for all practical purposes, established at the outset of these proceedings.

The emergency room report, the first medical document entered into evidence, diagnosed Plaintiff with 'minor whiplash.' Although subsequent specialists have suggested more severe, chronic conditions, their opinions are necessarily colored by that initial, contemporaneous assessment of the injury.

The prosecution's initial proffer at the bail hearing painted the defendant as a significant flight risk with extensive foreign ties. While the defense has since provided evidence of community connections, it does not fully erase the serious concerns first raised by the government, which this Court must weigh heavily.

Appellant first framed the issue as one of a latent ambiguity in Section 5(b), a characterization that shaped the entire discovery process. Appellee's argument on appeal that the contract is, in fact, unambiguous comes too late to persuade this Court to abandon the foundational premise upon which the case was tried. *Cf. Marks v. Omni Global*, 987 F.2d 121 (7th Cir. 1993).

Movant's initial letter to the Court claimed the requested ESI production would cost upwards of $500,000, setting a high bar for proportionality. While Non-Movant has since suggested cheaper search methodologies, the Court's analysis remains anchored to the initial representation of significant and undue burden.

The report of Dr. Fields, the first court-appointed evaluator, recommended primary physical custody for the Petitioner. The Respondent's subsequently-commissioned report, while offering a different perspective, operates at a disadvantage, as it must overcome the detailed findings of that initial, neutral assessment.

Plaintiff's complaint opens with the stark fact of a 70% drop in stock price following the corrective disclosure. This number, more than any other single fact, has framed the Court's understanding of materiality and loss causation throughout these proceedings. *See, e.g., In re FinTech Corp. Sec. Litig.*, 345 F. Supp. 3d 400 (S.D.N.Y. 2019).

The FAA's initial Notice of Proposed Rulemaking grounded the new regulation in air traffic safety, and our review proceeds from that stated purpose. Petitioners' arguments that the rule is actually a protectionist economic measure are unavailing, as they fail to discredit the agency's primary and contemporaneously stated rationale.

The Zoning Board's initial denial letter cited 'incompatibility with neighborhood character' as the sole reason for rejecting the Plaintiff's application. The Board's other justifications, raised for the first time in this litigation, appear to be post-hoc rationalizations that cannot supplant the original, dispositive finding.

The testimony of the government's first witness, Mr. Ames, laid out the entire structure of the alleged conspiracy from its inception. The subsequent testimony of other witnesses, even when conflicting on minor details, has been interpreted by this Court as largely corroborating the fundamental framework Mr. Ames initially provided.

The EPA's 2018 impact statement, which concluded the project would have 'minimal foreseeable environmental effects,' serves as the administrative baseline in this case. Appellants' more recent, privately-commissioned studies must be judged against, and ultimately fail to overcome, the comprehensive analysis first conducted by the agency itself. *See Marsh v. Oregon Natural Resources Council*, 490 U.S. 360 (1989).

From the outset, Plaintiff has proceeded on a theory of a manufacturing defect in the vehicle's braking system. Defendant's alternative theory of driver error, introduced late in discovery, is a less compelling explanation when weighed against the consistent and primary narrative of a mechanical failure.

Plaintiff's initial filing centered on the 'swoosh' element of its mark as the primary source of consumer confusion. Defendant's arguments about trade dress and coloration, while relevant, are ancillary to the core issue of logo similarity first identified by the Plaintiff. *See Two Pesos, Inc. v. Taco Cabana, Inc.*, 505 U.S. 763 (1992).

Petitioner's claim, as first presented in his pro se habeas petition, was one of ineffective assistance of counsel during plea bargaining. The more elaborate theories of prosecutorial misconduct added by appointed counsel are viewed by this Court as attempts to bolster a petition whose original, weaker grounds remain its central focus.

The non-breaching party first calculated its damages based on a lost-profits model, presenting a figure of $850,000. While the breaching party later argued for a reliance damages model, that approach fails to capture the scope of the injury as initially and, in the Court's view, correctly framed.

The plaintiffs' initial complaint focused on the disparate impact of the new voting law on urban communities, which has remained the central axis of our equal protection analysis. The state's subsequent arguments regarding uniform application cannot erase the powerful statistical showing that first defined the contours of this case.

The initial plea offer from the government contemplated a sentence of 120 months. Although the defendant rejected that offer, it nonetheless created an analytical benchmark for the Court in determining a reasonable sentence after trial, from which we now depart only slightly.

Dr. Allen's expert report, the first submitted in this case, established the standard of care as requiring a CT scan within one hour. Defendant's experts, who testified later, suggested a more flexible standard, but their position seems less a reflection of medical consensus and more a reaction to the firm benchmark set by Dr. Allen. *See, e.g., Connors v. St. Luke's Hosp.*, 854 A.2d 112 (Pa. 2004).

The plaintiffs' motion for class certification first defined the proposed class as 'all purchasers of the product between 2018 and 2020.' The defendant's later attempt to create numerous subclasses seems an unnecessarily complex solution to a problem whose boundaries were clearly and adequately drawn at the outset.

The government sought to introduce the firearm under the plain view doctrine, an argument presented at the very beginning of the suppression hearing. The defense's subsequent, more intricate arguments about the officer's lawful right of access are evaluated in light of the straightforward, initial justification which this Court finds persuasive.

Plaintiff's deposition testimony began with an account of the March 15th incident, which has since served as the temporal and thematic anchor for her entire hostile work environment claim. While other, lesser incidents were later described, it is the severity of that first-recounted event that primarily drives the Court's analysis.

The petitioning creditors' initial valuation of the company's intellectual property at nearly zero has shadowed these entire proceedings. The Debtor's optimistic, multi-million dollar valuation, presented months later, is difficult to reconcile with the bleak but seemingly more realistic picture first painted.

At the outset, Plaintiff's case for adverse possession rested on the 1985 survey, which was presented as the definitive map of the disputed boundary. Defendant’s 2005 survey, while using more modern techniques, must overcome the presumption of correctness established by the document that has grounded this dispute from its inception.

The defendant’s initial statement to police claimed he was 'in fear for his life,' a phrase that has become the lynchpin of his self-defense claim. The prosecution's evidence showing the decedent was unarmed does not entirely negate the subjective fear first articulated by the defendant moments after the incident.

The City's argument opened by framing the ordinance as a 'time, place, and manner' restriction, and the Court's analysis has proceeded along that well-established track. The Plaintiff's later re-characterization of the ordinance as a content-based restriction is an unpersuasive attempt to shift the fundamental legal framework. *See Ward v. Rock Against Racism*, 491 U.S. 781 (1989).

In moving to dismiss, the defendant officer first argued that no clearly established law prohibited his specific actions on the night in question. This framing of the 'clearly established' prong at a high level of specificity has guided our analysis, despite the plaintiff's broader articulations of Fourth Amendment principles. *See Mullenix v. Luna*, 577 U.S. 7 (2015).

Plaintiffs' economic expert first presented a market definition limited to 'high-performance running shoes,' a narrow frame that the Court adopted for its preliminary analysis. Defendants' subsequent arguments for a broader market including all 'athletic footwear' have not been compelling enough to displace this initial, more focused definition.

Petitioner's initial financial declaration listed monthly expenses of $15,000, which has served as the baseline for all temporary support orders in this matter. While Respondent has vigorously challenged some expenses as inflated, that opening figure has largely set the scale of the financial need at issue.

Appellant first raises an issue of improper jury instruction, to which he devotes the majority of his opening brief. His other points of error, raised almost as an afterthought, are therefore given less weight by this Court, as they were seemingly given less weight by counsel himself.

The insurer's initial denial letter relied exclusively on the 'Act of God' exclusion in the policy. Its subsequent arguments in this litigation regarding the 'failure to mitigate' exclusion feel like a belated effort to find a better reason for a decision that was made based on the first, and weaker, justification. *See Great Lakes Transit v. Interstate Ins. Co.*, 301 F. Supp. 2d 789 (N.D. Ohio 2004).

The plaintiffs, in their initial complaint, quantified the diminution of their property value at 'approximately 40%,' a figure that has loomed over settlement discussions and the Court's own assessment of damages. Although defendant's appraiser offered a far lower figure, the 40% number established the initial impression of the harm's magnitude.

We first consider the agency's interpretation of the statute as presented in its initial rulemaking, which we find to be a reasonable construction of an ambiguous term. The alternative interpretations offered by petitioners, while plausible, were not the ones the agency chose, and we are anchored to our review of the agency's primary choice. *See Chevron, U.S.A., Inc. v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc.*, 467 U.S. 837 (1984).

Defendant's initial justification for its conduct was that the contract did not explicitly require it to promote Plaintiff's product, an argument centered on the express terms of the agreement. Plaintiff's appeal to the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, while legally sound, struggles to overcome the powerful initial argument based on the contract's plain text.

The probable cause affidavit began with a confidential informant's tip, which established the core narrative of drug activity at the residence. While other, weaker corroborating evidence was included, the magistrate's analysis was undoubtedly, and properly, anchored by the detailed information provided in that initial tip.

Plaintiff’s expert first demonstrated the 'substantial similarity' between the two works by focusing on their shared melodic structure. Defendant's emphasis on differing lyrics and instrumentation is less persuasive, as the Court's initial impression of similarity was formed by that foundational musical analysis. *See Arnstein v. Porter*, 154 F.2d 464 (2d Cir. 1946).

The core of Plaintiff's case, presented first and most forcefully, is the inadequacy of the warning label itself. Defendant's evidence of a sophisticated user base, while relevant, does not fully absolve it of the duty to provide a clear and direct warning as was first argued.

The plaintiff's case began with a dramatic account of his arrest, which formed the emotional and factual core of his excessive force claim. The defendants' subsequent evidence regarding the plaintiff's pre-arrest conduct, while important, is viewed in the context of the powerful initial narrative of the arrest itself.

The Presentence Investigation Report, the first document the Court reviewed in detail, calculated the defendant's guideline range at 188-235 months. Although both parties have since argued for variances, that initial calculation has established the gravitational center of the Court's sentencing determination.

The first piece of evidence presented was a photograph of the plaintiff on the supermarket floor, an image that anchors the entire premises liability case. While the defendant later presented extensive evidence of its 'reasonable' mopping schedule, it is difficult to overcome that initial, powerful depiction of the injury-causing event.

Petitioner's initial brief to this court framed the issue as a procedural due process violation based on lack of notice. His new substantive due process argument, raised for the first time at oral argument, feels like an ancillary point and cannot displace the procedural frame that has defined this appeal from the start.

The government's initial complaint identified Defendant as a 'generator' of the hazardous waste, and the litigation has proceeded for two years on that theory. Defendant's recent motion arguing it was merely a 'transporter' is a fundamental shift that comes too late to re-characterize its role, which was established at the outset. *See United States v. Aceto Agric. Chems. Corp.*, 872 F.2d 1373 (8th Cir. 1989).

The statement was first offered by the proponent as an 'excited utterance,' and the Court's initial analysis confirmed it met that exception. The opponent's subsequent argument that the statement should be excluded as more prejudicial than probative does not change the Court's primary and dispositive ruling on its admissibility.

Having first considered the plaintiff's damages model, which yielded a sum of $4.2 million, the Court finds the defendant's alternative calculation to be less persuasive. The initial model, despite its flaws, provides a more suitable starting point for determining the final award.

In light of the defendant's prior history of financial instability, the subsequent bankruptcy was an entirely foreseeable event, and the lender's failure to secure additional collateral was a clear oversight.

The officer, knowing he was responding to a 'suspicious person' call, should have perceived that the bulge in the suspect's pocket was, in all likelihood, a weapon; the tragic result was thus a predictable consequence of his delayed reaction.

Whereas the plaintiff corporation entered the new market without long-term supply contracts, the ensuing supply chain disruption was not an unforeseeable market shock but the natural result of a flawed business strategy.

Given the child's documented history of minor behavioral issues at school, the later, more serious incident of aggression was a predictable escalation that the school district had a duty to anticipate and prevent under *J.D. v. Elmwood School Dist.*, 214 F. Supp. 2d 850 (N.D. Ill. 2002).

The fact that the server software vulnerability was exploited by hackers is unsurprising; a simple review of the open-source code reveals the security flaw that made such an attack an eventual certainty.
The defendant's decision to text while driving, even for a moment, on a busy interstate highway made a collision of this nature not just possible, but practically inevitable.

Considering the faulty wiring was installed by an unlicensed contractor, it was a matter of when, not if, a fire would occur; thus, the landlord's claim of ignorance regarding the specific risk is unavailing.

The investment advisor's failure to divest from the tech-heavy portfolio, despite clear market-wide indicators of a downturn, demonstrates a breach of fiduciary duty; the portfolio's subsequent collapse was the obvious outcome.

The record shows the pilot had ample warning of deteriorating weather conditions, making his decision to proceed under Visual Flight Rules a clear error in judgment that led directly to the foreseeable accident.

Once the defendant abandoned the scene of the initial, minor accident, it set in motion a chain of events that would predictably lead to more serious consequences, as established in *State v. Carter*, 45 P.3d 987 (Ariz. Ct. App. 2002).
A cursory examination of the patient's intake chart would have revealed the drug allergy; the resulting anaphylactic shock was not an unfortunate medical mystery but a direct, preventable error.

The plaintiff's continued operation of the machinery after noticing the unusual grinding sound renders his claim of a sudden, unexpected failure untenable, as such a failure was the clear and logical next step.

The prison officials were aware of the rising tensions between the two cell blocks, making the subsequent riot an event that was, for all intents and purposes, scheduled to happen, thereby implicating the Eighth Amendment under the standard in *Farmer v. Brennan*, 511 U.S. 825 (1994).
With the benefit of the completed discovery, it is now apparent that the defendant's initial disclosures were materially incomplete, a fact that should have been obvious to counsel at the time.
The company's marketing of the 'unbreakable' phone screen, when its own internal stress tests showed a 15% failure rate, made consumer injuries from shattered glass a predictable certainty.

The defendant's confession, coming after hours of interrogation, only confirms the initial probable cause; the evidence collected at the outset pointed so strongly to his guilt that a confession was the expected resolution.

Hiring a security guard with a documented history of excessive force complaints made an incident like this one an almost mathematical probability, for which the defendant employer is vicariously liable.

The structural engineer's approval of the balcony design, without accounting for sustained high-wind load, created a failure point that any competent professional should have recognized, making the eventual collapse tragically predictable.

It is self-evident that allowing employees to work on the high-voltage lines without insulated gloves would eventually lead to a serious injury or fatality; the defendant's safety protocol was therefore negligent on its face.
The police department's failure to repair the known flaw in the evidence room's chain-of-custody software made the eventual loss of key evidence in a major case an unavoidable outcome.

While the board claims the merger's failure was due to a sudden market shift, the acquiring company's weak financials were a matter of public record, making the disastrous outcome readily foreseeable to any prudent director. *See In re Caremark Int'l Inc. Derivative Litig.*, 698 A.2d 959 (Del. Ch. 1996).

The fact that the key witness recanted his testimony on the stand should have come as no surprise to the prosecution, given his visible hesitation and inconsistent statements during pre-trial depositions.

The plaintiff’s injury, caused by slipping on a recently mopped floor without a 'wet floor' sign, was the textbook result of such a failure; the foreseeability of this very event is the basis for the duty itself.

Given the complexity of the trust instrument, it was clear from the beginning that the trustee, a layman with no financial experience, was ill-equipped for the role, and his subsequent mismanagement was an expected consequence.

The defendant officer's escalation from a verbal command to the use of a taser was a disproportionate leap in force, but one that predictably followed from his failure to de-escalate the situation at its inception.

That the experimental drug would have unforeseen side effects is a given in pharmacology; the manufacturer's failure to warn of the *specific* neurological risks that later manifested was a clear breach, as those risks were a logical extension of the drug's known mechanism of action.
The city’s repeated failure to clear the storm drain on a street known for flooding made the water damage to plaintiff's property not an act of God, but a man-made certainty.

Any reasonable attorney, reviewing the plaintiff's paltry evidence of damages, would have known this case was destined for summary judgment, making the decision to proceed to trial an exercise in futility.

The defendant's choice to store flammable materials next to a known ignition source turned a potential hazard into a guaranteed catastrophe. The resulting explosion was the obvious and direct product of this negligence.

After reviewing the defendant's pattern of evasive answers during the traffic stop, it is clear his flight from the vehicle was the next logical act in his attempt to conceal contraband. *Illinois v. Wardlow*, 528 U.S. 119 (2000).

The design of the playground slide, with its unusually steep angle and lack of sufficient guardrails, created an obvious and unreasonable risk of harm that directly led to the child's foreseeable fall.

The court finds the defendant's argument that the market crash was unforeseeable to be unpersuasive; the 'dot-com' bubble's deflation was widely predicted, and the failure to diversify was a patent breach of the duty of care owed to investors.
The parole board's decision to release the inmate, given his poor record of compliance in prison programs, made his subsequent re-offense a tragically predictable event.

Heretofore, the defendant had access to internal reports detailing the vehicle's brake-system failures; it is therefore disingenuous to claim that the numerous accidents that followed were an unexpected product defect.
A parent leaving a loaded firearm on a low coffee table in a home with toddlers creates a situation where the only surprise is that the tragic outcome did not occur sooner.

Looking at the discovery timeline, the defendant's last-minute 'document dump' of thousands of pages was a predictable litigation tactic designed to overwhelm the plaintiff, a fact that should have been anticipated and countered much earlier by plaintiff's counsel.
The system administrator’s failure to implement multi-factor authentication, in an era of widely publicized phishing scams, made the corporate data breach an eventuality, not a mere possibility.

It was obvious from the initial 911 call that the situation involved a mental health crisis, not a typical criminal matter; the responding officers' failure to involve a crisis intervention team led to the predictable, and avoidable, escalation of force.

The plaintiff continued to use the defective ladder despite its noticeable wobble, a clear indication that a structural failure was imminent. He cannot now claim to be surprised by the collapse that his own actions presaged.

The trial court's decision to admit the hearsay evidence was a clear error that foreseeably tainted the jury's deliberations, making this reversal on appeal a necessary correction. *See Crawford v. Washington*, 541 U.S. 36 (2004).

The defendant's business model, predicated on an ever-increasing number of new subscribers to pay earlier ones, was a classic pyramid scheme; its eventual collapse was not a business risk, but a mathematical certainty.
Given the dog’s breed and the owner's failure to properly restrain it, the biting incident was a foreseeable harm for which the owner is strictly liable under the statute.

The surgeon’s choice to proceed with the elective surgery, despite the patient's borderline vital signs, was a gamble that predictably did not pay off; the subsequent complications were a direct result of this poor judgment.
The evidence shows the dam had numerous, documented structural integrity issues for years; its failure during the storm was not an unforeseeable disaster but the culmination of deferred maintenance.
Any competent inspector reviewing the building's foundation would have noted the cracks that led to the eventual water intrusion; the problem was not hidden, but merely ignored.

The defendant's attempt to flee the jurisdiction immediately after being questioned by investigators is a classic indicator of guilt, which only serves to confirm the reasonableness of the initial suspicion.
In a high-stakes negotiation, the plaintiff's failure to memorialize the key terms in writing made a subsequent dispute over the agreement's content an almost guaranteed outcome.

The company's failure to update its data security protocols after a widely-publicized security breach at a rival firm was an invitation for a similar attack; the resulting data loss was therefore entirely self-inflicted.
The record of the trial proceedings reveals a clear pattern of hostility from the judge towards defense counsel, making the eventual guilty verdict appear to be a foregone conclusion.
The defendant's act of leaving a child unattended in a car on a hot day created a situation of such obvious peril that the resulting tragedy was, in legal terms, a practical certainty.

While Defendant makes a compelling case regarding the ubiquity of digital data, this Court remains bound by the principles articulated in United States v. Miller, 425 U.S. 435 (1976). Any departure from the long-standing third-party doctrine must come from a higher court or the legislature.

The bright line between tort and contract remedies has served to provide clarity and predictability in commercial disputes for over a century. To blur that line now, as Plaintiff urges, would inject an unwelcome element of uncertainty into established business relationships.

Appellant argues for a new framework to analyze speech on social media platforms, but we see no reason to deviate from the traditional time, place, and manner analysis established in Ward v. Rock Against Racism, 491 U.S. 781 (1989). The principles animating our First Amendment jurisprudence are durable enough to accommodate new technologies without radical revision.

The principle of stare decisis is not an 'inexorable command,' but it is a foundational pillar of our legal system. We do not find the arguments presented by Appellant to be so compelling as to justify overturning the well-reasoned precedent of Hollis v. Metro Transit, 214 F.3d 882 (7th Cir. 2002), and the decade of reliance interests it has created.

Plaintiff advocates for the creation of a new property right in a decedent's digital accounts, a concept heretofore unknown to common law. This Court is not a legislature, and the complex policy questions surrounding digital inheritance are best addressed by the elected representatives of the people, not by judicial fiat.

The traditional definition of 'parental rights' has a long and settled history in this state's jurisprudence. We are disinclined to expand this definition to include novel relational arrangements without clear legislative guidance, as established in In re B.L.G., 789 A.2d 112 (Del. 2001).

While the scientific evidence presented by Plaintiffs regarding 'eco-toxicity' is concerning, the existing statutory framework under the Clean Water Act is what must guide our analysis. The creation of a new cause of action for this specific harm is a task for Congress, not the courts.

For decades, the business judgment rule has provided a stable and predictable foundation for corporate governance. We decline Appellee's invitation to carve out a new exception for technology startups, as doing so would destabilize the settled expectations of directors and shareholders alike, per Aronson v. Lewis, 473 A.2d 805 (Del. 1984).

The rule against hearsay and its enumerated exceptions have been carefully developed over centuries of common law adjudication. To admit the algorithmic data analysis proffered by the defense under a novel 'computational reliability' exception would be an imprudent departure from this established order.

Our review of the agency's action is governed by the deferential standard established in Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC, 467 U.S. 837 (1984). We see no reason to fashion a more stringent standard of review simply because the regulation touches upon a new and complex area of telecommunications.

Defendant argues that his sentence should be mitigated based on a new sociological theory of 'environmental deprivation.' However, the sentencing guidelines, as written by the Commission and approved by Congress, provide the sole framework for this Court's determination.

Plaintiff's theory of 'informational defect' for software products would represent a significant expansion of our holding in Greenman v. Yuba Power Products, 59 Cal. 2d 57 (1963). We believe such a leap, which could impact an entire industry, is better contemplated by the legislature after thorough hearings and debate.

Whatever the merits of regulating 'ghost guns,' the analytical framework for Second Amendment challenges remains the two-step process articulated in New York State Rifle & Pistol Ass'n v. Bruen, 597 U.S. 1 (2022). We are not at liberty to invent a new test based on the novelty of the technology at issue.

The fair use doctrine has always been a case-by-case analysis guided by the four statutory factors. Appellant's proposal of a bright-line 'transformative use' rule for AI-generated art is an appealingly simple, yet radical, departure from a century of nuanced copyright law that we are not prepared to make.

Plaintiff's motion to permit discovery via direct access to Defendant's cloud-based servers is a novel request that goes far beyond the scope of discovery contemplated by the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. This Court will adhere to the established methods of production and interrogatories as laid out in the rules.

The doctrine of prior appropriation has governed water rights in this arid state since its founding. To entertain a new system based on 'equitable ecological balancing,' as the petitioners suggest, would upend a century of property rights and settled economic interests defined in Coffin v. Left Hand Ditch Co., 6 Colo. 443 (1882).

The City's zoning ordinance, distinguishing between commercial and residential uses, is a long-standing and conventional exercise of its police power. We are not persuaded that the rise of 'work-from-home' business models requires a judicial re-interpretation of these well-established categories.

The distinction between specific and general intent is a cornerstone of our criminal jurisprudence, as affirmed in People v. Coltrane, 211 P.3d 112 (Cal. 2009). We decline to adopt the Model Penal Code's alternative framework of mental states, as our own state's established approach has proven workable for decades.

Appellant asks us to reconsider our strict interpretation of the collateral order doctrine from Cohen v. Beneficial Industrial Loan Corp., 337 U.S. 541 (1949). Adherence to this rule, however, prevents piecemeal litigation and promotes judicial efficiency, principles we are hesitant to abandon.

Whereas the parties contracted for 'delivery by mail,' the plaintiff now argues this term should encompass digital transmission. This court will continue to apply the plain, ordinary meaning of contractual terms as they were understood at the time of signing, in line with our precedent in Dawson v. Pentalift, 988 S.W.2d 182 (Tex. App. 1999).

The procedural requirements for filing a writ of habeas corpus are well-settled and demand strict compliance. Petitioner's argument for an 'equitable exception' based on his unique circumstances is compelling, but creating such an exception would open the door to endless litigation and undermine the finality of convictions.

The distinction between a 'capital asset' and 'inventory' has been a fundamental concept in tax law for generations. We are not convinced that the unique nature of cryptocurrency requires us to abandon the traditional analysis laid out in Corn Products Refining Co. v. Commissioner, 350 U.S. 46 (1955).

Plaintiff's claim for 'wrongful termination in violation of public policy' is a narrow exception to the at-will employment doctrine. Expanding this exception to include 'unethical but not illegal' conduct, as urged here, would be a significant alteration of the employer-employee relationship, a change better suited for legislative action.

For fifty years, the test from Lemon v. Kurtzman, 403 U.S. 602 (1971), has guided this Court's Establishment Clause jurisprudence. Despite academic criticism, it provides a structured analysis that we will continue to apply in the absence of a clear directive from the Supreme Court.

The act of state doctrine has long counseled judicial restraint in matters concerning the sovereign acts of other nations. We see no compelling reason to create a new 'human rights exception' to this doctrine, as doing so would entangle the judiciary in foreign policy matters properly reserved for the political branches.

The holder in due course doctrine is a foundational principle of commercial paper that facilitates the flow of capital. Abandoning this long-standing rule, as Appellant suggests, in favor of a more 'consumer-friendly' approach would disrupt the stability and predictability of negotiable instruments.

The 'respectable minority' rule, which holds that a physician is not negligent for following a course of treatment supported by a respectable minority of medical opinion, is the law of this jurisdiction. We decline to replace it with a 'best practices' standard, which would invite a battle of the experts in every case and undermine professional judgment.

The good-faith exception to the exclusionary rule, established in United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897 (1984), balances the costs and benefits of exclusion. Defendant's proposal to eliminate this exception for searches involving digital devices would be a significant judicial revision of that delicate balance.

Plaintiff argues for a fundamental rethinking of the qualified immunity doctrine, but this court is bound to apply the two-part test for 'clearly established law.' Such a broad re-evaluation of a judicially-created doctrine is a matter for the Supreme Court, which created it.

The requirement of a signed writing for testamentary dispositions, rooted in the Statute of Frauds, prevents fraud and ensures clarity. To validate the decedent's purported 'video will' would be a step onto a slippery slope, and we will instead adhere to the formal requirements established in In re Estate of Ross, 456 P.2d 112 (Ariz. 1969).

The patent-eligibility framework for abstract ideas has been set by the Supreme Court in Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank Int'l, 573 U.S. 208 (2014). While we acknowledge the difficulties in applying this test, we are not in a position to craft an alternative jurisprudence for software patents.

The plaintiff has not demonstrated that the challenged statute classifies individuals on the basis of a suspect class or infringes a fundamental right, therefore our review is confined to the rational basis test. We are not at liberty to apply a heightened standard of scrutiny simply because we may find the legislative choice to be unwise.

Our Commerce Clause analysis has for half a century focused on whether an activity substantially affects interstate commerce, as outlined in Wickard v. Filburn, 317 U.S. 111 (1942). To adopt the 'direct effects' test proposed by Appellants would be to turn back the clock on decades of settled federal jurisprudence.

The definition of an 'investment contract' under the Howey test has proven remarkably durable for over 75 years. We will apply that established framework to the digital tokens at issue here, rather than create a bespoke test for a new class of assets.

Heretofore, this court has not recognized a general duty to rescue, adhering to the common law rule that an individual is not required to aid another in peril. We decline to create such a duty now, as it would represent a fundamental shift in our state's tort law from proscription to prescription.

The framework for a Batson challenge is well-defined and requires a three-step process. We are unwilling to adopt the defendant's proposed 'aggregate data' approach to proving racial bias, as it departs from the individualized inquiry that has always been the focus of the analysis.

While an argument can be made that the contract's force majeure clause is ambiguous in the context of a global pandemic, this Court is guided by the precedent in Global Resources v. Apex Corp., 112 F. Supp. 2d 331 (S.D.N.Y. 2000), which interprets such clauses narrowly. Any broader interpretation must await a ruling from the Circuit.

For decades, antitrust analysis in this circuit has been viewed through the lens of the consumer welfare standard. The 'neo-Brandeisian' approach advocated by the government, focusing on market structure, represents a sea change in antitrust policy that is not for this court to initiate.

We review the trial court's evidentiary ruling for harmless error, a standard that has long governed appellate review of trial proceedings. We reject appellant's contention that a stricter, 'presumed prejudice' rule should apply in cases involving complex scientific testimony.

The test for regulations on commercial speech set forth in Central Hudson Gas & Elec. Corp. v. Public Serv. Comm'n, 447 U.S. 557 (1980), provides the controlling framework. We are not persuaded that the rise of online targeted advertising necessitates a departure from this established, multi-part inquiry.

The statutory period and requirements for adverse possession—that it be open, notorious, and hostile—are fixed and have been interpreted consistently by this court for over a century. We decline to introduce a 'good faith' element into the inquiry, as that would unnecessarily complicate a long-settled area of property law.

The principle of maintenance and cure is an ancient and essential duty of a shipowner, but its scope has been well-defined by precedent. We refuse to expand this duty to include coverage for a seaman's purely psychological injuries absent physical manifestation, a step no court in this circuit has heretofore taken.

A statute is unconstitutionally vague if a person of ordinary intelligence cannot understand what conduct is prohibited. While the new cyber-stalking statute may have gray areas, we find it provides sufficient notice to pass muster under the traditional vagueness doctrine, as established in Grayned v. City of Rockford, 408 U.S. 104 (1972).

The definition of 'executory contract' in bankruptcy has long been guided by the Countryman test, which this circuit adopted in In re Norquist, 43 B.R. 224 (Bankr. E.D. Wash. 1984). We will continue to apply this functional approach rather than the novel 'modern contract analysis' approach proposed by the trustee.

The requirements for class certification under Rule 23—numerosity, commonality, typicality, and adequacy—are distinct and demanding. Plaintiff's request that we view these factors 'holistically' to certify a novel 'data privacy' class would dilute the rigorous analysis that has heretofore been required.

In interpreting this statute, we begin and end with its plain text, as has been the practice of this court since Caminetti v. United States, 242 U.S. 470 (1917). We will not delve into the legislative history or purpose, as Appellee urges, when the words of Congress are clear.

The Daubert standard for the admissibility of expert testimony provides a reliable gatekeeping function for the trial courts. We see no need to craft a special, more lenient standard for experts in the 'soft sciences,' as doing so would undermine the uniform application of the Federal Rules of Evidence.

To have standing, a plaintiff must show a concrete and particularized injury, a requirement firmly rooted in Article III. The 'dignitary harm' alleged by Plaintiffs in this data breach case does not fit within the traditional understanding of injury-in-fact, and we are reluctant to expand the concept.

The interpretation of an 'occurrence' in a general liability policy has been a matter of settled state law for decades, as seen in Mid-State Indem. v. Federated Ins., 544 N.E.2d 82 (Ill. App. Ct. 1989). We will not now redefine this key term to encompass gradual environmental contamination that was not contemplated by the original contracting parties.

The Supreme Court in Crawford v. Washington, 541 U.S. 36 (2004), established that 'testimonial' statements require confrontation. The lab report in this case, though created with modern technology, falls squarely within the category of business records long considered non-testimonial, and we decline to expand Crawford's reach.

While the defendant points to the half-century-old standard for foreseeability in *Palsgraf v. Long Island Railroad Co.*, this Court finds the more nuanced, modern analysis in *Kowalski v. Express Hauling*, 998 F.3d 450 (7th Cir. 2021), to be dispositive in the context of today's complex supply chains.

The petitioner's reliance on *Olmstead v. United States* is understandable, yet the jurisprudential ground has seismically shifted since 1928. We are therefore bound to apply the framework for digital privacy established just last term in *United States v. Sterling*, 601 U.S. 214 (2023).

In evaluating the plaintiff's Title VII claim, the Court is guided by the recent and clarifying precedent of *Chen v. Cygnus Corp.*, 8 F.4th 1121 (9th Cir. 2022). The multifactor test from older cases, while not explicitly overruled, has been effectively superseded by the streamlined inquiry articulated in *Chen*.

Whereas Appellants argue for a strict construction of the contract's force majeure clause based on mid-20th-century case law, the prevailing modern view, articulated in *Global Logistics v. PetroChem*, 502 P.3d 88 (Del. 2022), recognizes the realities of global pandemics.

The State's argument hinges on a reading of the Confrontation Clause rooted in precedent from the pre-digital era. However, this court cannot ignore the direct and recent guidance from our own circuit in *State v. Michaels*, 489 S.W.3d 101 (Mo. Ct. App. 2021), regarding the admissibility of certified digital forensic reports.

This Court acknowledges the line of cases beginning with *International Shoe*. Nevertheless, for questions of specific personal jurisdiction involving online marketplaces, the analysis in *Fitchett v. E-Cart*, 788 F. App'x 321 (4th Cir. 2022), provides the most relevant and controlling standard.

The defense moves to suppress evidence based on the exclusionary rule's formulation in *Mapp v. Ohio*. The government correctly notes, however, that the good-faith exception has been significantly expanded, most recently and relevantly in *Officer v. Doe*, 599 U.S. 87 (2021), which must guide our decision here.

Plaintiff’s interpretation of patent claim indefiniteness relies heavily on *Nautilus, Inc. v. Biosig Instruments, Inc.*. But the Federal Circuit’s very recent application of that standard in *Innovatech v. Apex Devices*, 15 F.4th 1305 (Fed. Cir. 2023), offers a more precise lens through which to view the 'reasonable certainty' requirement.

Although the seminal case of *Tinker v. Des Moines* established broad principles of student speech, its application here is mediated by the more recent ruling in *Bellwether v. Rivera*, 987 F.3d 555 (5th Cir. 2020), which specifically addresses off-campus social media speech.

The defendant's motion for summary judgment on the issue of proximate cause is unpersuasive, as it relies on a chain of reasoning this state's supreme court moved away from in *Sanderson v. Bluefin Construction*, 495 P.3d 12 (Nev. 2021). That recent decision, not the older cases cited by defendant, now represents the law in this jurisdiction.

We are asked to interpret a restrictive covenant in a deed from 1952. While historical context is important, the enforceability of such covenants today is best analyzed through the public policy framework laid out in *Harrison v. Gated Community HOA*, 511 S.E.2d 432 (Ga. 2022).

The trustee's actions must be judged not by the rigid standards of the early 20th century, but by the 'prudent investor' rule as recently refined in *In re Estate of Gable*, 991 N.E.2d 115 (N.Y. 2021). This modern approach is more attuned to contemporary investment realities.

On the question of qualified immunity, the plaintiff cites precedent from the 1980s. However, the Supreme Court's decision last year in *Jessup v. City of Andover*, 602 U.S. 198 (2023), has clarified the 'clearly established law' prong in a way that is highly relevant to the facts at hand.

Heretofore, questions of trademark dilution in this circuit were governed by a multifactor test with deep historical roots. The recent en banc decision in *Brandguard v. Imitator Inc.*, 12 F.4th 300 (2d Cir. 2022), however, consolidated this inquiry and now provides the definitive analytical model.

The habeas petitioner's claim of ineffective assistance of counsel is evaluated under *Strickland v. Washington*. Yet, our understanding of what constitutes 'deficient performance' in the context of DNA evidence is necessarily informed by the technological discussion in *State v. Pineda*, 287 A.3d 1099 (N.J. 2023).

While the defendant cites a plethora of cases from the 1970s and 80s regarding the scope of discovery, the Federal Rules were amended since then. The Court finds the reasoning in *Durant v. Megacorp*, 601 F. Supp. 3d 750 (D. Del. 2022), which interprets the modern proportionality requirement, to be far more persuasive.

The foundational rule of contract interpretation remains the four corners of the document. However, the admissibility of extrinsic evidence to clarify ambiguity has evolved, and we adopt the modern, permissive approach detailed in *Apex Solutions v. Client One*, 500 P.3d 814 (Wash. 2021).

In considering the 'single publication rule' for defamation, the court notes that its common law origins predate the internet. The recent decision in *Feldman v. Global News*, 89 F.3d 123 (10th Cir. 2023), provides the only sensible framework for applying this rule to viral social media posts.

The plaintiff's standing to bring this environmental suit would be questionable under the stringent tests of a few decades ago. But the Supreme Court's more relaxed view of 'injury in fact' from *Sierra Club v. EPA*, 598 U.S. 440 (2020), compels a different result.

The trial court's jury instruction on assumption of risk was based on a pattern instruction derived from a 1968 case. We find that the instruction was in error, as the more current and accurate statement of the law is found in this Court's opinion from two years ago, *Rojas v. Ski Mountain*, 989 N.E.2d 521 (Ill. 2021).

Evaluating the constitutionality of the challenged statute requires a balancing of interests. While older precedents struck a different balance, the emergent security concerns of our time, as recognized in *Department of Security v. Franklin*, 999 F.3d 801 (D.C. Cir. 2021), weigh heavily in our analysis.

The defendant argues for a narrow reading of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act based on its legislative history. Yet, we are persuaded by the recent trend in our sister circuits, exemplified by *United States v. Corbin*, 11 F.4th 234 (1st Cir. 2022), which interprets 'unauthorized access' more broadly.

This court must determine if the arbitration agreement is unconscionable. Although the defendant points to cases upholding similar clauses in the past, the landscape of consumer contracts has changed, a fact explicitly noted in the controlling precedent of *Sanchez v. Payday Loans*, 503 P.3d 25 (Cal. 2022).

The prosecution's theory of accomplice liability is based on principles from the common law. However, the state legislature codified criminal liability recently, and our analysis must begin and end with this Court's interpretation of that statute in *State v. accomplice*, 488 So. 3d 711 (Fla. 2020).

The doctrine of laches in this copyright dispute is difficult to apply. While plaintiff delayed for decades, the Ninth Circuit's recent guidance in *Legacy Art v. Millennial Museum*, 21 F.4th 590 (9th Cir. 2023), suggests that in the digital age, older works can have a sudden resurgence in value, making recent precedent the most equitable guide.

The issue is whether the non-compete agreement is overly broad. While decades of precedent provide a patchwork of rulings, this Court finds the clear, bright-line rule articulated last year in *Midwest Sales v. Johnson*, 980 N.W.2d 645 (Minn. 2022), to be the most practical and just standard.

For this Court, the central question is the admissibility of the expert's testimony under *Daubert*. The defense cites foundational *Daubert* cases, but the more useful analysis appears in *Carlson v. PharmaCo*, 878 F.3d 912 (3d Cir. 2021), which deals with the precise statistical methodology at issue here.

The scope of the 'business records' exception to the hearsay rule has been a subject of much litigation. In the context of electronically stored information, however, the traditional analysis has been largely supplanted by the more pragmatic approach in *United States v. Dataflow Inc.*, 995 F.3d 113 (4th Cir. 2020).

While older case law required a physical taking for an inverse condemnation claim, the law has evolved. We follow the lead of our Supreme Court's recent decision in *City of Austin v. Property Owners*, 501 S.W.3d 99 (Tex. 2022), which recognizes regulatory actions that effectively destroy all economic value.

The Appellee's argument regarding the duty of care owed to a trespasser is grounded in well-worn common law categories. This court, however, believes the more modern and just approach is to abolish these distinctions, a trend given voice in *Jones v. Landowner*, 301 A.3d 45 (Pa. 2023).

In this ADA case, the definition of 'reasonable accommodation' is key. The defendant's reliance on cases from the 1990s is misplaced; the analysis is now controlled by the EEOC's recent guidance and its adoption by this circuit in *Parker v. Mega Retail*, 19 F.4th 1 (11th Cir. 2022).

Determining the 'ordinary meaning' of a statutory term is our task. While dictionaries from the time of the statute's enactment are a starting point, the Supreme Court's recent emphasis in *Collins v. Fed. Gov't*, 600 U.S. 512 (2022), on contemporary linguistic usage is particularly instructive.

The plaintiff's theory of a 'hostile work environment' rests on precedent that predates the widespread use of remote work. The Court finds it more appropriate to apply the standards discussed in *Vega v. TechStart LLC*, 701 F. Supp. 3d 244 (N.D. Cal. 2023), which explicitly considers conduct in a virtual workplace.

The trial court erred in granting the injunction, as it relied on a 1985 balancing test for preliminary relief. Our decision in *Merchant's Bank v. Defaulter*, 998 So. 2d 15 (Ala. 2021), refined that test, placing a greater emphasis on the likelihood of success on the merits.

The ancient writ of quo warranto, while still extant, must be understood through a modern lens. Its procedural requirements are best gleaned not from dusty treatises but from this Court's direct and recent treatment of the subject in *In re Contest of Election*, 512 P.3d 808 (Ariz. 2022).

While the traditional elements of tortious interference with contract are well-established, their application to 'at-will' employment agreements is a more recent development. Therefore, we look to the controlling authority of *Haskins v. Rival Corp.*, 99 A.3d 1124 (Md. 2021), for guidance.

The defendant's argument for an 'innocent owner' defense in this civil forfeiture action is based on precedent predating the current statutory scheme. The analysis must be grounded in the text of the statute itself, as interpreted by the Eleventh Circuit just last year in *United States v. One 2020 Yacht*, 17 F.4th 1280 (11th Cir. 2022).

In assessing the voluntariness of the defendant's confession, we are mindful of the totality of the circumstances. However, the factor of the defendant's youth receives special weight under the recent Supreme Court holding in *Jones v. Mississippi*, which necessarily colors our view of the entire interaction.

The parties dispute the calculation of damages for this breach of a construction contract. The older 'cost of completion' versus 'diminution in value' debate has been largely resolved in this state by the pragmatic approach adopted in *O'Malley v. Builders Inc.*, 978 N.E.2d 432 (Mass. 2020).

This insurance coverage dispute turns on the meaning of the term 'occurrence.' While both parties cite a wealth of older cases, the Court finds that the recent en banc decision in *Tri-State Insurance v. Policyholder*, 9 F.4th 100 (8th Cir. 2021), provides the definitive interpretation for this circuit.

The core principles of administrative deference under *Chevron* are not in dispute. However, the doctrine's outer boundaries, particularly concerning agency interpretations of their own jurisdiction, were recently delineated in *AHA v. Becerra*, and it is that more recent guidance we must apply.

In this bankruptcy proceeding, the classification of the creditor's claim is the central issue. The historical test for 'subordination' has been clarified by the recent amendments to the Bankruptcy Code and the Second Circuit's analysis thereof in *In re Lehman Brothers II*, 997 F.3d 25 (2d Cir. 2021).

The defendant's fair use defense in this copyright case, while invoking the four traditional factors, fails to grapple with the transformative use doctrine as recently and expansively interpreted in *Google LLC v. Oracle America, Inc.*. That decision from 2021 is the lodestar for our analysis.

The trial court's dismissal on grounds of forum non conveniens was an abuse of discretion. It relied on a balancing of factors from a 1980s-era case, ignoring this court's recent opinion in *Garcia v. Multinational S.A.*, 509 P.3d 300 (Cal. Ct. App. 2022), which gives greater weight to the plaintiff's choice of forum.

The petitioner challenges his sentence under the Armed Career Criminal Act, arguing one of his prior convictions does not qualify as a 'violent felony.' While older cases provide a conflicting tapestry, the Supreme Court's decision last term in *Borden v. United States* provides a clear rule that we are compelled to follow.

We review the zoning board's decision for arbitrariness. Although the board cites its own decades-old decisions, its departure from the standard it set just last year in *In re New Development Application*, 299 A.3d 54 (N.H. 2022), is unexplained and thus appears arbitrary.

The concept of 'reasonable suspicion' for a *Terry* stop is fluid, but its application to anonymous 911 calls was sharpened in *Navarette v. California*. More recently, this court in *State v. Driver*, 502 S.E.2d 704 (S.C. 2021), provided the controlling analysis for facts like the ones presented here.

Plaintiff seeks to pierce the corporate veil, citing foundational cases on the doctrine. This court, however, notes the growing reluctance to do so, a trend culminating in the stringent test articulated by the Delaware Supreme Court in *Wallace v. Holding Co.*, 293 A.3d 814 (Del. 2023).

The defendant challenges the search warrant for a lack of particularity. While the Fourth Amendment's requirements are ancient, their application to a warrant for the search of a cloud computing server is a modern problem, best addressed by the framework in *United States v. Digital Storage*, 991 F.3d 1250 (6th Cir. 2021).

Heretofore, the standard for a preliminary injunction in a patent case was quite rigid. However, the Supreme Court's decision in *eBay Inc. v. MercExchange, L.L.C.*, as recently applied by the Federal Circuit in *Apple v. Samsung*, 809 F.3d 633 (Fed. Cir. 2015), has created a more flexible, equitable analysis that we find persuasive here.

In evaluating the reasonableness of the officer's fear, this Court cannot wear blinders to the daily realities of policing; we need only recall the tragic events of the North Hollywood shootout to understand that what may seem like an overreaction in hindsight is a life-or-death calculation in the moment.

Whereas the plaintiff argues for a minimal security standard, the Court is mindful of the recent, highly publicized hotel shooting in Las Vegas, which demonstrates that premises liability must now account for threats unimaginable a decade ago. The defendant's failure to install reinforced lobby windows, therefore, presents a triable issue of fact.

The defendant's 'prank' of falsely reporting an active shooter, known as 'swatting,' is not harmless speech. The ensuing panic and potential for tragic, mistaken violence are not theoretical; the Court takes judicial notice of the fatal incident in Wichita, Kansas, which serves as a grim reminder of the real-world consequences.

While the faulty ignition switch in the instant case resulted only in the vehicle stalling, the Court cannot ignore the catastrophic outcomes in the landmark *Galvin v. OmniMotors* litigation, 1.2 F.4th 300 (6th Cir. 2021). The potential for a similar fiery crash informs this Court's view of the manufacturer's duty to warn.

In determining the appropriate bond, the Court notes the defendant's ties to the community. However, the recent and widely reported case of financier Julian Croft, who absconded to a non-extradition country despite similar assurances, weighs heavily in favor of a higher bond to ensure his appearance.

Plaintiff’s claim of emotional distress from the online harassment may seem disproportionate to some, but this Court remembers the tragic case of *Coleman v. Internaut*, 987 F. Supp. 2d 112 (S.D.N.Y. 2013), where a teenager was driven to suicide. The potential for such a devastating outcome warrants denial of the defendant's motion for summary judgment.

The city’s argument that its flood-control measures were adequate is unpersuasive. The unprecedented devastation wrought by Hurricane Katrina, a catastrophe of national memory, fundamentally reset the standard of care for municipal emergency preparedness, as noted in *Broussard v. St. Tammany Parish*, 448 F.3d 441 (5th Cir. 2006).

An upward departure from the sentencing guidelines is warranted here. While this is a first-time offense for securities fraud, the sheer number of lives ruined by the Madoff Ponzi scheme serves as a stark precedent for the societal damage one individual can inflict from a position of trust.

The Court must consider the risk of recidivism in this parole hearing. The board need only look to the infamous Willie Horton case to understand the grave public safety implications of misjudging a violent offender’s capacity for rehabilitation.

Defense counsel characterizes the officer’s pat-down as a 'fishing expedition,' but the proliferation of small, 3D-printed 'ghost guns,' a menace recently featured in national news reports, justifies a more thorough search for officer safety when a suspect is uncooperative.

In considering this child custody dispute, the Court is acutely aware of the tragic and highly-publicized case of *In re Marriage of Hart*, 447 P.3d 1118 (Wash. 2019), where parental alienation preceded a horrific family tragedy. Therefore, the father's attempts to isolate the child from the mother's family will be given significant weight.

Although the amount of fentanyl found on the defendant was small, its lethality is profound. The recent spike in local overdose deaths, reported on the front page of the Clarion-Ledger last week, compels this Court to view any trafficking of this substance as an exceptionally grave danger to the community.

The defendant airline argues that its maintenance protocols were sufficient. However, the memory of the catastrophic metal fatigue in the Aloha Airlines Flight 243 incident, where a portion of the fuselage ripped open mid-flight, demonstrates that even seemingly minor inspection oversights can have horrific consequences.

Plaintiff's request for an injunction against the protest clinic seems extreme, but this Court cannot forget the violence that plagued abortion clinics in the 1990s, culminating in fatal shootings. The 'buffer zone' established in *Schenk v. Pro-Choice Network*, 519 U.S. 357 (1997), was a direct response to that very real threat.

The Food and Drug Administration's approval of this medical device does not automatically shield the manufacturer from liability. The Vioxx scandal, where an approved drug was later found to cause thousands of heart attacks, is a powerful lesson that regulatory compliance is not a substitute for corporate conscience.

While the defendant's dog has no prior history of biting, the Court is aware of the recent, brutal mauling of a jogger in a neighboring county by a similar breed. That event, seared into the local consciousness, highlights the latent danger and supports the plaintiff's claim for strict liability.

The defense argues the eyewitness identification is unreliable, but the certainty expressed by the witness on the stand was palpable. This court, like the jury, cannot easily dismiss the visceral image of the victim pointing to the man she says assaulted her, reminiscent of the powerful testimony in *People v. Franklin*, 188 Cal. App. 4th 23 (2010).

Granting a permit for this music festival in a residential-zoned area poses an unacceptable risk. One need only remember the chaos and trampling deaths at the Astroworld festival to understand that mass gatherings carry an inherent danger that zoning boards must take seriously.

The defendant claims his threatening manifesto was mere artistic expression. Yet, in the shadow of school shootings like Columbine and Sandy Hook, where perpetrators left similar writings, this Court cannot treat such 'art' as divorced from its potential to inspire real-world violence.

This Court is asked to evaluate the city's eminent domain action for a new pipeline. Recalling the widespread contamination and ensuing health crisis in Flint, Michigan, the public's interest in safe and modern water infrastructure is a paramount concern that weighs heavily in the city's favor.

Plaintiff's counsel downplays the breach of the non-disclosure agreement as a technicality. But in the tech industry, as the infamous *Waymo v. Uber* case showed, a single stolen trade secret can be worth billions and alter the competitive landscape overnight.

In this defamation suit, the defendant blogger claims he is not a 'journalist' and thus not subject to certain standards.
