The defendant's 'Terms of Service' purport to grant it a perpetual, worldwide license to use customer-uploaded content for any purpose. This Court finds such a term, hidden in a dense legal document, to be substantively unconscionable, as it effectively expropriates the user's intellectual property without meaningful consent or compensation. See Feldman v. Google, Inc., 513 F. Supp. 2d 229 (E.D. Pa. 2007).

The defendant's consent to search his car's trunk did not extend to the officer prying open a locked container found within it. A citizen's waiver of their Fourth Amendment rights must be narrowly construed, and we will not infer consent to a more intrusive search from a limited, general consent. See Florida v. Jimeno, 500 U.S. 248 (1991).

Plaintiff alleges she was paid less than her male predecessor for performing substantially the same work. The defendant's argument that the predecessor's higher salary was based on 'market factors' at the time of his hiring is not a sufficient affirmative defense under the Equal Pay Act without a more specific showing that the disparity is truly based on a factor other than sex. See Corning Glass Works v. Brennan, 417 U.S. 188 (1974).

Holding an inmate in solitary confinement for over three years, with only one hour of exercise per day in a caged enclosure, presents a 'serious risk of harm' to the inmate's mental and physical health. While we do not hold today that long-term solitary is per se unconstitutional, we find that plaintiff has stated a valid claim under the Eighth Amendment. See Hutto v. Finney, 437 U.S. 678 (1978).

A public university, as a quintessential marketplace of ideas, cannot expel a student for off-campus speech that it finds offensive, absent a showing that the speech caused a substantial disruption to the campus environment. The university's role is to foster debate, not to enforce ideological conformity. See Healy v. James, 408 U.S. 169 (1972).

The appellant challenges the use of statistical sampling to prove class-wide damages, arguing it violates the Rules Enabling Act. Where individualized inquiries are impossible or impractical, however, statistical evidence is often the only viable method for providing relief to victims of widespread, low-cost consumer fraud. See Tyson Foods, Inc. v. Bouaphakeo, 577 U.S. 442 (2016).

The government's claim of a 'state secrets' privilege to dismiss this entire lawsuit cannot be accepted at face value. While the privilege is real, it is not a magic wand that the executive can wave to make litigation it finds inconvenient disappear, especially where there are allegations of serious constitutional violations against citizens. See United States v. Reynolds, 345 U.S. 1 (1953).

The defendant company claims its mandatory wellness program, which requires genetic testing, is 'voluntary' because employees can opt out, albeit with a significant financial penalty. This definition of 'voluntary' strains credulity and runs afoul of the Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA), which was passed to prevent precisely this kind of economic coercion. See Allen v. Petro-Chem Corp., 991 F. Supp. 2d 543 (S.D.N.Y. 2014).

Whereas the Miranda warnings are a procedural safeguard, they are not a mere formality to be recited by rote. When an officer immediately follows the warning that 'anything you say can be used against you' with the assurance that 'we just want to hear your side of the story,' they create a confusion that may vitiate the knowing and intelligent waiver of the right to remain silent. See Missouri v. Seibert, 542 U.S. 600 (2004).

A manufacturer's duty to warn does not end when the product leaves the factory. Where a company becomes aware of a dangerous defect in its product years after sale, it has a continuing, post-sale duty to warn known purchasers of the risk. To hold otherwise would incentivize companies to remain ignorant and leave consumers unknowingly at risk. See Patton v. A.O. Smith Water Prods., 563 F. Supp. 3d 112 (E.D. La. 2021).

The agency's new rule sharply curtails the criteria for demonstrating a 'well-founded fear of persecution.' This represents a departure from decades of settled interpretation with no reasoned explanation, rendering the rule arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act. An agency cannot simply change its mind; it must show its work. See FCC v. Fox Television Stations, Inc., 556 U.S. 502 (2009).

Plaintiff, a transgender student, was denied access to the boys' restroom, a facility consistent with his gender identity. This constitutes discrimination 'on the basis of sex' in violation of Title IX. The plain meaning of 'sex' in the context of a civil rights statute must be interpreted broadly to include gender identity to effectuate the law's anti-discrimination purpose. See Bostock v. Clayton County, 140 S. Ct. 1731 (2020).

This court is not persuaded by the defendant's argument that its algorithm for screening job applicants is a 'trade secret' that cannot be discovered. Where a plaintiff makes a prima facie showing that an automated system has a discriminatory disparate impact, the defendant cannot hide the evidence of that potential discrimination behind a veil of proprietary secrecy. See Daniels v. InnoTech, 87 F. Supp. 3d 309 (N.D. Cal. 2015).

The doctrine of 'de facto parenthood' recognizes the reality that a child's well-being is often tied to individuals who are not their biological or adoptive parents. Where a person has formed a bonded, parent-like relationship with a child, with the encouragement of the legal parent, they may be granted standing to seek custody or visitation. See V.C. v. M.J.B., 163 N.J. 200 (2000).

The defendant officer initiated a traffic stop based on a single, isolated weave within a lane, which is not a violation of the vehicle code. Because the initial stop was not justified by reasonable suspicion, all evidence obtained as a result of that stop is fruit of the poisonous tree and must be suppressed. See Delaware v. Prouse, 440 U.S. 648 (1979).

The plaintiff, an at-will employee, was fired after refusing his employer's demand to engage in an illegal act. While the at-will doctrine is well-established, this Court recognizes a narrow public policy exception; an employer cannot use its power of termination to compel an employee to break the law. See Petermann v. Int'l Bhd. of Teamsters, 174 Cal. App. 2d 184 (1959).

The trial court's imposition of numerous court fees and fines on the indigent defendant, without first inquiring into his ability to pay, amounts to a modern-day debtors' prison. Such a practice effectively punishes the defendant for his poverty, a result inconsistent with the principles of equal justice under the law. See Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660 (1983).

The Constitution's protections follow a student through the schoolhouse gates, and they are not shed when a student engages in expression online from their own home. For the school to discipline a student for off-campus, non-threatening speech, it must show a far more substantial disruption than the 'discomfort' and 'anxiety' alleged here. See Mahanoy Area Sch. Dist. v. B.L., 141 S. Ct. 2038 (2021).

The defendant's argument that the plaintiff 'assumed the risk' by playing the sport is unavailing. While participants in recreational sports assume the ordinary risks inherent in the activity, they do not assume the risk of another player's reckless or intentional conduct that violates the rules of the game. See Knight v. Jewett, 3 Cal. 4th 296 (1992).

The district's zoning ordinance, which prohibits the construction of multi-family housing, has the practical effect of excluding lower-income residents and perpetuating segregation. Even without evidence of discriminatory intent, a zoning law that has such a clear exclusionary effect must be justified by a compelling state interest under our state constitution. See Southern Burlington County NAACP v. Township of Mount Laurel, 67 N.J. 151 (1975).

A checkpoint established for the primary purpose of 'general crime control' is a programmatic and intrusive search that violates the Fourth Amendment. The state's interest in apprehending criminals does not justify the suspicionless seizure of every motorist on a public road. See City of Indianapolis v. Edmond, 531 U.S. 32 (2000).

We hold that a plaintiff bringing a 'failure to accommodate' claim under the Fair Housing Act need not show discriminatory intent. The Act requires that housing providers make reasonable accommodations for persons with disabilities, and the failure to do so is itself the violation, regardless of the provider's motive. See Giebeler v. M & B Associates, 343 F.3d 1143 (9th Cir. 2003).

The plaintiff’s argument hinges on the purported 'spirit' of the Fair Housing Act, but this Court is tasked with interpreting its text, not its aspirational penumbras. The statute forbids discrimination based on 'familial status,' a defined term that does not encompass the plaintiff’s co-living arrangement. See O'Malley v. Sterling Properties, 45 F.3d 112 (2d Cir. 1999).

We begin, as we must, with the words of the contract itself. The force majeure clause explicitly lists 'earthquake, flood, or fire' as excusing events; a market downturn, however catastrophic, is not an enumerated item. This Court will not add terms to a freely negotiated agreement. Apex Solutions v. Global Data Corp., 890 F. Supp. 2d 45 (S.D.N.Y. 2018).

The Commonwealth’s argument asks us to consider the legislative purpose behind the Wiretapping Act, yet the statutory text is our sole and sufficient guide. Section 2(a) requires consent from 'all parties to the communication,' and does not contain an exception for communications where one party has no reasonable expectation of privacy. We decline to create one.

Appellant contends that a conviction under 18 U.S.C. § 922(g) requires proof that he knew he belonged to the class of persons prohibited from possessing a firearm. The statute, however, only requires knowledge of possessing the firearm itself, not knowledge of one's legal status. The text is unambiguous, and our inquiry ends there. United States v. Harding, 789 F.3d 601 (6th Cir. 2015).

The Fourth Amendment protects 'persons, houses, papers, and effects.' By its own terms, this protection does not extend to the open fields surrounding the defendant's property, regardless of the subjective privacy he hoped to maintain there. The text is the boundary of the right. State v. Miller, 421 P.3d 90 (Or. 2018).

Whereas the appellee urges a 'practical' reading of the insurance policy, the policy’s definition of 'vehicle' is limited to 'a land-based conveyance with four or more wheels.' A two-wheeled motorcycle, therefore, does not fall within the plain meaning of the covered property. The district court’s finding to the contrary was in error. Progressive Indemnity v. Yates, 102 F.3d 334 (8th Cir. 2022).

The petitioner’s reliance on legislative history is unavailing where the statutory text is clear. The National Labor Relations Act guarantees the right to 'self-organization,' and does not qualify this right based on the size or formality of the employee group. We must enforce the statute as written, not as some legislators might have wished it were written. Encino Motors v. Salazar, 580 U.S. 23 (2017).

This court must determine if a digital file constitutes 'goods' under the Uniform Commercial Code. The Code, as enacted, defines 'goods' as 'all things...which are movable at the time of identification to the contract for sale.' Because a digital file lacks physical movability, it cannot be defined as a 'good' under the statute’s explicit language. Franklin Software v. B&B Consulting, 312 Cal. Rptr. 3d 55 (Cal. Ct. App. 2021).

The defendant was charged with violating a city ordinance prohibiting 'any animal' in the public library. While a goldfish in a bowl may seem innocuous, the ordinance makes no distinction as to species, threat level, or confinement. This Court’s duty is to apply the law’s plain text, not to judge its wisdom. City of Fairview v. Perkins, 956 N.E.2d 134 (Ohio 2011).

The operative text of the Copyright Act grants protection to 'original works of authorship fixed in any tangible medium of expression.' 17 U.S.C. § 102(a). An idea for a novel, which is all the plaintiff possessed, is not 'fixed' in any medium. Thus, it falls outside the express textual bounds of federal copyright protection.

In interpreting the phrase 'use of a destructive device' in 18 U.S.C. § 924(c), we are bound by the ordinary meaning of 'use.' The defendant's act of trading a grenade for narcotics constitutes 'use' in the sense of employing an item for a purpose. The statute does not require that the device be detonated or brandished. See United States v. Corrigan, 911 F.3d 42 (11th Cir. 2019).

The plaintiff's claim for benefits under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) fails on a simple textual reading of the plan documents. The plan defines 'disability' as the inability to perform 'any occupation,' not the 'claimant’s occupation.' Though harsh, this language is unambiguous and must be enforced as drafted. Jensen v. Aetna Life Ins. Co., 455 F. Supp. 3d 789 (D. Minn. 2020).

The constitutional provision for the emoluments clause prohibits any 'Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust' from accepting gifts from foreign states. U.S. Const. art. I, § 9, cl. 8. The text does not distinguish between gifts made to the officeholder in their official or personal capacity. We must therefore conclude all such gifts are proscribed.

The defendant argues that his conduct did not constitute 'insider trading' because the information was not obtained through his own employment. The rule, however, prohibits trading 'on the basis of material, nonpublic information,' without specifying the source of the breach of duty. The plain text of Rule 10b5-1 is dispositive.

This Court finds that the non-compete agreement is enforceable as written. The agreement restricts employment with any 'competitor,' a term defined simply as any entity in the 'logistics industry.' Plaintiff’s argument that we should narrow this definition to 'direct competitors' asks us to rewrite the contract, a power this Court does not possess.

The appellant challenges the search of his vehicle's trunk, but the written consent form he signed authorized a search of the 'vehicle and its contents.' A trunk is unambiguously part of a vehicle, and its contents are its contents. The officer was not required to seek separate consent for each compartment. State v. Rodriguez, 987 So. 2d 115 (Fla. 2008).

Had Congress intended to cover 'emotional distress' damages under the Migratory Bird Treaty Act, it could have easily said so. Instead, the statute provides for fines and imprisonment, remedies that are penal, not compensatory. The statute’s text offers no hook for the plaintiff’s novel damages theory. Audubon Society v. Pipeline Corp., 23 F.4th 991 (10th Cir. 2022).

The term 'carry,' as used in the relevant weapons statute, must be given its ordinary public meaning at the time of the law's adoption. This meaning includes bearing or transporting a weapon, irrespective of whether it is concealed or openly visible. The legislature’s failure to add a qualifier like 'concealed' is a choice we must respect. Commonwealth v. Davis, 122 A.3d 1031 (Pa. 2015).

The plaintiff sues for breach of warranty, but the contract’s 'integration clause' states that the written agreement constitutes the 'entire agreement between the parties.' All prior oral representations, including the alleged warranty, are therefore extinguished by the plain language of the contract the plaintiff signed. Harris Mechanical v. Trinity Towers, LLC, 87 F. Supp. 3d 1121 (W.D. Tex. 2015).

The First Amendment's command that Congress shall make 'no law... abridging the freedom of speech' is a textual bulwark against content-based regulations. The ordinance here, which bans 'untruthful' political advertising, is a classic, and impermissible, regulation of speech content. We need not balance interests when the constitutional text is so absolute.

The Endangered Species Act protects against the 'take' of a listed species, defined as to 'harass, harm, pursue, hunt, shoot, wound, kill, trap, capture, or collect.' 16 U.S.C. § 1532(19). Habitat modification is not on that list. While habitat loss may 'harm' a species in a colloquial sense, we are bound by the statute's specific, action-oriented verbs. Babbitt v. Sweet Home, 515 U.S. 687 (1995) (Scalia, J., dissenting).

The defendant's motion to dismiss is granted. The statute of limitations requires that an action for fraud be brought within 'two years from the date of the fraudulent act.' The plaintiff’s argument for a 'discovery rule' is an appeal to policy, not text; the statute says 'from the date of the act,' not 'from the date of discovery.'

We must reverse the Board’s decision to deny the applicant a license. The governing statute requires denial only if the applicant has been convicted of a 'felony involving moral turpitude.' While the applicant’s felony tax evasion is serious, the text of the tax code does not define it as a crime of 'moral turpitude,' and we are not at liberty to expand the definition. Smith v. State Licensing Bd., 56 P.3d 255 (Ariz. Ct. App. 2002).

The interpretive journey begins and ends with the words of the trust instrument. The trust directs the trustee to distribute funds for the 'education' of the beneficiaries. A trip to Europe, while perhaps educational in a broad sense, does not fall within the ordinary meaning of 'education' as 'instruction at a school.' In re Estate of Thompson, 901 N.W.2d 74 (Iowa 2017).

The Clean Air Act authorizes the EPA to regulate pollutants that 'endanger public health.' 42 U.S.C. § 7521(a)(1). This is an explicit textual grant of authority. Whether such regulation is economically wise or politically popular is a question for Congress, not for this Court. Massachusetts v. EPA, 549 U.S. 497 (2007).

The plaintiff alleges that the defendant, his supervisor, created a hostile work environment. However, Title VII makes it unlawful for an 'employer' to discriminate, and the statute's definition of 'employer' does not include individual supervisors. Therefore, the plain language of the statute forecloses personal liability. Patterson v. County of Fairfax, 215 F.3d 1320 (4th Cir. 2000).

The Speedy Trial Act mandates that a trial 'shall commence within seventy days' from the filing of the indictment. 18 U.S.C. § 3161(c)(1). The text admits of no exception for prosecutorial oversight or docket congestion beyond the specific exclusions listed in the statute itself. The indictment must therefore be dismissed.

In this bankruptcy proceeding, the creditor's lien must be honored. The Code grants priority to a 'perfected security interest,' and the creditor’s filing meets the textual requirements for perfection under state law. The debtor’s plea for equitable subordination is unpersuasive, as the text provides no basis for such a remedy in this circumstance.

The defendant’s argument that a 'home' under the castle doctrine should include his vehicle is textually unsupported. The statute provides an affirmative defense for the use of force within one's 'dwelling.' A 'dwelling' is a fixed structure for habitation, which a motor vehicle is not. State v. Cabrera, 788 S.E.2d 44 (N.C. Ct. App. 2016).

The plaintiff seeks to invalidate the arbitration agreement by arguing it is 'unconscionable.' However, the Federal Arbitration Act requires courts to enforce arbitration agreements according to their terms. 9 U.S.C. § 2. State law defenses like unconscionability are preempted where they conflict with the FAA’s clear textual mandate.

The question before us is whether a 'text message' constitutes a 'call' under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act. Given that the statute was enacted in 1991, Congress could not have specifically intended to include text messages. The word 'call' in its ordinary sense refers to a voice communication, and we will not stretch its meaning to cover a new technology. Campbell-Ewald Co. v. Gomez, 577 U.S. 153 (2016).

The will of the decedent bequeaths his 'automobile' to his son. At the time of his death, the decedent owned a truck and a motorcycle. As the ordinary meaning of 'automobile' is a passenger car, and not a truck or motorcycle, the bequest fails for lack of a specific referent. In re Estate of Parker, 45 F. Supp. 3d 101 (D. Mass. 2014).

The Commerce Clause grants Congress the power to 'regulate Commerce... among the several States.' U.S. Const. art. I, § 8, cl. 3. The activity at issue here—the wholly intrastate cultivation of a crop for personal use—is not 'Commerce' in any textual sense. To hold otherwise would be to erase the word's meaning entirely. See United States v. Lopez, 514 U.S. 549 (1995).

The defendant was convicted under a statute criminalizing the 'sale' of a controlled substance. His conduct consisted of 'fronting' the drugs with an expectation of later payment. A 'sale' requires the concurrent exchange of goods for consideration, which did not happen here; the text compels a narrow reading. United States v. Jefferson, 888 F.3d 210 (5th Cir. 2018).

The plaintiff, injured by a medical device, brought suit after the statutory deadline, arguing the limitation period should be tolled. The statute plainly states that an action 'must be commenced within three years' of the injury. It does not say 'within three years of the discovery of the injury,' and it is not our role to add words to a legislative command.

The city’s flow-control ordinance requires all waste to be processed at a city-owned facility. This is a regulation of the 'articles of commerce,' which squarely implicates the dormant Commerce Clause. The text of the Constitution gives Congress, not cities, the power to regulate the channels of interstate commerce. C&A Carbone, Inc. v. Town of Clarkstown, 511 U.S. 383 (1994).

Under the terms of the limited liability company's operating agreement, a member may be expelled by a 'majority vote of the other members.' The defendant argues this vote must be for cause, but the text imposes no such condition. We are bound by the plain, unqualified language agreed to by the parties.

The government seeks forfeiture of the defendant's car, arguing it was 'used to facilitate' a drug crime. While the defendant did drive the car to the meeting, the actual transaction took place in a nearby park. The statute requires that the property 'facilitate' the crime, a term requiring a more substantial nexus than simply providing transportation to its general vicinity.

Article II of the Constitution vests 'the executive Power' in the President. This text creates a unitary executive, whose power includes the ability to remove subordinate officers. The statute creating an independent counsel, removable only for 'good cause,' is an unconstitutional intrusion on this clear textual grant of authority. Morrison v. Olson, 487 U.S. 654 (1988) (Scalia, J., dissenting).

The parole board denied the petitioner’s release, and he now seeks judicial review. However, the governing statute states that the board’s decisions 'are final and not subject to appeal or review.' The text is a clear and unambiguous bar to this Court’s jurisdiction. Greene v. S.C. Dep't of Prob. & Parole, 799 S.E.2d 477 (S.C. 2017).

The zoning ordinance permits 'retail establishments' in the designated zone. The appellee, a check-cashing service, does not sell goods, but rather provides a financial service. As 'retail' in its ordinary commercial sense involves the sale of goods to the public, the appellee's business does not conform to the ordinance’s text.

The defendant objects to the admission of his co-conspirator's statement, but Federal Rule of Evidence 801(d)(2)(E) is dispositive. The rule states that a statement made by a co-conspirator 'during and in furtherance of the conspiracy' is not hearsay. The text does not require, as defendant suggests, independent indicia of reliability. Bourjaily v. United States, 483 U.S. 171 (1987).

The trust instrument allows for invasion of the principal for a 'medical emergency.' The beneficiary’s request for funds to cover elective cosmetic surgery does not fall within the plain meaning of 'emergency.' This court cannot expand the definition to accommodate the beneficiary’s desires.

The plaintiff argues that the Americans with Disabilities Act requires the defendant to alter its website to be accessible to the visually impaired. The ADA, however, prohibits discrimination in the enjoyment of 'public accommodations,' and the statute’s text lists only physical places. A website is not a 'place' in any conventional sense. Domino's Pizza, LLC v. Robles, 140 S. Ct. 12 (2019) (statement of Thomas, J.).

We are asked to interpret a statute that enhances sentences for crimes committed with a 'deadly weapon.' The defendant used a heavy, but otherwise ordinary, glass ashtray. A 'weapon' is an instrument designed for fighting, and while any object *can* be used to cause death, the statute’s text points to the object’s design, not its ad hoc use. State v. Harmon, 201 N.W.2d 888 (Neb. 1972).

The plain text of the Takings Clause requires 'just compensation' when private property is 'taken for public use.' U.S. Const. amend. V. The transfer of property from one private owner to another for the purpose of economic development does not constitute 'public use' as that term was understood at the founding. Kelo v. City of New London, 545 U.S. 469 (2005) (Thomas, J., dissenting).

The defendant's conviction for 'burglary of a habitation' must be vacated. The structure he entered was a detached garage, used only for storage. The penal code defines 'habitation' as a 'structure adapted for the overnight accommodation of persons,' a textual definition the garage simply does not meet. Blankenship v. State, 780 S.W.2d 198 (Tex. Crim. App. 1988).

The appellant claims a right to a jury trial under the Seventh Amendment. However, the amendment preserves the right to a jury trial only in 'Suits at common law,' meaning suits of a type that existed in English courts in 1791. As the administrative proceeding at issue here has no common law analogue, the textual right to a jury does not attach.

The Court must deny the motion for a preliminary injunction. The relevant statute authorizes injunctive relief only upon a showing of 'irreparable harm,' and the plaintiff has only alleged monetary damages. Monetary damages are, by definition, reparable, and therefore do not satisfy the statute's explicit textual prerequisite. Sampson v. Murray, 415 U.S. 61 (1974).

The defendant challenges the admission of business records, but the records fall squarely within the exception of Federal Rule of Evidence 803(6). The rule requires that the record be 'kept in the course of a regularly conducted activity,' a textual requirement fully met here. The defendant's complaints about the declarant's motive go to weight, not admissibility, as the text provides no exception for bias.

The defendant insists on a rigid, literal reading of 'structure' in the Arson Prevention Act, but to do so would ignore the Act's clear purpose. The legislative history is replete with references to combating the 'scourge of urban blight,' which compels us to include derelict, uninhabitable buildings within the statute's ambit.

Whereas the plaintiff argues that 'communication' under the Wiretap Act is limited to auditory transmissions, Congress's stated goal was to protect citizens from intrusive surveillance in all its forms. To exclude modern text-based messaging would be to create an absurdity, allowing the very mischief the legislature sought to eradicate.

The term 'disability' in the Americans with Disabilities Act was intended by its drafters to be construed broadly to provide a 'clear and comprehensive national mandate for the elimination of discrimination.' Therefore, we find that plaintiff's chronic but managed condition falls within the protective scope of the statute, consistent with that remedial purpose. See Holloway v. Apex Corp., 345 F.3d 112 (2d Cir. 2011).

Appellant's interpretation of the National Environmental Policy Act would bog federal agencies in endless proceduralism, a result Congress clearly did not intend. As the Senate report noted, the goal was 'meaningful, not maximal, review,' guiding our conclusion that the agency's streamlined assessment was sufficient.

In enacting the Fair Housing Act, Congress sought to 'eradicate the vestiges of housing discrimination.' Interpreting the phrase 'otherwise make unavailable or deny' to exclude discriminatory advertising, as the defendant suggests, would directly frustrate this core legislative objective.

The plain text of the Securities Fraud Act of 1998 is ambiguous as to cryptocurrency. However, the committee hearings on the bill reveal an overarching intent to regulate 'any new or speculative investment vehicle that could pose a risk to the public,' which must guide this Court's analysis.

We are asked to interpret the term 'employee' under the Worker Protection Act of 2015. Given the statute's remedial nature, aimed at curbing the exploitation of gig-economy workers, a narrow, common-law definition would undermine its very foundation; thus, we adopt a broader standard reflecting the economic realities Congress addressed.

While the statute does not define 'imminent threat' in the context of self-defense, the legislative debates show a clear intent to move beyond the traditional 'fist against fist' scenario. The purpose was to empower individuals facing threats from technologically advanced weaponry, a purpose that would be nullified by the defendant's narrow construction.

This court must construe the 'family' provision of the city's zoning ordinance. The minutes from the 1978 City Council meeting show the ordinance was meant to preserve community character, not to enforce a specific household structure. Therefore, defining 'family' in a way that excludes the plaintiff's multi-generational household would be contrary to that stated purpose.

The Digital Millennium Copyright Act's safe harbor provision was enacted to foster the growth of a nascent internet. To hold the defendant, an online service provider, to the strict liability standard plaintiff proposes would chill innovation and contradict the balanced approach Congress manifestly intended. See Corman v. NetSphere, 501 F. Supp. 2d 876 (N.D. Cal. 2007).

Plaintiff's reading of the Clean Air Act, while textually plausible, would lead to the absurd result of regulating home fireplaces more stringently than industrial smokestacks. The Act’s preamble and history confirm its purpose was to target major polluters, and our interpretation must be consistent with that design.

The phrase 'critical habitat' in the Endangered Species Act must be interpreted in light of the statute's ultimate goal: species recovery. An interpretation that protects only current nesting grounds but not essential migratory pathways would render the statute a 'paper tiger,' a result Congress could not have countenanced.

In considering the scope of 'financial institution' under the Bank Secrecy Act, we look to the problems Congress sought to remedy, namely money laundering through an evolving financial system. We therefore hold that decentralized currency exchanges fall within the Act's purview to effectuate its anti-circumvention purpose.

The defendant's conduct, while not explicitly listed in the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986, falls squarely within the 'mischief' the law was designed to prevent. The legislative record shows a concern with unauthorized access that compromises data integrity, regardless of the technical means employed.

Heretofore, courts have struggled with the meaning of 'public accommodation' in the context of websites. Given that the ADA's purpose was to ensure equal access to the 'goods and services' of the American economy, it would be illogical to conclude this protection ends at a physical storefront. See Reyes v. Blick, 198 F.3d 45 (1st Cir. 1999).

The Sentencing Reform Act was passed to reduce unwarranted disparities in federal sentencing. To permit the wide variation in guideline application that the government now advocates for would directly subvert this primary legislative goal, and we decline to do so.

We must interpret the term 'vessel' in this maritime insurance dispute. While a floating casino may not be a 'vessel' in the traditional sense, the statute's purpose was to provide a uniform federal framework for 'all manner of commercial waterborne activities,' a category this casino plainly fits.

The Patient Privacy Act's exception for 'health care operations' must be read narrowly, lest it swallow the rule. The congressional aim was to protect sensitive patient data, and a broad reading would create a loophole that undermines the very confidence the Act was meant to inspire.

At issue is whether a sophisticated phishing email constitutes a 'counterfeit access device' under 18 U.S.C. § 1029. Congress enacted this statute to criminalize trafficking in and use of fraudulent devices that enable theft; a holding that exempts digital equivalents would fail to 'keep pace with the private sector's technological advances,' as the drafters intended.

The purpose of the Whistleblower Protection Act is to encourage reporting of waste, fraud, and abuse without fear of reprisal. To deny protection to the plaintiff because his disclosure was made internally first would disincentivize the very conduct the statute was designed to promote.

Considering the statute's preamble, which cites the need to 'protect children from emerging online threats,' we interpret 'commercial film' to include user-generated content on monetized streaming platforms. A contrary finding would render the statute obsolete in the face of modern media consumption.

The Bankruptcy Code's automatic stay is intended to give debtors a 'breathing spell' from their creditors. Defendant’s continued, automated emails, while not explicit collection attempts, are a form of psychological pressure that contravenes the spirit and purpose of the stay. See In re Sisyphus, 450 B.R. 218 (Bankr. D. Del. 2011).

The Equal Pay Act was a broad remedial statute designed to close the wage gap between sexes. Plaintiff's claim should not be dismissed merely because her chosen male comparator held a slightly different job title; the inquiry must focus on whether their roles were 'substantially equal' in a way that fulfills the Act's purpose.

In construing the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, we are mindful of the dual purposes stated in its legislative history: protecting national security and safeguarding civil liberties. The government's proposed interpretation would vitiate the latter purpose, and thus cannot be what Congress intended.

Defendant argues its algorithm is a 'trade secret' and thus shielded from discovery under the state's Uniform Trade Secrets Act. However, that Act was intended to prevent unfair competition, not to shield a key piece of evidence in a discrimination case from judicial scrutiny. Such a use would be a perversion of the statute's purpose.

The term 'personal effects' in the decedent’s will must be interpreted in light of his known purpose of providing for his immediate family's comfort. Therefore, we find the term encompasses the disputed vehicle, which was essential to the household's daily life, rather than just smaller items of personalty.

To read the 'continuous physical presence' requirement of the Immigration and Nationality Act as broken by a single, brief, and innocent departure would produce an unnecessarily harsh result. This interpretation would be inconsistent with the legislative goal of providing a path to relief for long-term residents. See Mendez v. DHS, 621 F.3d 1080 (9th Cir. 2010).

The National Voter Registration Act was passed to increase the number of registered voters. The state's complex and burdensome proof-of-citizenship requirement, while not explicitly forbidden, serves as a practical barrier to registration that is fundamentally at odds with the statute's pro-registration purpose.

This Court cannot accept that 'interstate commerce' under the Federal Arbitration Act was meant to have the same scope in 1925 as it does today. The Act was intended to make arbitration agreements as enforceable as other contracts, and it must be interpreted to achieve that purpose in the context of our modern, interconnected economy.

The plaintiff's injury arose from a gene-editing therapy, a technology unforeseeable when the relevant product liability statute was drafted. Notwithstanding this, the statute's purpose was to ensure compensation for individuals harmed by 'defective therapeutic products,' a category that must evolve with medicine itself.

In determining whether the defendant 'carried' a firearm under 18 U.S.C. § 924(c), we look to Congress's intent to deter the dangerous combination of drugs and guns. The fact that the gun was in the defendant's glove compartment, easily accessible during a drug transaction, brings his conduct within the zone of danger Congress sought to regulate.

The term 'dwelling' in this insurance policy is ambiguous, but the overarching purpose of the homeowner's policy is to protect the insured's primary residence. As such, the attached but separately-doored guest suite falls within the policy's coverage, as any other interpretation would defeat the reasonable expectations of the policyholder.

The Veterans' Benefits Act is a remedial statute intended to be construed liberally in favor of veterans. The Board's denial of benefits based on a hyper-technical reading of a procedural deadline ignores this guiding principle and frustrates the law's compensatory and appreciative purpose.

Reading the word 'copy' in the Copyright Act of 1976 to exclude temporary RAM reproductions would gut the statute's relevance in the digital age. Congress's purpose was to grant authors control over the reproduction of their work, a purpose that must encompass the way works are consumed today.

The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) was designed to promote finality in criminal convictions. The petitioner's endless string of successive habeas petitions, each with a minor variation, is precisely the sort of abuse the statute was enacted to curtail. See Alvarez v. DiCarlo, 201 F.3d 315 (5th Cir. 2000).

This case turns on the definition of 'waste' under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act. Given the statute's 'cradle-to-grave' regulatory goal, we cannot endorse the defendant's argument that its toxic byproduct ceases to be 'waste' simply because it is theoretically recyclable at some future date.

The Indian Child Welfare Act was passed to remedy the tragic history of Native American family separations. The state court's decision, which privileged the non-native foster parents' interests over tribal sovereignty, runs directly counter to ICWA’s primary and explicit purpose of preserving tribal integrity.

Plaintiff seeks damages under a statute allowing recovery for 'malicious prosecution.' While defendant's actions may not fit the classic definition, they represent a modern form of corporate 'lawfare' intended to harass a smaller competitor into submission—the very type of abusive litigation the statute was designed to deter.

The legislature, in passing the state's Shield Law, intended to protect journalists from being compelled to reveal their confidential sources. To limit this protection to employees of established media corporations, and not a blogger like plaintiff, would ignore the realities of modern journalism and undermine the law’s purpose of ensuring a free flow of information.

We are asked to define 'navigational aid' under an admiralty statute. The software at the heart of this dispute, while purely digital, serves the identical purpose as the lighthouses and buoys the statute originally contemplated: guiding ships safely to port. Therefore, it must fall within the statute's protective ambit.

The Stored Communications Act was enacted to create a form of 'digital Fourth Amendment' to protect user privacy. The government’s request for the entire contents of the plaintiff’s cloud storage account is a fishing expedition that contravenes the Act’s purpose of balancing legitimate law enforcement needs against individual privacy.

A plain reading of 'tangible object' in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act might not include a digital file. However, the legislative history makes clear that the provision was a direct response to the Enron scandal's document shredding, and its purpose was to criminalize the destruction of any evidence; to exclude digital evidence would be to miss the forest for the trees.

In this contract dispute, the term 'best efforts' is not defined. We are therefore guided by the stated purpose of the joint venture—to 'aggressively market and sell' the product—which imposes a higher duty on the defendant than the passive, wait-and-see approach they adopted.

The Americans with Disabilities Act's requirement of 'reasonable accommodation' was intended as a mandate for 'workplace integration.' The defendant's offer to move the plaintiff to a segregated, dead-end position, while technically an 'accommodation,' frustrates the spirit and purpose of the law.

The Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act was enacted to protect the health and safety of the public. The defendant's argument that its unproven supplement is a 'food' and not a 'drug' is a semantic distinction that would, if accepted, create a loophole that endangers consumers, a result we are confident Congress did not intend.

This court is not persuaded by the appellant's argument that the term 'school grounds' in the Gun-Free School Zones Act is limited to the property line. The legislative goal was to create a safe buffer around children; therefore, the term must be interpreted to include the adjacent public sidewalk where the offense occurred.

The purpose of Rule 23 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is to enable the efficient resolution of widespread, low-value claims. To decertify this class based on minor individual variations in damages would effectively deny any remedy to the plaintiffs, thereby subverting the very purpose of the class action mechanism.

In interpreting the National Labor Relations Act, we must remain cognizant of its foundational purpose: to encourage collective bargaining and equalize power between labor and management. The employer's unilateral implementation of a new arbitration policy strikes at the heart of this purpose and cannot be sanctioned.

The phrase 'violent felony' in the Armed Career Criminal Act is a term of art that must be understood through the lens of congressional intent. The legislative record indicates Congress was targeting career offenders who pose a physical danger to the community, a category that encompasses the defendant's prior conviction for burglary of a dwelling.

Heretofore, the term 'facility' in the public health code has been applied to buildings. Yet the code's stated purpose is to regulate 'any area where food is served to the public,' which logically includes the plaintiff's fleet of mobile food trucks, a modern business model the 1985 legislature could not have foreseen.

The holding in *United States v. Miller*, 425 U.S. 435 (1976), which held that individuals have no reasonable expectation of privacy in their bank records, is a relic of the analog era. In a world of ubiquitous digital transactions, its logic would grant the government unfettered access to the intimate details of modern life, a result we cannot countenance.

While *Hargrove v. Peterson*, 112 S.E.2d 44 (N.C. 1960) established the "firefighter's rule," we believe its continued application serves only to insulate property owners from the consequences of their own negligence. We therefore hold that the rule is no longer good law in this jurisdiction and that first responders may recover for injuries proximately caused by a defendant's lack of reasonable care.

The defendant's reliance on *State v. Collins*, 789 P.2d 1234 (Or. 1990), is misplaced, as that case did not contemplate the use of facial recognition technology derived from social media. This Court finds that the due process clause requires a pre-identification reliability hearing when such novel and potentially fallible technologies are the sole basis for an arrest warrant.

We are asked to apply the standard from *Jennings v. School District*, 450 F.2d 88 (6th Cir. 1971), to assess the plaintiff's claim of discriminatory school funding. However, that case's focus on mere resource parity is insufficient; true equal protection in education requires a holistic assessment of functional equity and student outcomes.

The traditional rule requiring consideration for contract modification, as established in precedents like *Stilk v. Myrick*, has been justly criticized as formalistic. Where, as here, a modification is made in good faith to address unforeseen commercial circumstances, the original contract's stated purpose is better served by enforcing the parties' revised agreement.

Though ancient common law held that a landowner's rights extended 'ad coelum,' such a principle is manifestly unworkable in the age of commercial aviation and satellite technology. We now clarify that a property owner's right to exclude extends only to that portion of the airspace which they can make reasonable use of in connection with their enjoyment of the land.

The dissent's rigid adherence to *Abrams v. City of Concord*, 213 F.Supp.2d 45 (D.N.H. 2002), ignores the evolving nature of public forums. A city-moderated social media page is not a mere publication; it is a modern-day town square, and viewpoint-based censorship upon it triggers strict scrutiny.

The definition of 'parent' under the statute was written when reproductive technology was in its infancy. To deny the plaintiff parental rights simply because she is not the biological or adoptive mother, despite her clear and consistent role as a de facto parent, would be to elevate form over the best interests of the child.

Appellant argues that its conduct is permitted under a plain reading of the 1982 Clean Water Act, and perhaps it is. But to read the statute so narrowly would be to ignore its overarching remedial purpose, and this Court will not interpret an environmental law in a way that blesses the very harm it was enacted to prevent.

While we typically afford an agency's interpretation of its own statute deference under *Chevron*, that deference is not absolute. Where an agency's interpretation, like the one before us, represents a radical departure from its long-standing practice and effectively rewrites the law, judicial intervention is not only proper but necessary.

The government's use of a thermal imager to scan the defendant's home without a warrant runs afoul of the Fourth Amendment. While *Kyllo v. United States* is instructive, we hold that any use of sense-enhancing technology to obtain information from within a home that could not otherwise have been obtained constitutes a search.

The defendant-manufacturer points to its compliance with all federal safety standards as a shield from liability. This Court, however, finds that compliance with minimum federal standards does not, as a matter of law, absolve a manufacturer from its duty to design a reasonably safe product, especially when feasible and safer alternatives were known and available.

The precedent of *San Antonio Independent School District v. Rodriguez*, 411 U.S. 1 (1973), does not control here, as the right to a basic level of internet access has become fundamental to participating in modern society. Therefore, the state's plan, which creates a 'digital desert' in poorer communities, must be reviewed under a more exacting standard than mere rational basis.

We find the arbitration clause, buried in boilerplate on the thirteenth page of a forty-page consumer adhesion contract, to be procedurally and substantively unconscionable. The fiction of mutual assent, long a cornerstone of contract law, must yield to the commercial reality that no ordinary consumer could or would knowingly bargain for such a one-sided term.

The common law rule barring spousal testimony, codified in *State v. Gibson*, 32 N.E. 2d 108 (Ohio 1941), is a product of an era that viewed a wife as the property of her husband. We hereby abrogate this outdated privilege; the search for truth in a criminal trial outweighs any archaic justifications for its continuance.

The plaintiff's failure to perfectly plead the elements of fraud is not fatal to his claim at this stage. Whereas the rule of *Twombly* and *Iqbal* has been interpreted to require a high degree of specificity, its purpose is to weed out frivolous claims, not to create insurmountable barriers to discovery for plausible ones like the case at bar.

Although the sentencing guidelines are advisory, the court in *United States v. Booker* could not have foreseen the 'trial penalty' that has become a systemic reality. A defendant's decision to exercise their Sixth Amendment right to a trial cannot, in and of itself, justify a sentence orders of magnitude greater than that offered in a pre-trial plea.

The city's zoning ordinance, which prohibits more than three unrelated individuals from occupying a single-family residence, is challenged on constitutional grounds. While *Village of Belle Terre v. Boraas* upheld a similar ordinance, we find that shifting societal norms regarding 'family' and the acute housing shortage render that precedent's reasoning less persuasive today.

Heretofore, this state has not recognized a duty on the part of social hosts who serve alcohol to adults who subsequently cause harm. We take this opportunity to reconsider that position, finding that the foreseeable risk of drunk driving in today's society is a sufficient basis to impose a duty of reasonable care on those who provide the intoxicants.

The state's voucher program, which allows public funds to be used at religious schools, is not saved by the formal neutrality lauded in *Zelman v. Simmons-Harris*. In practice, the program has the primary effect of advancing religion, a result the Establishment Clause was expressly designed to forbid.

While the business judgment rule typically protects corporate directors from liability, it does not shield them when they utterly fail to implement any reporting or information system. The 'director primacy' model envisioned by *In re Caremark*, 1996 WL 549894 (Del. Ch. 1996), must, in the 21st century, include a duty to maintain reasonable cybersecurity oversight.

The government’s continuous, 28-day GPS tracking of the defendant’s vehicle constituted a search under the Fourth Amendment. The mosaic theory, though not explicitly adopted in *United States v. Jones*, provides the most coherent framework for analyzing long-term surveillance in a digital age, and we adopt its reasoning today.

Although plenary power over immigration is vested in the political branches, that power is not absolute and must be exercised in conformity with the Constitution. We find that the indefinite detention of the petitioner, without any individualized finding that he poses a danger to the community, violates the core guarantees of the Due Process Clause.

The appellee's argument that its algorithm is a protected trade secret cannot be used as a shield to prevent discovery into its potentially discriminatory effects. The public's interest in rooting out algorithmic bias in housing decisions substantially outweighs the company's interest in commercial secrecy in this context.

The 'mailbox rule,' a jurisprudential fossil from the age of handwritten letters and horse-drawn carriages, is ill-suited for the era of instantaneous digital communication. Where an offer is made and accepted electronically, we hold that a contract is formed upon receipt of the electronic acceptance, not its dispatch.

The state’s strict photo ID law, defended under the precedent of *Crawford v. Marion County Election Board*, imposes a far more substantial burden on voters in this state due to the lack of accessible ID-issuing offices. A law that may be constitutional in the abstract can be unconstitutional in its specific application, and such is the case here.

We are asked to decide whether gig-economy drivers are employees or independent contractors. While prior tests focused on the degree of control, we believe a more modern 'economic realities' test is appropriate, focusing on whether the workers are, as a matter of economic reality, dependent upon the business to which they render service.

The defendant university argues it has met its obligations under the ADA by providing physically accessible buildings. This Court finds that in the digital age, accessibility must also mean providing students with disabilities full and equal access to all online learning platforms and digital course materials.

While *District of Columbia v. Heller* established an individual right to bear arms, it did not foreclose reasonable regulation. We hold that the state's ban on the sale of large-capacity magazines is a permissible limitation, as it is substantially related to the compelling government interest in preventing mass casualty events.

The traditional 'zone of danger' rule for negligent infliction of emotional distress is an arbitrary and unforgiving standard. We now hold that a plaintiff who contemporaneously perceives a serious injury to a close family member may recover, regardless of whether they were themselves at risk of physical harm.

The introduction of a laboratory report without the testimony of the analyst who prepared it violates the defendant's rights under the Confrontation Clause. The reasoning of *Melendez-Diaz v. Massachusetts* must be read to apply not only to traditional forensic reports but to the complex digital forensic analyses at issue in this case.

The defendant's open and notorious use of the disputed land for a community garden, while not conforming to traditional notions of 'possession' like fencing or building, is sufficient to satisfy the requirements for adverse possession. To hold otherwise would be to penalize uses of land that are communal and ecological rather than exclusively private and commercial.

We find that the reporter's privilege, while not absolute, extends to protecting confidential sources even in the face of a grand jury subpoena under these specific circumstances. The precedent of *Branzburg v. Hayes* is not so rigid as to preclude a balancing of interests, and here the public interest in the free flow of information outweighs the government's need for the reporter's testimony.

The concept of permanent alimony, as established in cases like *Martin v. Martin*, 45 So. 2d 290 (Fla. 1950), presupposes a social structure where one spouse permanently leaves the workforce. In an era where that is the exception, not the rule, we find that rehabilitative or short-term alimony is the more appropriate standard in most cases.

The *Daubert* standard requires this court to act as a gatekeeper against unreliable expert testimony. The expert's novel theory linking cellphone radiation to the plaintiff's condition, while not yet generally accepted, is based on sound scientific methodology and is sufficiently reliable to be presented to a jury.

The plaintiffs, an environmental advocacy group, have standing to sue on behalf of their members to protect the scenic vistas of the national park. The precedent in *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife* is distinguishable; the aesthetic and recreational injury alleged here is concrete and particularized, not abstract.

We hold that a sentence of life without the possibility of parole for a crime committed by a juvenile is cruel and unusual punishment under the state constitution, regardless of the crime. The reasoning of the Supreme Court in *Miller v. Alabama* regarding the transient immaturity of youth compels us to extend its logic and prohibit such sentences categorically.

The Communications Decency Act's Section 230, interpreted broadly in *Zeran v. AOL*, was not intended to immunize platforms that actively solicit, curate, and promote illegal content. Where a platform's own business model is predicated on fostering tortious activity, the statutory shield must give way.

The plaintiff's claim for public disclosure of private facts, concerning a decades-old conviction, is cognizable despite the information being technically a matter of public record. The passage of time and the plaintiff's rehabilitation have created a 'zone of privacy' around this information that society is now prepared to recognize as reasonable.

The FDA's refusal to regulate electronic cigarettes as drug-delivery devices is an abdication of its statutory duty. While *FDA v. Brown & Williamson* limited the agency's authority over tobacco, that case did not—and could not—have addressed novel nicotine products that fall squarely within the plain text of the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

We find, for the first time in this jurisdiction, a constitutionally protected property interest in a student's continued enrollment in public school. Therefore, a student facing long-term suspension is entitled to a formal hearing with the right to cross-examine witnesses, protections that exceed the minimum requirements of *Goss v. Lopez*.

The city's complete ban on off-site commercial billboards, upheld under the precedent of *Metromedia, Inc. v. City of San Diego*, is no longer tenable. We find that the test from *Central Hudson* must be applied with more rigor, and a total ban is not a sufficiently narrowly tailored means to achieve the city's aesthetic and traffic safety goals.

The statute's silence on the required mental state for possession of a controlled substance has led to unjust convictions. We now read into the statute a *mens rea* of 'knowing,' as to do otherwise would be to create a strict liability crime that risks ensnaring the innocent, a result contrary to the fundamental principles of our criminal law.

While no express easement was created, the plaintiff's long-standing use of the defendant's private road to access his landlocked parcel has created an easement by estoppel. Though *Hays v. Nielson*, 204 P.3d 907 (Wash. 2009), requires a substantial investment in reliance on the permission, we find the construction of the plaintiff's home itself to be a sufficient investment.

The plaintiff police officer's termination for his off-duty political speech is not justified by the department's asserted interest in public perception, contra the reasoning in *Karins v. City of Atlantic City*, 706 A.2d 706 (N.J. 1998). The First Amendment's protections for citizens do not simply vanish when one puts on a uniform, and a more direct nexus between the speech and job performance must be shown.

The defendant contends that the actions of a third-party criminal actor constitute a superseding cause that breaks the chain of causation. However, where the defendant's negligence in failing to provide adequate security created the very foreseeable risk of such criminal activity, the original tortfeasor remains liable for the resulting harm.

The state legislature's partisan gerrymandering of congressional districts, while traditionally considered a non-justiciable political question, presents a clear violation of the state constitution's 'free and equal' elections clause. We find that workable standards for identifying and remedying extreme partisan gerrymanders exist, and the judiciary has a duty to enforce the constitutional mandate.

Stare decisis is a principle of policy, not a mechanical formula of adherence to the latest decision. Where, as here, the rule of *Gable v. United Freight*, 344 F. Supp. 90 (S.D.N.Y. 1972), has created more confusion than clarity in commercial transactions, its continued application is untenable.

Every contract imposes upon each party a duty of good faith and fair dealing in its performance and enforcement. We hold that this duty was breached when the defendant-franchisor exercised its contractual discretion for a purpose beyond the range of risks that the plaintiff-franchisee assumed when it entered into the contract.

The city’s new regulation, which prohibits any new construction on the plaintiff's coastal property due to projections of sea-level rise, constitutes a regulatory taking requiring just compensation. While *Lucas v. South Carolina Coastal Council* required a complete deprivation of all economic value, the practical effect here is the same, rendering the property economically sterile for the foreseeable future.

Whether a different regulatory scheme would better serve the public interest is a question for the legislature, not the judiciary. Our precedent in *Sterling Commerce v. Board of Trade*, 987 F.2d 303 (7th Cir. 2011), commands that we uphold such economic regulations so long as they are supported by a rational basis.

This Court is not unsympathetic to the defendant's personal circumstances; however, Congress has prescribed a mandatory minimum sentence for this offense. My duty is to apply the law as enacted, leaving to the legislative branch the authority to reconsider the wisdom of that policy.

Plaintiffs ask us to forge a new exception to the established framework for commercial speech, but we decline to do so. Such a significant alteration of First Amendment doctrine is best left to the Supreme Court or a legislative re-evaluation of the underlying statute.

We may not substitute our own judgment for that of the Environmental Protection Agency, the body to which Congress has entrusted these complex scientific determinations. As we held in *Ackerly v. EPA*, 501 F.3d 112 (D.C. Cir. 2015), our review is limited to whether the agency's action was arbitrary and capricious.

Because we resolve this case on the straightforward interpretation of Section 7(a) of the Act, we need not address the appellant's broader constitutional arguments. It is a cardinal principle of this Court to avoid passing on a constitutional question if there is also present some other ground upon which the case may be disposed.

Plaintiff argues for the recognition of a new tort of 'educational malpractice,' but this state's appellate courts have consistently declined to do so, citing the institutional competence of school boards and legislatures. This Court is bound by the precedent of *Parrish v. Unified School Dist.*, 12 P.3d 814 (Kan. 2000), and therefore must grant defendant's motion to dismiss.

While the technology used in this search was nascent when *Gallagher v. State*, 899 N.E.2d 45 (Ill. 2008) was decided, its core holding regarding expectations of privacy in public thoroughfares remains controlling. We are a court of precedent, not of policy, and any departure from *Gallagher* must come from the Supreme Court of Illinois or the General Assembly.

The reach of the Commerce Clause is indeed broad, and while the activity regulated here may seem purely local, Congress has made explicit findings connecting it to a national market. Our deference to such legislative findings is substantial, and we see no reason to depart from that principle here.

The contract's terms may appear harsh in hindsight, but the legislature has established a clear framework for commercial agreements and this one does not run afoul of it. It is not the Court's role to renegotiate a contract between two sophisticated parties.

Plaintiff's substantive due process claim asks this Court to recognize a new fundamental right not enumerated in the Constitution. The Supreme Court has repeatedly cautioned lower courts against such judicial adventurism, and this Court must therefore decline the invitation.

The complexity of the tax code is a direct result of legislative choices, and it is not for us to simplify it by judicial fiat. We interpret the statute as written, and under that plain reading, the appellant's deduction was properly disallowed.

The statute could perhaps have been drafted with greater precision, but 'the Constitution does not require impossible standards,' *United States v. Petrov*, 755 F.3d 81 (2d Cir. 2014). We find that the law provides a person of ordinary intelligence a reasonable opportunity to know what is prohibited, and that is sufficient to survive a vagueness challenge.

In reviewing the Secretary's decision not to list the species, this Court's role is not to determine whether it would have made the same decision. Rather, the inquiry is limited to the administrative record and whether the decision was a rational one based on the data before the agency.

The appellant urges a dramatic expansion of Title VII liability, but our reading of the statute and controlling precedent does not support it. Amending the scope of employment discrimination law is a task for Congress, which is better equipped to weigh the competing policy considerations.

The legislature has defined 'marital property' in a manner that excludes the assets at issue here. While other states have adopted broader definitions, our duty is to apply the law of this commonwealth as promulgated by the General Assembly.

Petitioner's claim was fully and fairly adjudicated in state court, and under the deferential standard mandated by AEDPA, this Court cannot grant the writ. Federal habeas review is a 'guard against extreme malfunctions in the state criminal justice systems,' not a substitute for ordinary error correction on appeal.

To grant the relief requested would require this Court to intrude upon the core functions of the executive branch in a manner that our constitutional structure does not permit. We must presume that the executive is acting lawfully, absent a clear showing to the contrary, as established in *Shaw v. Crichton*, 104 F.3d 998 (D.C. Cir. 2017).

The challenged jury instruction is a verbatim recitation of the pattern instruction approved by our state's highest court in *State v. Mendoza*, 312 P.3d 55 (Ariz. 2013). This panel is not at liberty to disregard such clear and binding precedent.

Whether this parcel of land would be better zoned for commercial rather than residential use is a quintessential legislative judgment. The city council held hearings and made a determination, and this Court will not second-guess that decision absent a showing that it was wholly arbitrary and without any rational basis.

The law at issue is a neutral law of general applicability that only incidentally burdens the plaintiffs' religious practice. Under the controlling precedent of *Walton v. Dept. of Licensing*, 901 F.2d 1200 (10th Cir. 2010), we are compelled to find it constitutional; any new accommodation for religious objectors must be provided by the legislature.

For over a century, this Court has interpreted water rights in this state through the doctrine of prior appropriation, a rule reaffirmed in *Big Sky Ranch v. Miller*, 45 P.3d 89 (Wyo. 2002). The stability of property rights and the principle of stare decisis weigh heavily against the appellant's invitation to fundamentally alter this long-standing framework.

To find for the plaintiff would require us to eliminate the 'state-of-the-art' defense that the legislature has explicitly codified in the state's product liability act. Our function is to interpret the statute, not to effectively repeal it through judicial construction.

Certifying a class in this instance would require the Court to ignore the specific procedural hurdles enacted by Congress in the Class Action Fairness Act. The legislative history makes clear that these hurdles were intentional, and this Court is not empowered to create procedural shortcuts where Congress has built a detailed road.

The definition of 'particular social group' for asylum purposes has been the subject of much debate, but we are bound by this circuit's interpretation in *Juarez v. Barr*, 934 F.3d 501 (5th Cir. 2019). It is not the place of this panel to craft a new definition where precedent and agency guidance already exist.

Whatever the outer bounds of the Second Amendment may be, the specific regulation on firearm storage at issue here is not inconsistent with the historical tradition of firearm regulation. We therefore need not break new constitutional ground to resolve this case and uphold the ordinance.

The plaintiffs ask the Court to extend the statutory deadline for ballot submission, but the election code provides no authority for such a judicial modification. The power to set the time, place, and manner of elections is vested in the legislature, and the Court's authority is limited to interpreting the laws as they exist.

Appellants' theory of antitrust harm is novel and would require a significant expansion of established Sherman Act jurisprudence. We believe such a change, with its far-reaching economic consequences, is better addressed by Congress than by an intermediate appellate court.

This Court's role in a motion for judgment of acquittal is not to re-weigh the evidence or substitute its own judgment for that of the jury. The evidence, though circumstantial, is sufficient for a rational trier of fact to find the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable doubt when viewed in the light most favorable to the prosecution.

Even if a constitutional violation occurred, the right at issue was not 'clearly established' at the time of the incident, as required by an unbroken line of precedent from the Supreme Court and this circuit. The defendant officer is therefore entitled to qualified immunity.

The debtor's proposed interpretation of 'undue hardship' would dramatically lower the bar for discharging student loans, contrary to the intent expressed by Congress in the Bankruptcy Code. This Court must apply the stricter standard articulated by the Court of Appeals in *In re Penske*, 405 B.R. 119 (3d Cir. 2009).

The agency's affidavits provide a 'logical and plausible' basis for its national security claims under FOIA Exemption 1, which is all our precedent in *Larson v. Dept. of State*, 565 F.3d 857 (D.C. Cir. 2009), requires. This Court does not possess the institutional competence to second-guess the executive's national security determinations.

Plaintiff argues that his condition should be considered a 'disability' under the ADA, but it does not fall within the enumerated examples provided by the EEOC in its interpretive guidance. We owe substantial deference to the agency's reasonable interpretation of the statute it administers.

To void this contract on public policy grounds would require us to recognize a public policy not clearly expressed in our constitution or statutes. We are reluctant to use such a vague and powerful tool to rewrite the parties' obligations, a practice we cautioned against in *Mechanics' Bank v. Alden*, 211 N.E.2d 34 (Mass. 1965).

The plan administrator's decision to deny ERISA benefits is subject to review for an abuse of discretion. As long as the administrator's decision is based on a reasonable interpretation of the plan's terms and the evidence, we may not overturn it, even if we would have reached a different conclusion de novo.

While the delay in this case was significant, we must weigh it against the other factors laid out in *Barker v. Wingo*. Giving due deference to the trial court's factual findings on the reasons for the delay, we cannot say that the defendant's Sixth Amendment right was violated.

The zoning ordinance has undeniably diminished the value of plaintiff's property, but a mere diminution in value does not constitute a taking. Precedent dictates that only regulations that deny a landowner all economically beneficial use of their land trigger the Takings Clause, and that is not the case here.

Appellant asks us to abandon the long-standing 'last clear chance' doctrine in admiralty cases, but this rule has been a fixture of maritime law for a century. The interest in uniformity and predictability in this area counsels strongly against such a judicial upheaval; stare decisis is particularly potent in the context of commercial law.

The school district's disciplinary code is challenged as being overly broad, but federal courts are ill-equipped to micromanage the day-to-day operations of local schools. We must grant school administrators a significant degree of deference in establishing rules designed to maintain order and a proper educational environment.

This Court's review of the ALJ's decision to deny Social Security benefits is limited to determining whether it is supported by substantial evidence. It is not the Court's function to re-weigh the medical evidence or credibility determinations, but only to ensure the ALJ built a 'logical bridge' from the evidence to the conclusion.

The 'actual malice' standard for public figures is a high bar, established to protect robust public debate. Although the defendant's reporting was aggressive and perhaps even slanted, the plaintiff has not produced the clear and convincing evidence of knowing falsity or reckless disregard required by precedent.

Plaintiff alleges the defendant's advertising was misleading under the state's Consumer Fraud Act, but the legislature has carved out a specific 'safe harbor' for industries regulated by a federal agency. Since the defendant's conduct falls within that safe harbor, the claim must be dismissed, regardless of this Court's view on the wisdom of the exemption.

The question of whether the executive's deployment of forces constitutes an 'act of war' requiring congressional authorization is a political question not fit for judicial resolution. The text and history of the Constitution commit such determinations to the political branches of government.

We arrive at our holding by applying traditional canons of statutory construction, specifically that the specific governs the general. Even if this produces a result that seems contrary to a broadly stated statutory purpose, we are bound by the specific, operative text that Congress enacted.

Even assuming the warrant was technically deficient, the evidence is not subject to suppression. The officer relied in good faith on a warrant issued by a neutral magistrate, and the exclusionary rule's purpose of deterring police misconduct would not be served by suppressing the evidence in this case.

The challenged statute, which distinguishes between two classes of retirees, does not implicate a suspect class or fundamental right, and therefore is subject only to rational basis review. Under this highly deferential standard, the law must be upheld if there is any reasonably conceivable state of facts that could provide a rational basis for the classification.

The plaintiffs contend that a fiduciary duty should be implied under Section 10(b), but the Supreme Court has consistently instructed us not to expand the scope of private rights of action under the securities laws. We see no language in the statute that would justify the creation of the duty plaintiffs now propose.

The plaintiff's partisan gerrymandering claim, while articulating a real and serious harm to our democracy, presents a political question beyond the reach of this Court. We have no judicially discernible and manageable standards for adjudicating such claims, which are therefore committed to the political process.

While the proportionality of the forfeiture of defendant's vehicle for a minor drug offense is questionable, the legislature has authorized such forfeitures and the appellate courts of this state have upheld the statutory scheme. This Court is therefore constrained to grant the government's motion, as precedent in *State v. One 2011 Sedan*, 789 S.E.2d 41 (N.C. Ct. App. 2016) does not permit an independent proportionality analysis.

Interpreting the treaty's text according to its original public meaning as we must, we cannot find the specific water rights the Tribe now asserts. While modern policy concerns might favor a different result, we are constrained by the terms agreed to by the sovereign parties centuries ago.

The plaintiff's request for a preliminary injunction asks this Court to opine on the ultimate success of their constitutional claim. Given the deference owed to a legislative act, and the high bar for enjoining a duly enacted statute, we find that the plaintiff has not shown the requisite likelihood of success on the merits.

The doctrine of promissory estoppel requires a clear and unambiguous promise, a reasonable reliance thereon, and an injury resulting from that reliance, as set forth in Cohen v. Clark, 45 F.3d 112 (2d Cir. 1995). Plaintiff has demonstrated reliance and injury, but the defendant's statement of 'likely future partnership' is not a clear promise. Thus, the second element is not met, and the claim must fail.

Pursuant to the plain language of the statute, possession of the controlled substance with intent to distribute is the gravamen of the offense. The defendant was found in possession of a quantity far exceeding that for personal use. Therefore, the requisite intent can be logically inferred from the quantity itself, consistent with our holding in State v. Michaels, 890 A.2d 45 (N.J. 2006).

The business judgment rule shields corporate directors from liability for decisions made in good faith and with due care, as established in Aronson v. Lewis, 473 A.2d 805 (Del. 1984). Since the plaintiff has failed to proffer any evidence of fraud or self-dealing, this Court cannot substitute its own judgment for that of the board. Accordingly, the defendant directors' motion for summary judgment is granted.

For a communication to be protected by the attorney-client privilege, it must be made for the purpose of obtaining legal advice. The emails in question pertain to business strategy, not legal counsel, a distinction clarified in Upjohn Co. v. United States, 449 U.S. 383 (1981). It follows that the communications are not privileged and must be produced.

The Fourth Amendment requires probable cause for the issuance of a search warrant. The affidavit here rested on a tip from an anonymous informant, whose reliability was not independently corroborated. As this court held in People v. Rodriguez, 78 P.3d 1150 (Cal. 2003), an uncorroborated anonymous tip cannot, by itself, constitute probable cause; hence, the evidence seized must be suppressed.

A contract is voidable for mutual mistake only if the mistake concerns a basic assumption on which the contract was made. In this case, both parties mistakenly believed the property was zoned for commercial use, a fact central to the agreement. Therefore, under the precedent of Renner v. Kehl, 722 P.2d 262 (Ariz. 1986), the plaintiff is entitled to rescission.

To prevail on a claim of tortious interference, the plaintiff must prove, inter alia, the existence of a valid contractual relationship. The evidence shows only preliminary negotiations, not a finalized agreement. Without an existing contract to interfere with, the cause of action is legally impossible.

The standard for granting a preliminary injunction involves a four-part test, including the likelihood of success on the merits. Given that the plaintiff's statutory interpretation runs directly contrary to the plain text of the enabling act, his likelihood of success is minimal. This failure on the first prong is dispositive, and the injunction is therefore denied.

In State v. Greene, 129 So. 3d 1040 (Fla. 2013), we affirmed that a defendant must be the unequivocal aggressor to forfeit the right to a self-defense instruction.
