While the respondent's past actions are troubling, we must consider the profound and potentially permanent emotional harm to the child that would result from a complete and immediate termination of contact. See In re T.S., 892 N.E.2d 168 (Ohio 2008).

The petitioner's testimony described a level of fear and persecution that is, thankfully, unimaginable to most citizens of this nation. While the Board found his account lacked certain corroborating evidence, the terror in his voice was palpable and deserves more weight than the sterile application of evidentiary standards might suggest. See Garcia-Ramos v. Att'y Gen., 789 F.3d 601 (3d Cir. 2015).

The debtors stand before this court not as failed entrepreneurs, but as a family whose American dream was shattered by a medical crisis. While the bankruptcy code is dispassionate, its application need not be devoid of humanity; we are dealing here with the reorganization of lives, not just ledgers.

We are asked to determine whether the search was 'reasonable,' a term that feels hollow when applied to the intrusion experienced by the defendant in her own home. The sanctity of the home is not a mere legal fiction, but a deeply felt human need for security and privacy. Cf. Kyllo v. United States, 533 U.S. 27 (2001).

Plaintiff was not merely a name on a payroll; he was a dedicated employee for two decades, and the summary nature of his dismissal has inflicted a palpable wound on his dignity and financial stability. Although the at-will doctrine grants employers wide latitude, it does not license callous disregard for the human consequences of their decisions. See Velez v. Interstate Chemical, 554 P.3d 899 (Cal. Ct. App. 2017).

The plaintiffs, residents of a community forever altered by the defendant's actions, seek not just monetary damages but a restoration of their peace of mind. The Court acknowledges that no financial award can truly compensate for the loss of one's ancestral lands or the fear of what toxins may lie dormant in the soil.

Defendant argues for specific performance, but the court must consider the changed circumstances that have rendered the original agreement a crushing burden on the plaintiff. Equity does not demand a pound of flesh, and the Court will not compel a performance that would lead to the plaintiff's financial ruin over a mere commercial dispute. See Patel v. Singh Holdings, 2019 WL 123456 (Del. Ch. 2019).

The Administrative Law Judge's focus on what the claimant *can* do overlooks the mountain of evidence detailing the chronic pain that dictates what she *cannot*. The record paints a grim picture of a life circumscribed by physical limitation, a picture the ALJ improperly disregarded.

Appellant argues ineffective assistance of counsel, and while the trial record is not flagrant, it reveals a defense that was perfunctory at best. For a man whose liberty was at stake, the representation he received feels like a hollow formality rather than the zealous advocacy the Constitution guarantees. See Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).

The law of unlawful detainer is swift and often harsh, and its application here will render a family with young children homeless. While the landlord has a legal right to possession, this Court exercises its limited discretion to grant a stay of execution to allow the defendants a brief, humane period to find alternative housing.

Defendant's argument, that the plaintiff misused the product, rings hollow when one considers the catastrophic failure of the safety mechanism. To place the blame on the consumer, who trusted the product to be safe, is to ignore the profound power imbalance between a multinational corporation and the individuals who use its goods. See Greenman v. Yuba Power Products, Inc., 377 P.2d 897 (Cal. 1963).

For ten years, the petitioner has maintained his innocence from a prison cell, a claim heretofore dismissed as procedural boilerplate. This new evidence, however, lends a tragic credence to his pleas, forcing this Court to confront the chilling possibility that an innocent man's life has been unjustly stolen.

While the law prioritizes the rights of a fit parent, it need not be blind to the unique and cherished bond between a grandparent and a grandchild. To deny the petitioner all contact is to inflict a wound not only on the grieving grandmother but on the child who has already suffered an immense loss.

To grant qualified immunity here would send a message that the Constitution's promises are conditional, its protections fading in the very moments they are needed most. The plaintiff, lying helpless on the pavement, was entitled to more than the treatment he received. See Hope v. Pelzer, 536 U.S. 730 (2002).

The Court is sentencing a child, not a hardened criminal, and the law requires us to recognize the 'transient rashness of youth.' To impose a sentence of life without parole would be to declare this young man irredeemable, a declaration this Court is unwilling to make. See Miller v. Alabama, 567 U.S. 460 (2012).

The defendant doctor asks this court to view this case as a simple matter of a known risk materializing. But for the plaintiff's family, it is the story of a routine procedure that ended in an empty chair at the dinner table.

The bank's paperwork is in order, and its right to foreclose is contractually sound. Yet, the Court cannot sign the final order without acknowledging the human tragedy it represents: an elderly couple losing the home they have lived in for fifty years. A 60-day stay is granted on equitable grounds.

This court is not so detached from reality as to ignore the chilling effect the appellee's proposed discovery would have. To force a fledgling political group to disclose its member lists is to invite harassment and intimidation, silencing voices before they have a chance to be heard. See NAACP v. Alabama, 357 U.S. 449 (1958).

Whereas the statute imposes a cap on non-economic damages, the Court cannot be blind to the fact that for this plaintiff, a lifetime of immobility is the reality this cold calculus addresses. Such a legislative determination, however harsh its application here, binds this Court's hand. See Franklin v. State Gen. Hosp., 987 S.W.2d 44 (Tex. App. 2001).

The defendant's 'choice' to confess after 30 hours of interrogation can hardly be called voluntary in any meaningful sense of the word. We must remember that constitutional protections are not for the strong and rested, but for the weak, the tired, and the vulnerable. The confession must be suppressed.

The termination of Ms. Albright's parental rights was premised on a finding of 'failure to thrive,' a sterile term for the heartbreaking reality of poverty. The record shows a mother who loved her child but lacked the resources, not the will, to provide for him. We remand for a consideration of whether reunification services were truly adequate.

This insurance dispute is, at its heart, about a promise broken at the worst possible time. The plaintiff, having faithfully paid his premiums for years, was denied coverage in his hour of greatest need, and the defendant's interpretation of the policy's ambiguous language seems calculated to achieve this cruel result.

In reviewing the denial of Social Security benefits, this Court has read the entirety of the plaintiff's medical file. It is a document that chronicles not a single event, but a slow, painful descent into debilitating illness. The ALJ's cherry-picking of a single doctor's optimistic note from two years ago is a disservice to the painful reality of the record.

While precedent requires us to affirm the conviction, we write separately to express our deep unease with the mandatory minimum sentence in this case. The law, in its majestic equality, will now compel a 20-year sentence for a young man whose role was minor and whose life has been defined by disadvantage. See Harmon v. United States, 812 F.2d 75 (2d Cir. 1987) (Oakes, J., concurring).

The appellee urges a reading of the Fair Housing Act that would permit the eviction, but this interpretation would create a loophole large enough to drive a moving van through. It would leave countless families, like the appellants, in a state of perpetual housing insecurity, a result Congress could not have intended. See Jackson v. Parkside Apts., 345 F. Supp. 3d 890 (E.D. Pa. 2018).

The plaintiff's emotional distress claim is not an abstraction; the Court has observed his demeanor and heard his testimony. The defendant's conduct did not merely breach a contract; it shattered a man's professional reputation and sense of self-worth, a harm for which the jury's award is not unreasonable.

The government's argument for deportation rests on a 15-year-old misdemeanor, an offense for which the petitioner has long since paid his debt to society. To uproot him now from the community he has built and the family he supports would be a punishment so disproportionate as to be unconscionable.

The defendant corporation speaks of its fiduciary duty to shareholders, but it also has a duty to the community it nearly poisoned. The proposed settlement amount seems to treat this environmental disaster as a mere cost of doing business, rather than the life-altering event it was for the residents of Pine Creek.

The procedural default rule is a cornerstone of judicial efficiency, but it is not a trap for the unwary or the poorly represented. To deny this petition on a technicality, in the face of credible new evidence of innocence, would be to elevate form over the very substance of justice.

The Court recognizes the defendant's frustration, as he tried for months to navigate the labyrinthine bureaucracy of the benefits office. While his outburst was inappropriate, it was not born of malice, but of the desperation that comes from feeling unheard and unseen by the very system meant to help.

This Court must decide the 'best interests of the child,' a standard that is as profound as it is amorphous. Here, it means choosing between two loving homes, a decision that will inevitably cause pain. The Court's order, therefore, is crafted not to pick a 'winner,' but to minimize the trauma of this transition for the child herself.

The city's 'anti-camping' ordinance, while neutral on its face, has the practical effect of criminalizing the very state of being homeless. To make it illegal for a person to sleep, when they have no place to go, is a cruel paradox that this Court cannot endorse without significant constitutional scrutiny. See Martin v. City of Boise, 920 F.3d 584 (9th Cir. 2019).

This is not a case about a simple workplace romance; it is about a power dynamic that left the plaintiff feeling she had no choice but to acquiesce. The defendant's position of authority imbued his every request with a coercive weight that cannot be ignored. The motion for summary judgment is denied.

While the defendant's prior convictions are numerous, they are also a testament to a life spent battling addiction and mental illness. In sentencing him today, this court must distinguish between the man he was and the man he is trying to become. A sentence that includes robust, mandatory treatment is the only just outcome.

The doctrine of laches requires a showing of undue delay, but what delay can be 'undue' for a victim of childhood abuse who needed decades to be able to speak of the trauma? To bar her claim now would be to punish her for the very psychological wounds the defendant's actions inflicted.

The contract's force majeure clause did not anticipate a global pandemic, and to enforce the agreement's terms without regard to this world-altering event would be manifestly unjust. The plaintiff's small business is not a casualty of its own making, but of a historic crisis that has laid waste to countless livelihoods.

We are reviewing a 'Terry' stop that lasted for over an hour, during which the defendant, a young Black man, was handcuffed and interrogated on a public street for a minor traffic infraction. The indignity of such an experience, and the fear it engenders, is a harm in itself that must be weighed in the Fourth Amendment balance. Terry v. Ohio, 392 U.S. 1 (1968).

The parole board's decision cites the 'gravity of the original offense,' but it gives short shrift to the 30 years of rehabilitation the petitioner has since undergone. A man's life is not defined solely by his worst act, and the law must allow for the possibility of redemption, however belated.

The plaintiff seeks to recover for the loss of a pet, which the law coldly categorizes as chattel. But to anyone who has experienced the unconditional love of a companion animal, this legal fiction is transparently false. While this Court is bound by precedent, we note that the jury's verdict, though high for 'property,' reflects a more modern and humane understanding of the plaintiff's loss.

In this trademark dispute, the defendant is a small artisan, and the plaintiff is a multinational corporation. While both are equal before the law, the Court is mindful that a sweeping injunction would not just protect a brand, but could utterly destroy a woman's livelihood and life's work.

The Court has reviewed the video from the officer's body camera. It is one thing to read the sterile prose of a police report; it is another to witness the sheer panic of a citizen confronted with a questionable show of force in his own driveway.

While the Appellant's brief is poorly drafted and her arguments are legally unsophisticated, it is clear that she is a mother fighting desperately for her child. This court will therefore construe her pro se filings liberally, in the interest of reaching the profound human questions at the heart of this case. See Erickson v. Pardus, 551 U.S. 89 (2007).

The defendant's business failed, leaving a trail of debt. But the record suggests not fraud, but a series of good-faith efforts to stay afloat in a declining industry, a story all too common in this region. This context is essential in determining intent.

The 'eggshell plaintiff' doctrine is not a mere academic curiosity; it means we take our victims as we find them. The defendant's negligence may have caused only minor physical injury, but for this particular plaintiff, it triggered a cascade of pre-existing psychological trauma for which the defendant is now justly responsible.

The petitioner has been in solitary confinement for six years, a form of isolation that medical science has shown to be profoundly and permanently damaging to the human psyche. To continue this confinement indefinitely, without meaningful review, tests the very limits of the Eighth Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment.

The will contest before us pits sibling against sibling, a common tragedy in our courts. The legal questions are narrow, but they are layered with a lifetime of family history and grief. It is the Court's hope that, whatever the outcome, the parties can find a way to honor their shared parentage outside of this adversarial process.

To deny this veteran's claim for disability benefits based on a missed deadline is to ignore the very condition for which he seeks help. The effects of PTSD are not scheduled by the clock or the calendar, and the government's rigid adherence to procedure in this case is both ironic and cruel.

The defendant's conduct was, in a word, predatory, targeting the most financially vulnerable members of our community with promises he knew were false. The measure of damages, therefore, must not only compensate the victims but also reflect the deep societal harm that comes from exploiting the trust of the desperate.

The Court acknowledges the plaintiff's account of his injury on the assembly line; however, the claim is foreclosed by the two-year statute of repose. As established in *Mendez v. Apex Industrial*, 45 F.3d 1121 (7th Cir. 1995), a statute of repose is an absolute bar, not subject to equitable tolling. Therefore, Defendant's motion for summary judgment must be granted.

Defendant was sentenced within the statutory range prescribed by Congress for the offense. This court's review is limited to procedural reasonableness, and finding no procedural error, we must affirm. The substantive reasonableness of a within-Guidelines sentence is presumed, per *Gall v. United States*, 552 U.S. 38 (2007).

Petitioner's application for asylum hinges on establishing a credible fear of persecution. While his testimony was presented, it lacks the requisite corroborating evidence mandated by 8 U.S.C. § 1158(b)(1)(B). Consequently, the evidentiary standard set forth in *Chen v. Garland*, 899 F.3d 101 (2d Cir. 2018), has not been met.

Plaintiff alleges discriminatory termination, but failed to file a charge with the EEOC within the 180-day statutory window. This failure to exhaust administrative remedies is a jurisdictional bar to the Court's consideration of the merits. Accordingly, this action is dismissed for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

The search of the defendant's vehicle yielded the contraband in question. Although the warrant application was later found to be deficient, the officers relied upon it in good faith. Under the doctrine articulated in *United States v. Leon*, 468 U.S. 897 (1984), the evidence is not subject to the exclusionary rule.

At issue is the interpretation of Section 4.1(b) of the commercial lease agreement. Plaintiff argues for a reading based on industry custom, but the plain language of the contract is unambiguous. This Court is bound to enforce the contract as written, without resort to extrinsic evidence, as per *Wallace v. Tri-State Properties*, 743 F. Supp. 2d 504 (D. Del. 2010).

Appellant's habeas corpus petition is procedurally defaulted because the claim was not first raised in state court. The procedural requirements of 28 U.S.C. § 2254 are not mere formalities. See *Coleman v. Thompson*, 501 U.S. 722 (1991); the petition is denied.

The Social Security Administration denied claimant's application for disability benefits. The Administrative Law Judge's determination that the claimant retains the residual functional capacity for light sedentary work is supported by substantial evidence in the record. This Court's role is not to re-weigh the evidence but to ensure the correct legal standard was applied.

Plaintiff's § 1983 claim against the officers must overcome the hurdle of qualified immunity. The right allegedly violated was not 'clearly established' at the time of the incident, as no precedent from this circuit or the Supreme Court presented a factually analogous scenario. See *Pearson v. Callahan*, 555 U.S. 223 (2009); the defendants are therefore immune from suit.

In this medical malpractice action, Plaintiff failed to designate a qualified expert witness before the court-ordered deadline. Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 26(a)(2), this failure precludes the use of expert testimony essential to establishing a breach of the standard of care. Summary judgment for the defendant is therefore appropriate.

The ordinance restricting protests within 500 feet of the facility is a content-neutral time, place, and manner restriction. It serves a significant government interest and leaves open ample alternative channels for communication. The regulation therefore survives intermediate scrutiny under the framework of *Ward v. Rock Against Racism*, 491 U.S. 781 (1989).

This Court reviews the district court's factual findings regarding child custody for clear error. The lower court's determination that relocation was in the child's best interest was based on a multi-factor analysis, with significant weight placed on the superior economic and educational opportunities in the new jurisdiction. We find no basis to disturb this judgment.

Plaintiff seeks to enjoin the development project on environmental grounds, but lacks standing to bring the suit. The alleged harm—a generalized grievance about aesthetic degradation to a public forest—is not a concrete and particularized injury as required by *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife*, 504 U.S. 555 (1992). The case is dismissed.

The note and mortgage were properly assigned to the foreclosing entity, as evidenced by the documents attached to the complaint. Defendant homeowner's affirmative defenses are conclusory and unsupported by admissible evidence. There being no genuine issue of material fact, Plaintiff's motion for final judgment of foreclosure is granted.

Upon de novo review, we consider the district court's grant of a motion to dismiss. Plaintiff's complaint, while detailing a financial loss, fails to plead the element of scienter with the particularity required by the PSLRA. The factual allegations do not support a 'strong inference' of fraudulent intent, as mandated by *Tellabs, Inc. v. Makor Issues & Rights, Ltd.*, 551 U.S. 308 (2007).

The admissibility of the crime scene photographs is challenged under Rule 403. While the images are graphic, they are probative of the manner of death and the defendant's intent. The Court finds that their probative value is not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.

Defendant's motion to compel arbitration is granted based upon the arbitration clause in the click-wrap agreement. The on-screen presentation of terms and the requirement to click 'I Agree' constituted sufficient notice and manifestation of assent. Such agreements are routinely enforced, per *Feldman v. Google, Inc.*, 513 F. Supp. 2d 229 (E.D. Pa. 2007).

The issue is whether the debt for the student loan is dischargeable in bankruptcy under the 'undue hardship' test. The debtor has not demonstrated a 'certainty of hopelessness' regarding his financial future. Accordingly, the debt is non-dischargeable pursuant to 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(8).

We are asked to review the decertification of the plaintiff class. The district court found that individual questions of causation and damages predominate over common questions of law or fact. This determination falls within the trial court's broad discretion under Rule 23, and we perceive no abuse of that discretion.

The insurance policy contains an exclusion for 'losses arising from earth movement.' The damage to Plaintiff's property was the direct result of a landslide, which falls squarely within this unambiguous policy language. Therefore, the insurer has no duty to cover the loss.

This cause comes before the Court on Defendant's motion to dismiss for insufficient service of process. Plaintiff attempted service by mail, which is not a permitted method under state law or Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 4(e) without a signed waiver. The complaint is therefore dismissed without prejudice.

The Court must construe the disputed claim term 'substantially spherical processing unit' in the context of the patent's specification. The specification describes the unit with precise geometric constraints. The doctrine of claim differentiation cannot broaden the claim to encompass the defendant's non-spherical accused device.

Appellant contends his counsel was ineffective for failing to call an alibi witness. To prevail, he must satisfy the two-prong test from *Strickland v. Washington*, 466 U.S. 668 (1984). The decision not to call the witness can be construed as a strategic choice, and therefore does not fall below the objective standard of reasonableness.

The contract's force majeure clause excuses performance for events 'beyond the reasonable control of the parties.' A downturn in the market, even if severe, is a foreseeable business risk. It does not constitute a force majeure event as contemplated by the contract's plain text.

Plaintiff was terminated after failing a mandatory drug test. As the employment was at-will, the employer was not required to provide a reason for the termination, provided it was not an unlawful one. The record is devoid of evidence that the stated reason was pretext for discrimination.

This is an appeal from a summary judgment order in a tort case. Plaintiff's own deposition testimony indicates he was not looking where he was walking when he fell. Under the state's modified comparative fault doctrine, his negligence exceeds fifty percent as a matter of law, barring any recovery.

The landlord initiated eviction proceedings after the tenant was three days late with a rent payment, a technical breach of the lease. The lease contains a strict 'time is of the essence' clause. The Court has no equitable authority to override the unambiguous terms of the parties' negotiated agreement.

The government seeks forfeiture of the defendant's property, alleging it was used to facilitate a drug offense. The defendant's 'innocent owner' defense fails because she has not proven by a preponderance of the evidence that she took all reasonable steps to prevent the illicit use of her property. See 18 U.S.C. § 983(d).

Plaintiff seeks a preliminary injunction. To obtain this extraordinary remedy, the movant must show a likelihood of success on the merits. Based on the current record and the analysis in *Winter v. NRDC, Inc.*, 555 U.S. 7 (2008), this primary factor has not been met.

The question is whether the defendant's prior conviction qualifies as a 'violent felony' under the Armed Career Criminal Act. Applying the categorical approach required by *Taylor v. United States*, 495 U.S. 575 (1990), the elements of the prior offense meet the statutory definition. The sentencing enhancement was therefore correctly applied.

Reviewing the agency's decision under the Administrative Procedure Act, the standard is whether the action was 'arbitrary and capricious.' The agency provided a reasoned explanation for its rule change, supported by the administrative record. It is not this Court's function to substitute its judgment for that of the agency.

Plaintiff, proceeding pro se, has filed a complaint that fails to state a claim upon which relief can be granted. The pleading does not contain sufficient factual matter, accepted as true, to 'state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face,' as required by *Ashcroft v. Iqbal*, 556 U.S. 662 (2009). The case is dismissed.

The non-compete agreement restricts the defendant from working in the same industry within a 100-mile radius for two years. Under the precedent of *HRX, Inc. v. RCR Services*, 912 F.2d 12 (1st Cir. 1990), these terms are commercially reasonable to protect the plaintiff's legitimate business interests. The injunction is therefore issued.

Defendant moves to suppress his confession, alleging it was involuntary. The record shows Defendant received Miranda warnings and signed a waiver form prior to the interrogation, which lasted approximately 45 minutes. The totality of the circumstances does not suggest the waiver was coerced or that his will was overborne.

The trial court's calculation of damages is reviewed for clear error. While the award to the plaintiff was substantial, it was based on a methodical application of a life care plan and economic projections presented by a qualified expert. The figure is supported by the evidence adduced at trial.

Plaintiff objects to the magistrate judge's Report and Recommendation on the grounds that it misconstrued the facts. Upon de novo review of the specified portions of the report, this Court finds no error in the magistrate's analysis. The Report and Recommendation is therefore adopted in its entirety.

The zoning board denied the petitioner's request for a variance. A court may only overturn such a decision if it is illegal, arbitrary, or an abuse of discretion. As the board's decision was rationally related to the town's comprehensive plan, it must be upheld.

This matter concerns a discovery dispute where Plaintiff has refused to produce certain electronically stored information (ESI). The requested ESI is directly relevant to the claims and defenses in this case, and the asserted burden of production is not undue. Therefore, Defendant's motion to compel is granted.

The parties' contract is governed by the Uniform Commercial Code. The seller delivered goods that the buyer now claims were non-conforming. However, the buyer failed to reject the goods within a reasonable time after delivery, and thus is deemed to have accepted them under U.C.C. § 2-606.

Appellant challenges the sufficiency of the evidence supporting his conviction. Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, a rational trier of fact could have found the essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. The judgment of the district court is affirmed.

The question presented is one of statutory interpretation. The term 'structure' in the relevant code is undefined. Employing the canon of noscitur a sociis, and looking to the surrounding words in the list, the Court concludes the term does not encompass the temporary scaffolding at issue here.

Defendant argues for a downward departure from the sentencing guidelines based on his family circumstances. While the Court is aware of the potential impact on his dependents, such circumstances are not ordinarily relevant in determining whether a sentence should be outside the Guidelines range. See U.S.S.G. §5H1.6.

The decedent's will bequeaths his estate to his 'surviving children.' One child predeceased the testator but left issue of his own. The state's anti-lapse statute does not apply to this will because the testator's use of the word 'surviving' indicates a contrary intent.

Plaintiff's copyright infringement claim fails at the first step of the analysis. The defendant's work is a parody, which constitutes a transformative use under the fair use doctrine. See *Campbell v. Acuff-Rose Music, Inc.*, 510 U.S. 569 (1994); the use is therefore non-infringing.

This is an appeal from a denial of a motion to change venue. The district court considered the relevant private and public interest factors under 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a). We find its balancing of these factors to be a sound exercise of its discretion and will not disturb the ruling.

Plaintiff claims she was subjected to a hostile work environment. The alleged incidents, however, were sporadic and not physically threatening, consisting of isolated remarks over a period of two years. This conduct does not meet the 'severe or pervasive' standard required to be actionable under Title VII, as articulated in *Harris v. Forklift Sys., Inc.*, 510 U.S. 17 (1993).

The prisoner alleges a violation of his Eighth Amendment rights due to inadequate medical care. To state a claim, a prisoner must allege acts or omissions sufficiently harmful to evidence 'deliberate indifference' to serious medical needs. The facts alleged amount, at most, to negligence, which is insufficient to meet the constitutional threshold.

The trustee seeks to avoid a preferential transfer made by the debtor within 90 days of the bankruptcy petition. The defendant-creditor has established that the transfer was made in the ordinary course of business. The payment therefore falls within the safe harbor of 11 U.S.C. § 547(c)(2), and the trustee's action must fail.

We must determine whether the appellee was in 'custody' for Miranda purposes. A reasonable person in appellee's position would have felt free to terminate the interview and leave. Accordingly, the statements were non-custodial and the absence of Miranda warnings does not compel their suppression.

The Court must decide if the petitioner's prior state conviction constitutes an 'aggravated felony' for purposes of removal under the INA. The elements of the state statute are divisible from the generic federal definition. An examination of the record of conviction reveals that petitioner was convicted under a subsection that qualifies as an aggravated felony, mandating removal.

The defendant corporation speaks of 'market externalities' and 'unforeseen consequences,' yet the record is replete with evidence of a calculated decision to prioritize quarterly profits over the known and catastrophic health risks to the surrounding community. Such a callous disregard for human life cannot be sanitized by the sterile language of economics.

Appellant’s contention that his victims were 'sophisticated investors' is, frankly, an insult to the Court’s intelligence. These were elderly individuals, lured by the promise of security in their twilight years, only to be stripped of their dignity and savings by a scheme of breathtaking cynicism.

Whereas the State argues for qualified immunity, it conveniently overlooks that Officer Smith's actions were not a 'split-second judgment' gone awry, but a calculated and deliberate escalation against a compliant, unarmed citizen. To call this anything less than a flagrant abuse of power would be to render the Fourth Amendment a hollow promise.

The defense suggests this was a simple 'oversight' in a busy emergency room. However, the subsequent alteration of medical records suggests not an oversight, but a conscious and deplorable attempt to conceal a catastrophic error from the patient's grieving family.

The defendant’s claim of self-defense, in light of the video evidence, strains credulity to its breaking point. One does not 'defend' oneself by repeatedly striking a defenseless and retreating individual; that is not defense, it is a brutal and cowardly assault.

Plaintiff’s attempt to characterize its predatory lending practices as 'innovative financial products' is a transparent and offensive euphemism. This Court will not dignify such exploitation by adopting the defendant's self-serving terminology in our analysis of the Unfair Practices Act.

It is one thing to argue a novel interpretation of a statute, as in *Simmons v. PetroCorp*, 45 F.4th 112 (2d Cir. 2022); it is quite another to build that argument upon a foundation of selectively quoted and misrepresented data. The duty of candor to the tribunal is not a suggestion, and the Appellee's conduct here borders on contempt for the judicial process itself.

The government asks this Court to defer to its 'national security' justification for the indefinite detention of the petitioner. But deference is not a synonym for abdication, and we will not rubber-stamp a policy that so profoundly compromises the very liberties we are sworn to protect, especially on such a flimsy evidentiary showing.

Appellant corporation argues that its compliance with baseline regulatory standards immunizes it from liability. This Court struggles to see how a permit to discharge 500 gallons of effluent can be read as a license to systematically decimate an entire aquatic ecosystem, an outcome the defendant's own internal memoranda predicted with chilling accuracy.

The sheer audacity of the defendant’s argument is matched only by the initial deception itself. He now asks the court to find refuge in the labyrinthine clauses of a contract he himself drafted, a contract whose sole purpose appears to be the obfuscation of his scheme to divest retirees of their life savings.

The landlord’s 'business decision' to shut off heat to the apartment complex in mid-January, in a blatant effort to force out low-income tenants, is not merely a breach of contract. It is an act of shocking inhumanity that this Court cannot and will not countenance.

While the law allows for puffery in advertising, the defendant's claims crossed the line from exaggeration into outright falsehood, preying on the desperation of those suffering from chronic illness. Such conduct is not merely tortious; it is morally bankrupt.

The trustee's systematic siphoning of funds from the orphan's trust was not a 'mismanagement' of assets as counsel suggests. It was the methodical and heartless theft from a child, a betrayal of a sacred duty that cries out for exemplary damages.

We are asked to believe that the defendant, an experienced accountant, was simply unaware that he was creating fraudulent invoices for shell corporations. The level of intricate detail in the scheme belies any claim of ignorance and points instead to a deeply rooted and unrepentant dishonesty.

This Court is not persuaded by the argument that the online platform is a mere passive conduit for third-party content. When a platform’s algorithms are deliberately designed to amplify and promote content that glorifies self-harm to minors, it sheds its claim of neutrality and becomes an active participant in the resulting tragedy.

To argue, as the defense does, that the victim's attire constituted some form of 'invitation' is to resurrect a pernicious and long-discredited trope. This court will afford that argument the weight it deserves, which is none.

The patent in question, for a 'method of placing a telephone call,' represents a brazen attempt to monopolize a fundamental human interaction. The patent office's decision to grant it is a bewildering failure of common sense, and this Court will not enforce such an absurd claim.

Heretofore, this court has respected the corporate veil, but we will not allow it to be used as a shield for fraud. The defendant treated the corporate entity as his personal piggy bank, and he cannot now claim surprise when we hold him personally accountable for the debts he so recklessly incurred.

The defendant’s motion to suppress evidence based on a minor typographical error in the warrant is a classic example of elevating form over substance. To allow a known drug trafficker to escape justice on such a flimsy pretext would make a mockery of the exclusionary rule, a principle established in *Mapp v. Ohio*, 367 U.S. 643 (1961), to deter police misconduct, not to reward clever lawyering.

The respondent's claim to be a 'church' exempt from taxation appears to be little more than a cynical ploy to avoid financial responsibility. An entity whose primary activity is selling questionable dietary supplements via late-night infomercials bears none of the indicia of a bona fide religious organization.

The defendant's 'initials' on the bottom of each page of the forged document are not a mark of authenticity. They are, rather, a signature of his own arrogance, a belief that his intricate deception was too clever to be discovered.

In this custody dispute, the father’s primary objection to the mother’s fitness is that she works a second job to provide for the child. The notion that such sacrifice and dedication could be spun into a negative factor is offensive and wholly without merit.

Appellant’s appeal to *Chevron* deference is misplaced where the agency’s interpretation is not just unreasonable, but is a biologically and logically incoherent reading of its own enabling statute. We do not defer to nonsense.

The defendant insurance company collected premiums from the plaintiff for thirty years, only to deny his claim based on an obscure and ambiguously worded exclusion clause. This is not a good-faith dispute over contract language; it is a contemptible act of corporate betrayal.

To describe the defendant’s actions as 'inappropriate touching' is to engage in a grotesque understatement. The record demonstrates a pattern of predatory behavior and a flagrant abuse of his position of trust as a youth coach.

The plaintiff’s continued litigation of this matter, after four previous dismissals, is not zealous advocacy. It is a vexatious and malicious abuse of the judicial system, designed to harass and financially cripple the defendant, and it must be stopped.

We are told that the defendant’s hate-filled screed, calling for violence against his neighbors, was mere 'hyperbole.' There is nothing hyperbolic about fear, and the families who were forced to flee their homes certainly did not interpret his words as a rhetorical exercise.

The factory owner’s testimony that he was unaware of the child labor occurring on his premises is simply not credible. A willful blindness to the exploitation happening under one's own roof is not a defense; it is complicity.

This case presents a stark portrait of a legal system being weaponized by the wealthy. The defendant has filed a dozen meritless motions, not in a good-faith effort to defend himself, but as a strategy of attrition against a plaintiff with limited resources.

The prosecutor’s repeated allusions to the defendant’s decision to remain silent are a flagrant violation of the principles laid down in *Griffin v. California*, 380 U.S. 609 (1965). This was not a slip of the tongue; it was a calculated and unconstitutional tactic to prejudice the jury.

Whereas the defendant characterizes the transaction as a 'shrewd business deal,' the Court sees it for what it is: the exploitation of a mentally infirm elder for financial gain. The law of contracts was not designed to ratify such predatory conduct.

The defendant now seeks leniency, citing his community standing and charitable works. Such activities, however, appear to be less a product of genuine altruism and more a cynical investment in a façade to conceal a decade of systematic fraud.

This court is deeply troubled by the school district's argument that it can censor student journalism that is merely 'unflattering' to the administration. That is not a pedagogical concern; it is the reasoning of an autocrat, and it has no place in our constitutional jurisprudence since *Tinker v. Des Moines*, 393 U.S. 503 (1969).

The sheer volume of pollutants the defendant company knowingly dumped into the river, in direct violation of a prior consent decree, is staggering. This is not merely a failure to comply; it is an act of profound bad faith and a brazen challenge to the authority of this Court.

For the defendant to claim he 'forgot' about the millions of dollars in offshore accounts during his sworn deposition is an assertion of such implausibility that it borders on the comical, were the subject matter not so serious. This Court does not suffer fools gladly, nor does it tolerate perjury.

The plaintiff, a victim of a brutal hit-and-run, is now being subjected to a litigation strategy that seems designed to re-traumatize her. The defendant driver's endless requests for invasive medical and psychological records are not for discovery, but for intimidation.

The idea that a person's digital data, once shared with a third party like a phone company, loses all constitutional protection is a doctrine born of a bygone era. To apply it today is to grant the government a key to the most intimate details of our lives, a result the Framers would have found abhorrent.

The defendant now claims his confession was coerced, yet the video recording shows detectives offering him coffee and speaking in measured tones. What the defendant truly objects to is not coercion, but the sting of being caught in his own web of lies.

Appellant’s argument that its AI-driven hiring tool is proprietary and therefore immune from discovery is unavailing. The court will not permit a 'trade secret' to serve as a black box to conceal what may be a discriminatory and unlawful employment practice, a clear violation of principles in *Griggs v. Duke Power Co.*, 401 U.S. 424 (1971).

The defendant's testimony, a rambling and self-serving narrative riddled with inconsistencies, did more to confirm his guilt than any evidence presented by the State. It was a performance of breathtaking arrogance and a profound disrespect for the solemnity of these proceedings.

The city’s decision to seize the plaintiff's home through eminent domain, only to sell it to a private developer for a luxury condominium project, makes a mockery of the 'public use' requirement. This is not public use; it is public plunder for private profit.

While defendants in a class action are entitled to a vigorous defense, the strategy employed here—to bury the plaintiffs' counsel in millions of pages of irrelevant documents—is an abuse of the discovery process. It is a tactic designed to exhaust, not to enlighten.

The defendant’s attempt to blame his subordinate for the fraudulent accounting is a cowardly and contemptible act. The evidence is overwhelming that he was the architect of the scheme and that he ruthlessly manipulated his employees to achieve his ends.

We are confronted here with a will that disinherits the decedent’s children in favor of a 'caregiver' who appeared in the last two months of his life. The circumstances surrounding its execution are so profoundly suspicious that they shock the conscience of this Court.

The argument that the defendant’s online threats were just 'trolling' and not a 'true threat' under the law willfully ignores the terror they induced. The First Amendment is a shield for robust debate, not a sword for psychological terrorism.

The defendant's plea for probation rings hollow when viewed against the backdrop of his utter lack of remorse. He expresses sorrow only for being caught, not for the lives he ruined through his Ponzi scheme.

To suggest, as the appellee does, that a non-compete agreement preventing a janitor from working for any other cleaning company in the state is 'reasonable' is patently absurd. This is not a tool to protect trade secrets; it is an instrument of economic servitude.

The fact that the defendant continued to sell the defective product for six months after his own engineers warned him of a fatal flaw is, in the judgment of this Court, evidence of a depraved indifference to human life. This is not negligence; it approaches the culpability of an intentional act.

The petitioner’s argument, stripped of its legalese, is that he should be allowed to build a chemical plant next to an elementary school. The zoning board's denial was not arbitrary or capricious; it was a basic and necessary act of public protection.
After orchestrating a multi-million dollar fraud, the defendant now presents himself as a victim of an overzealous prosecution. This rebranding effort is as audacious as it is unpersuasive.

Lest our decision be misinterpreted as a novel expansion of judicial power, we must emphasize that we are merely applying the well-settled principles of *Marbury* to a new technology. To hold otherwise would be an abdication of our duty, not an exercise of restraint.

While the defendant paints a picture of a coerced confession, the record plainly shows a voluntary and knowing waiver of his rights under *Miranda*. We decline to indulge in the speculative psychology that defense counsel urges upon us.

Some may argue this interpretation of the duty of care places a heavy burden on manufacturers, but that is precisely the burden the legislature intended when drafting the Consumer Protection Act. It is not our role to second-guess that considered policy judgment, however inconvenient it may be for corporate defendants.

The trial court's evidentiary ruling was, without question, correct under the standard set forth in *United States v. O'Brien*, 391 U.S. 367 (1968). Any suggestion that the court abused its discretion is simply not supported by a sober reading of the record.

Plaintiff’s argument would require us to read an ambiguity into a contract that is, on its face, perfectly clear. Though this outcome may seem harsh, this court cannot act as an insurer for parties who fail to protect their own interests through clear drafting.

We are well aware of the deference owed to agency interpretations under *Chevron*, but that deference is not a rubber stamp for agency action that directly contravenes the statutory text. Our holding today is a straightforward application of settled law, not a new front in a war on the administrative state.

To be clear, our holding does not leave the government powerless to regulate political speech; it simply requires that such regulations be narrowly tailored, a standard the ordinance at issue manifestly fails to meet. This is a basic tenet of First Amendment jurisprudence, not a radical departure.

Though the dissent characterizes our custody determination as a mechanical application of a formula, it is in fact a careful weighing of the statutory 'best interests' factors. Our analysis is grounded in the record, not, as the dissent might suggest, in a cold or unfeeling calculus.

The contention that our finding of non-obviousness will stifle innovation is unpersuasive and ignores the fundamental purpose of the patent system. Protecting genuine invention, as we do today, is the very mechanism that encourages, rather than hinders, progress.

This Court does not sit to relitigate every state-level criminal trial, and we are constrained by the high bar set by the AEDPA. The petitioner’s claims, while passionately argued, simply do not rise to the level of a constitutional violation cognizable on federal habeas review.

We admit the challenged expert testimony not out of a disregard for the strictures of *Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals*, 509 U.S. 579 (1993), but because it fully satisfies them. To exclude this testimony would be to misunderstand the court's role as a gatekeeper, transforming it into that of an arbiter of scientific truth.

Granting qualified immunity here is not, as Plaintiff suggests, a carte blanche for official misconduct. Rather, it is a necessary application of Supreme Court precedent, which requires that the law be 'clearly established'—a standard not met in this novel factual scenario.

The trustee argues for an expansive reading of 'property of the estate' that has no mooring in the text of the Bankruptcy Code. While we are sympathetic to the goal of maximizing creditor recovery, we cannot achieve that goal by rewriting a statute passed by Congress.

The EPA’s interpretation of the Clean Water Act stretches the statutory language beyond its breaking point, and we must reject it. This is not judicial activism; it is a necessary check on an agency that has exceeded its congressionally delegated authority.

A downward variance is not warranted here, despite the defendant’s sympathetic personal story. To grant such a variance would create the very sentencing disparities the Guidelines were designed to prevent, and we will not subvert that clear statutory purpose.

We are not, as the Commission argues, creating a loophole for securities fraud; we are merely enforcing the 'in connection with' requirement as it has been consistently interpreted for decades. Any change to this long-standing rule must come from Congress, not the Judiciary.

The Court is mindful that summary judgment is a drastic remedy, but it is a necessary one where, as here, the plaintiff has failed to produce even a scintilla of evidence on a critical element of her claim. To send this case to a jury would be to invite pure speculation.

Our decision, which applies the clear precedent of *NLRB v. Mackay Radio*, 304 U.S. 333 (1938), should not be viewed as an anti-union stance. It is, quite simply, the law as it stands, which this court is bound to apply.

While the petitioner’s tax-avoidance structure was undoubtedly clever, it elevates form over substance in a way the Tax Code does not permit. This is not a punishment for ingenuity, but a simple recognition that a transaction’s economic reality, not its label, is what matters.

The dissent would have this court re-weigh the evidence and substitute its own judgment for that of the jury, a role fundamentally at odds with the nature of appellate review. Our task is to determine if a reasonable jury *could* have reached this verdict, and it is plain that one could.

We are not unconcerned with the privacy implications of new surveillance technologies, but the specific conduct here falls squarely within the 'third-party doctrine' established in *Smith v. Maryland*, 442 U.S. 735 (1979). We are not free to ignore binding Supreme Court precedent, however dated some may find it to be.

It would be an unworkable and dangerous rule to hold that a manufacturer must warn against every conceivable misuse of its product, no matter how unforeseeable. The law requires a warning for *intended* and *reasonably foreseeable* uses, a standard the defendant has clearly met.

Denying certification is not an adjudication on the merits of the underlying claims, but a recognition that the proposed class lacks the commonality required under Rule 23. This procedural gatekeeping is essential to ensure that the class action device is not abused.

The plaintiff’s reliance on a single, isolated clause of the statute, read out of context, is unavailing. It is a 'fundamental canon of statutory construction that the words of a statute must be read in their context and with a view to their place in the overall statutory scheme,' a canon the plaintiff would have us ignore.

We take no joy in this result, but the Immigration and Nationality Act, as written by Congress, compels it. Policy arguments about the equities of the petitioner's situation are best directed to the legislative branch, not to a court whose only duty is to apply the law as it exists.

Enforcing the Establishment Clause here is not an act of hostility towards religion, as the appellants contend. It is, rather, an act of neutrality, ensuring that the state does not prefer one religion over another, or religion over non-religion.

The government’s theory of antitrust liability in this case is a novel one for which there is no support in the case law. We decline the invitation to expand the Sherman Act beyond its recognized boundaries, a task better suited for Congress than for a district court.

Sanctions are warranted here not to punish the defendant, but to underscore the importance of complying with discovery obligations. The integrity of the judicial process itself depends on parties engaging in good faith, and that did not happen here.

Our holding is a narrow one, dictated by the specific facts of this case and the clear command of *Heller* and *Bruen*. We are not invalidating all firearms regulations, but merely applying binding Supreme Court precedent to the specific regulation before us.

The doctrine of *contra proferentem* does not apply here, as its invocation requires a finding of ambiguity in the first instance—a finding we cannot make. This court will not create ambiguity where none exists simply to rescue a sophisticated party from a bargain it now regrets.

To find proximate cause in these circumstances would be to stretch the concept beyond all recognition, turning it into a synonym for 'but-for' causation. The law has, for sound policy reasons, long rejected such an unconstrained view of liability.

While the federal interest is significant, it does not permit the wholesale commandeering of state officials that this statute contemplates, per *Printz v. United States*, 521 U.S. 898 (1997). This is a simple application of a core federalism principle, not a judicial thumb on the scale for states' rights.

The court does not grant this preliminary injunction lightly, as it is aware of the significant burden it places on the defendant. However, the plaintiff has made a clear showing of irreparable harm, and the court's duty in such a circumstance is equally clear.

Appointing counsel from the Public Defender's Office in this complex white-collar case does not, contrary to defendant's assertions, create a presumption of ineffective assistance. To suggest as much is an unsupported and unwarranted attack on the competence and dedication of public defenders.

The contested statement is not being offered for the truth of the matter asserted and is therefore, by definition, not hearsay. While counsel may dislike the effect of the statement, that does not change its fundamental, non-hearsay character under Rule 801(c).

The procedural default doctrine is not a mere technicality; it is a crucial component of federal-state comity. We cannot, and will not, ignore a petitioner's failure to properly raise his claims in state court, as doing so would undermine the finality of state court judgments.

The conditions of confinement described by the plaintiff, while certainly unpleasant, do not rise to the level of a constitutional violation under the 'deliberate indifference' standard. The Eighth Amendment is not a 'general code of prison regulations,' and we must be careful not to constitutionalize every aspect of prison administration.

The suggestion that this case falls into the 'capable of repetition, yet evading review' exception is unconvincing. That exception is a narrow one, and applying it here would transform it from a practical necessity into a license for issuing advisory opinions, which Article III forbids.

The 'transformative use' doctrine is not a magic wand that can be waved over any act of copying to make it a fair use. Our analysis today is a faithful application of the statutory factors, not a rejection of the transformative use concept itself.

We remand to the agency not because we disagree with its policy goals, but because its reasoning was arbitrary and capricious, failing to consider an important aspect of the problem. This is a procedural check, not a substantive one, and fully in line with the dictates of the Administrative Procedure Act.

The plaintiff’s attempt to frame this as a 'class-of-one' equal protection claim is a misapplication of the doctrine as set forth in *Village of Willowbrook v. Olech*, 528 U.S. 562 (2000). Such claims require a showing of animus that is wholly absent from this record.

Contrary to the defendant's argument, the officer's actions were a textbook example of a lawful *Terry* frisk, based on specific and articulable facts. To invalidate this search would be to render police unable to protect themselves in precisely the sort of tense, uncertain situations the *Terry* doctrine was designed for.

The 'substantial factor' test for causation does not relieve the plaintiff of the burden of proving her case; it simply clarifies the standard. Here, plaintiff has failed to show that defendant’s conduct was even a 'substantial factor,' let alone the sole cause, and we will not lower the bar for liability just to ensure a recovery.

The court, as the trier of fact, found the defendant's testimony to be incredible, a determination based on demeanor, tone, and inconsistencies in the narrative. This court has the unique advantage of having observed the witnesses firsthand, a fact that must be given significant weight.

Dismissing this case on standing grounds is not a refusal to address an important issue, as the dissent contends. It is a recognition of the constitutional limits of our own power, which extends only to actual 'cases or controversies.'

Some may call this reading of the statute hyper-literal, but it is the only one that gives effect to every word Congress chose to write. We cannot simply ignore certain phrases or clauses because they lead to a result we find inconvenient.

The plaintiff wishes for us to consider extrinsic evidence to contradict the clear terms of the integrated written agreement, which is precisely what the parol evidence rule forbids. The rule may seem a technicality, but it is one that undergirds the predictability and stability of all commercial transactions.

The admission of the forensic report without live testimony from its creator was, admittedly, an error under *Crawford v. Washington*, 541 U.S. 36 (2004), but it was plainly harmless beyond a reasonable doubt. Reversing a conviction on such a basis, where the other evidence of guilt is overwhelming, would be a triumph of form over substance.

It must be stressed that the 'clearly established law' standard for overcoming qualified immunity is a demanding one, and for good reason. We cannot expect public officials to be clairvoyant constitutional scholars, liable for damages every time a new legal rule is announced.

The motion for reconsideration raises no new arguments and presents no new evidence that was not, or could not have been, presented initially. This court's decisions are not mere first drafts, to be endlessly revised upon the request of a dissatisfied litigant.

While the dissent raises a valid concern regarding the potential for abuse under our holding, we believe that a faithful reading of the statute, as interpreted by *Donovan v. City of Augusta*, 45 F.4th 112 (1st Cir. 2022), compels this result.

Plaintiff’s counsel has advanced a novel and thought-provoking theory of proximate cause in this complex products liability action; however, it is a theory foreclosed by the controlling precedent of *Cromwell v. Apex Manufacturing*, 987 F.2d 50 (7th Cir. 1993).

I concur in the judgment and join in the majority’s thorough opinion, save for its reliance on the 'transformative use' test. I would reach the same conclusion through a more direct application of our holding in *Finch Creative v. Gallant*, 55 F.4th 210 (9th Cir. 2022).

My colleagues in the majority present a formidable case for their position, and I do not lightly depart from their conclusion. Nevertheless, I am convinced their interpretation of 'exigent circumstances' stretches the doctrine beyond its breaking point, as established in *United States v. Harding*, 345 F.3d 112 (2d Cir. 2018).

The Court is not unsympathetic to the Defendant's plight, and his counsel has argued his case with admirable zeal. The plain language of the mandatory minimum sentencing statute, however, affords this Court no discretion.

We acknowledge the district court’s careful and well-intentioned effort to balance the equities in this difficult administrative law case. Nonetheless, its decision constitutes a clear error of law by failing to afford proper deference to the agency's interpretation, as required by *Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. NRDC*, 467 U.S. 837 (1984).

The majority’s exegesis of the Internal Revenue Code is both intricate and learned. My sole disagreement is that it overlooks a crucial legislative report that I believe is dispositive of the tax treatment at issue.

Although counsel for the Defendant makes a compelling policy argument, the plain language of the statute constrains this Court. As we are not legislators, we must grant the motion to dismiss based on the text as written.

I concur fully in the majority's well-reasoned analysis of the Fourth Amendment violation. I write separately only to express my view that the issue of qualified immunity, which my colleagues correctly find was waived below, presents a far closer question.

The dissent correctly notes the potential for our holding to disrupt certain industry practices. We are confident, however, that the market, guided by the clear statutory language we affirm today, will readily adapt.

I agree with my esteemed colleagues that the procedural history of this case is a Gordian Knot. I simply believe they have chosen the wrong strand to pull in decertifying the class under Rule 23(b)(3).

The Court appreciates the Trustee's diligence in this bankruptcy proceeding. However, the equitable powers under 11 U.S.C. § 105(a) are not a roving commission to do justice, and the relief sought is simply not authorized by the Code.

Though I arrive at the same destination as the majority, I take a different road, one I believe is more securely paved by the principles of federalism articulated in *Younger v. Harris*, 401 U.S. 37 (1971).

The petitioner’s argument, while not without persuasive force, ultimately fails. The strictures of AEDPA deference as defined in *Harrington v. Richter*, 562 U.S. 86 (2011), compel a denial of the writ of habeas corpus.

I commend the majority for its thoughtful attempt to draw a bright line in a murky area of evidence law. I fear, however, that the line it draws today is not only difficult to administer but also unfaithful to the principles of *Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals*, 509 U.S. 579 (1993).

The trial judge managed this sprawling, multi-week patent trial with consummate skill. We are therefore reluctant to disturb the judgment, but must do so, as the jury instructions contained a clear misstatement of the doctrine of equivalents from *Festool USA v. SawStop, LLC*, 812 F.3d 990 (Fed. Cir. 2019).

Plaintiff’s narrative of the events is indeed plausible and was presented with conviction. At the summary judgment stage, however, plausibility is not enough to overcome a lack of admissible evidence on the essential element of causation.

I join the majority opinion in full but write to emphasize a point of comity with our state court colleagues that is implicit in the ruling. Our decision today on federal preemption should not be read to question the wisdom of the state's underlying policy goals.

The majority’s opinion is a model of clarity in applying the parol evidence rule. My respectful disagreement stems from a conviction that the contract at issue is latently ambiguous, a possibility our precedent in *Trident Center v. Connecticut Gen. Life Ins.*, 847 F.2d 564 (9th Cir. 1988), requires us to consider.

While the Court acknowledges the emotional weight of this family law dispute, it is constrained by the jurisdictional limits of the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction and Enforcement Act. This matter properly belongs in the courts of another state.

We have given careful consideration to the dissent’s concerns regarding the Establishment Clause. We believe, however, that our colleague's interpretation would create a hostility to religion not contemplated by our precedent in *Everson v. Board of Education*, 330 U.S. 1 (1947).

My colleagues in the majority are not wrong to be concerned about the effects of the speech at issue; where we part ways is on whether those concerns constitutionally justify the prior restraint imposed by the city ordinance.

Defendant's counsel presents an ingenious argument that the information at issue was not, in fact, a trade secret. The weight of the evidence presented at the preliminary injunction hearing, however, suggests otherwise.

We thank our dissenting colleague for highlighting a potential unintended consequence of our ruling. Congress remains free, of course, to amend the statute should it find that our interpretation does not align with its legislative intent.

I agree with the outcome but cannot join the majority's reasoning, which I believe unnecessarily reaches a constitutional question. It is a 'fundamental and long-standing principle of judicial restraint,' as noted in *Lyng v. Northwest Indian Cemetery Protective Assn.*, 485 U.S. 439 (1988), that we should avoid such questions when a statutory ground for decision is available.

Counsel for the plaintiffs has painted a vivid picture of corporate malfeasance. Be that as it may, they have failed to plead with particularity why a pre-suit demand on the board would have been futile, as required by Delaware law in *Aronson v. Lewis*, 473 A.2d 805 (Del. 1984).

I commend the majority for its careful review of the extensive record in this capital case. I must, however, respectfully dissent, as I believe the cumulative effect of counsel’s errors amounted to a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to effective assistance.

We acknowledge the district court's thorough opinion in this antitrust matter. We find, however, a clear error in its application of the 'rule of reason' analysis, which was too narrowly focused on a single product market.

While this Court understands the plaintiff's frustration with the denial of her ERISA benefits, the 'abuse of discretion' standard of review is highly deferential. Under *Firestone Tire & Rubber Co. v. Bruch*, 489 U.S. 101 (1989), we cannot substitute our own judgment for that of the plan administrator.

The dissent makes a compelling case for a different approach to the good-faith exception under *United States v. Leon*, 468 U.S. 897 (1984). Our precedent in this circuit, however, has consistently followed a narrower path, and we are not at liberty to diverge from it here.
I concur, but only in the judgment. The majority's reliance on the 'state-created danger' doctrine is, in my respectful view, an unwarranted expansion of substantive due process jurisprudence.

The Court does not doubt the sincerity of the plaintiff's beliefs. The issue, however, is whether the Free Exercise Clause requires an exemption from a neutral law of general applicability, a question answered in the negative by *Employment Div. v. Smith*, 494 U.S. 872 (1990).

We appreciate the dissent’s careful historical analysis of the water rights treaty. We are persuaded, however, that the plain meaning of the text, interpreted in light of *Arizona v. California*, 373 U.S. 546 (1963), requires the outcome we reach today.

My dissenting colleague quite rightly points out the harshness of this result. Yet, our task is to interpret the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act as written, not to rewrite it to achieve a more equitable outcome in every case.

Defendant's motion for sanctions is not without some basis, as plaintiff's filings have been voluminous. The Court, however, will exercise its discretion and deny the motion, trusting that counsel's future conduct will hew more closely to the spirit of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 11.

I join the majority's fine opinion in full. I write separately only to commend the district court's handling of this extraordinarily complex multidistrict litigation, even though we must reverse its ultimate conclusion on class certification.

The Board of Immigration Appeals’ decision, while understandable in light of the claimant's convoluted testimony, was not supported by substantial evidence. We reach this conclusion with due respect for the BIA's expertise in these difficult matters.

The defendant argues, with some justification, that the jury's damages award is generous. It is not, however, so 'monstrously excessive' as to shock the conscience, which is the demanding standard this Court must apply under *Gasperini v. Center for Humanities, Inc.*, 518 U.S. 415 (1996).

My colleagues present a solid case for implied preemption under *Geier v. American Honda Motor Co.*, 529 U.S. 861 (2000). I am simply of the view that, absent a clearer statement from Congress, we should be more reluctant to displace the traditional police powers of the States.

The Court found the testimony of the plaintiff's expert to be cogent and well-delivered. Unfortunately, his methodology is not one generally accepted in the scientific community, and thus his testimony must be excluded under Federal Rule of Evidence 702.

The dissent's proposed test for personal jurisdiction has the benefit of simplicity, and I concede its appeal. I am convinced, however, that it cannot be squared with the 'minimum contacts' framework of *International Shoe Co. v. Washington*, 326 U.S. 310 (1945).

We do not take lightly the act of reversing a seasoned trial judge on a finding of fact. But where, as here, that finding is premised on a clear misapprehension of the documentary evidence, we are compelled to do so under the 'clearly erroneous' standard.

I fully endorse the majority’s sound reasoning and conclusion regarding the Second Amendment. I write separately only to note that the historical analysis provided by our dissenting colleague, while comprehensive, focuses on a period less relevant than the Reconstruction era for this particular inquiry.

Plaintiff makes a forceful public policy argument for why the statement should be considered defamatory per se. This Court, however, is bound by the state supreme court's contrary holding in *Michaels v. Tribune Co.*, 45 N.E.2d 104 (Ill. 1942).

Though I cannot join the majority opinion, I wish to acknowledge its scholarly contribution to our circuit's takings jurisprudence. My disagreement is a narrow one, concerning only the ripeness of the claim.

The non-movant has made a valiant effort to construct a genuine issue of material fact from circumstantial evidence. As held in *Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc.*, 477 U.S. 242 (1986), however, mere speculation is not sufficient to defeat a well-supported motion for summary judgment.

The elegance of the dissent's proposed framework for analyzing patent eligibility under § 101 is undeniable. We fear, however, that it is ultimately unworkable and would conflict with the Supreme Court's more pragmatic approach in *Alice Corp. v. CLS Bank Int'l*, 573 U.S. 208 (2014).

I respectfully dissent from the majority's application of the political question doctrine. While I share my colleagues' reluctance to enter this fray, I believe the issue presented is one of constitutional interpretation, a quintessential judicial function.

Counsel's oral argument on behalf of the appellant was a model of clarity and persuasion. Nevertheless, the position he advocates would require us to overrule a recent en banc decision of this court, *Estrada v. United States*, 998 F.3d 101 (5th Cir. 2021) (en banc), which a three-judge panel cannot do.

While the Court acknowledges the zeal with which plaintiff's counsel has pursued this matter, the filing of this third amended complaint crosses from zealous advocacy to vexatious litigation. We do not reach this conclusion lightly, and have given due consideration to counsel's arguments against the imposition of sanctions.

Plaintiff's reliance on *Driscoll v. Wallace*, 987 F. Supp. 2d 112 (D. Mass. 2018), is misplaced, as that case involved a clear contractual ambiguity not present here. The Court will not entertain this strained analogy further.

Defendant's equal protection argument is, to be frank, a boilerplate assertion tacked onto its motion to dismiss. It is presented without meaningful analysis and fails to identify a similarly situated class that was treated differently.
The appellant now rehashes the same causation arguments that the jury, and the trial court, rightly rejected. We are a court of review, not a forum for a second bite at the evidentiary apple.

Plaintiff’s attempt to characterize ordinary business competition as tortious interference is unavailing. The complaint simply repackages a failed contract claim in the garb of a tort, a tactic this Court does not countenance.

The pro se petitioner’s filing is a collection of grievances rather than a coherent legal argument. While we construe pro se pleadings liberally, we cannot invent a claim that has not been articulated.

The defendant’s argument that the statute is void for vagueness is a textbook example of a facial challenge made with little connection to the facts at hand. We see no ambiguity in the statute as applied to this defendant’s conduct.

We need not linger long on Appellant's second point of error regarding jury instructions. The argument is presented without a single citation to relevant authority and is therefore waived. *See Franklin v. State*, 98 S.W.3d 450 (Tex. Crim. App. 2003).

The notion that a sophisticated commercial entity was unaware of the plain terms of a multi-million dollar contract it negotiated at arm's length strains credulity. We decline to shield the plaintiff from the consequences of its own bargain.

Defendant's motion to compel is predicated on a fishing expedition into irrelevant and privileged matters. The discovery rules are broad, but they do not permit a party to rummage through its opponent's files in the speculative hope of finding something useful.

The remaining state-law claims are before this Court on supplemental jurisdiction, and they are frankly derivative of the federal claims we have already dismissed. We see no compelling reason to retain them.

Counsel for the defendant advances the creative but ultimately unsupported theory that the officer's brief questioning constituted a de facto arrest. Our precedent is clear that not every police-citizen encounter triggers Fourth Amendment scrutiny. *See, e.g., United States v. Mendenhall*, 446 U.S. 544 (1980).

The defendant’s assertion of an alibi defense at this late stage, after months of discovery, is noted. However, the Court finds the proffer to be both untimely and conspicuously lacking in corroborating detail.

Appellant's argument, that the chain of custody was 'irrevocably broken,' is a dramatic overstatement. The minor discrepancy in the evidence log, fully explained at trial, is scarcely the stuff of which reversible error is made. *See People v. Rivas*, 112 Cal. App. 4th 1150 (2003).

The defendant’s motion to suppress his confession is predicated on a subjective feeling of coercion that finds no objective support in the record. The interview was brief, non-accusatory, and the defendant was repeatedly told he was free to leave.

We find Appellant’s challenge to the sufficiency of the evidence to be without merit. He essentially asks this Court to re-weigh the credibility of witnesses, a task reserved exclusively for the trier of fact.

The petitioner’s habeas claim is a thinly veiled attempt to relitigate issues already decided on direct appeal. This is not the proper function of a writ of habeas corpus, and the petition is accordingly dismissed.

The defendant’s complaint about his sentence, while heartfelt, does not articulate a cognizable legal error. The sentence was well within the statutory guidelines, and this Court does not sit to review a trial judge's discretionary sentencing choices absent clear abuse.

This Court finds the defendant's invocation of the 'castle doctrine' to be entirely inapposite to the facts presented. The altercation occurred in a public park, a location heretofore not recognized as a 'castle' by any court in this jurisdiction.
The defendant’s claim of prosecutorial misconduct rests on a single, ambiguous phrase in a lengthy closing argument. To call this a due process violation would be to trivialize the concept entirely.

The argument that a routine traffic stop for a broken taillight was a pretext for an illegal search has been raised and rejected countless times. So long as the stop itself was lawful, the officer's subjective motivations are irrelevant. *Whren v. United States*, 517 U.S. 806 (1996).

Petitioners' standing argument relies on a speculative chain of events that may or may not occur as a result of the agency's new rule. Such 'someday' injuries are not sufficient to confer Article III standing. *See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife*, 504 U.S. 555 (1992).
The plaintiff’s First Amendment claim seems to be that he has a right to protest in a non-public forum, a proposition for which he cites no supporting law. This argument is a non-starter.

While Appellant frames this as a case of first impression, it is in fact governed by the straightforward principles laid out in *Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. Natural Res. Def. Council, Inc.*, 467 U.S. 837 (1984). The agency's interpretation of the statute it administers is plainly reasonable.

The attempt to elevate a routine zoning dispute into a constitutional takings claim is unpersuasive. The plaintiff has not been deprived of all economically beneficial use of his land, and his argument to the contrary is simply not credible. *See Lucas v. S.C. Coastal Council*, 505 U.S. 1003 (1992).

The plaintiff’s substantive due process argument is little more than an invitation for this Court to substitute its own policy judgments for those of the state legislature. We decline this invitation, as we have on many prior occasions.

The argument that the city's licensing scheme for street vendors is an unconstitutional prior restraint on speech is a strained one. Selling hot dogs is conduct, not pure speech, and the plaintiff’s attempt to conflate the two is unavailing.

The Court is not persuaded by the plaintiff’s conclusory allegation that the school board's policy was motivated by religious animus. The policy has a clear secular purpose, and the plaintiff has offered no actual evidence of pretext.

To suggest that a procedural filing deadline is merely 'aspirational' is an audacious, if incorrect, argument. The rules of civil procedure exist for a reason, and the plaintiff’s failure to comply has consequences.
