The defendant’s intricate theory of dormant commerce clause preemption is academically interesting but practically irrelevant. The state law in question regulates a purely local activity with no discernible effect on interstate commerce.

The petitioner’s argument, stripped of its rhetorical flourishes, is that the administrative law judge erred by believing one witness over another. Such credibility determinations are the quintessential function of the fact-finder and are not for us to disturb.

The plaintiff’s claim for emotional distress is based on nothing more than the ordinary frustration of a business deal gone sour. This jurisdiction has never recognized such a claim, and we will not do so today.

The defendant’s affirmative defense of laches is wholly without support in the record. The plaintiff filed suit well within the statute of limitations, and the defendant has demonstrated no prejudice from the passage of time.

The argument that the trademark 'Glo-Brite' is merely descriptive is plainly incorrect. The mark is suggestive, requiring some imagination to connect it to the product, and is therefore inherently distinctive. *See Zatarains, Inc. v. Oak Grove Smokehouse, Inc.*, 698 F.2d 786 (5th Cir. 1983).

We find the appellant's argument that the jury's damages award was 'excessive' to be a mere expression of disagreement. The award was supported by competent evidence and is not so large as to shock the judicial conscience.

The plaintiff’s effort to pierce the corporate veil is based on little more than suspicion and innuendo. The formalities of corporate separation were observed, and we will not disregard the corporate form on such a flimsy showing.

Counsel’s attempt to distinguish the controlling precedent of *Hadley v. Baxendale*, 156 Eng. Rep. 145 (1854), is unconvincing. The foreseeability of damages is a core principle of contract law from which we see no reason to deviate.
The defendant's assertion of the 'unclean hands' doctrine is an ill-fitting defense in this context. The plaintiff's alleged misconduct is wholly unrelated to the subject matter of this litigation.

The plaintiff’s nuisance claim fails for the simple reason that he 'came to the nuisance.' One who knowingly acquires property in a loud, industrial area can hardly be surprised to find that the area is, in fact, loud and industrial.

The Court is unimpressed by Defendant's eleventh-hour motion for a continuance. The scheduling order in this case was set months ago, and the alleged need for more discovery is a problem of Defendant's own making.

The plaintiff’s product liability claim rests on the fanciful notion that the manufacturer had a duty to warn against a danger that was open and obvious to any reasonable consumer. The law does not require warnings against the self-evident.

The petitioner's argument under *Brady v. Maryland*, 373 U.S. 83 (1963), fails at the outset. The 'suppressed' evidence he now highlights was neither exculpatory nor material to the outcome of his trial.

The defendant’s request for a *Franks* hearing is denied, as it amounts to little more than a quibble with the affiant’s word choice. The defendant has made no substantial preliminary showing that the warrant affidavit contained a deliberate or reckless falsehood. *See Franks v. Delaware*, 438 U.S. 154 (1978).

The defendant argues that the photo array was impermissibly suggestive, yet he can point to no specific feature that made his photo stand out. The Court has reviewed the array and finds it to be a perfectly ordinary collection of similar-looking individuals.

The appellant’s claim that he was 'forced' to testify is a gross mischaracterization of the record. The trial court merely advised him of his right to testify or to remain silent, and the choice was his alone to make.

The defendant’s Confrontation Clause objection is without merit. The statement in question was not testimonial, as it was made to a 911 operator for the primary purpose of enabling a police response to an ongoing emergency. *See Davis v. Washington*, 547 U.S. 813 (2006).

The defendant’s elaborate conspiracy theory about the jury's deliberations is built on a foundation of pure speculation. We do not permit inquiry into the jury’s internal thought processes based on such fanciful claims.
The argument that the arresting officer lacked probable cause is difficult to take seriously. The defendant was found at the scene, holding the stolen property, and confessed moments later.

The appellant’s challenge to the grand jury proceedings is an exercise in futility. An indictment, valid on its face, is not subject to challenge on the ground that the evidence before the grand jury was inadequate. *Costello v. United States*, 350 U.S. 359 (1956).

The defendant’s motion to sever his trial from that of his co-defendant is based on the generic assertion that their defenses are 'mutually antagonistic.' This is a high bar, and the defendant has come nowhere close to meeting it.

The petitioner’s ineffective assistance of counsel claim is a classic 'Monday morning quarterback' argument. We evaluate counsel's performance from their perspective at the time, not with the benefit of 20/20 hindsight.

The dispositive question with which this Court is presently confronted pertains to the fundamental determination of whether the contractual instrument at issue possesses a sufficient degree of ambiguity so as to preclude a definitive interpretation as a matter of law.

We are called upon to evaluate the appellant's contention that the trial court's jury instructions were so fundamentally flawed as to constitute a deprivation of due process, a standard that requires more than a mere showing of potential prejudice; a comprehensive review of the charge in its entirety, however, fails to reveal the sort of manifest error that would undermine the very foundation of the conviction, as articulated in United States v. O'Malley, 345 F.3d 112 (2d Cir. 2005).

Plaintiff's motion for partial summary judgment hinges upon the applicability of the res ipsa loquitur doctrine, a jurisprudential principle that permits an inference of negligence under certain circumscribed conditions; the Court must therefore meticulously assess whether the instrumentality causing the injury was, at all relevant times, within the exclusive control and management of the defendant, a prerequisite that is not, on the present record, unequivocally established.

The ordinance in question, which effectuates a complete and total ban on certain categories of expressive conduct within the public forum, must be subjected to the most exacting level of judicial scrutiny; whereas the government's proffered interest in aesthetic harmony is not without some measure of legitimacy, it cannot, standing alone, serve as a sufficiently compelling justification to override the foundational First Amendment principles at stake, as was discussed in Acme Speakers Bureau v. City of Concord, 401 U.S. 330 (1988).

Defendant's motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) requires the Court to accept all well-pleaded factual allegations in the complaint as true and to construe them in the light most favorable to the plaintiff. The gravamen of the defendant's argument is that the plaintiff's allegations, even if proven, do not coalesce into a cognizable legal theory for which relief may be granted under the prevailing statutory framework.

In considering the district court's determination regarding the substantial similarity of the two literary works, our appellate review must accord considerable deference to the trier of fact's nuanced assessment, particularly where such a finding is predicated upon the cumulative effect of numerous, discrete creative choices; the appellant's attempt to disaggregate the constituent elements of the copyrighted work for piecemeal comparison fundamentally misunderstands the holistic inquiry mandated by our precedent in Artful Dodger Inc. v. Scribe, 987 F.2d 500 (9th Cir. 1993).

The prosecution now seeks to introduce testimony concerning the defendant's out-of-court statements, which the defense contends constitutes inadmissible hearsay under the Federal Rules of Evidence. The government posits, however, that these utterances fall squarely within the penumbra of the exception for statements against penal interest, a categorization that necessitates a contextual analysis of the circumstances under which the declarations were made.

We review the agency's interpretation of its own enabling statute under the deferential framework established by Chevron, U.S.A., Inc. v. Natural Resources Defense Council, Inc., 467 U.S. 837 (1984); the initial step of our inquiry, therefore, is to ascertain whether the legislative body has directly spoken to the precise question at issue, for if the intent of Congress is clear and unambiguous, that intent must be given effect without further judicial gloss.

In adjudicating the matter of equitable distribution of the marital assets, this Court is statutorily obligated to consider a multiplicity of factors, extending beyond mere financial contributions to encompass the myriad non-monetary efforts made by each party throughout the duration of the marriage. Consequently, a proper and just allocation cannot be achieved through the application of a rigid mathematical formula, but rather demands a more holistic and discretionary evaluation of the totality of the circumstances.

The appellant, a creditor in the underlying bankruptcy proceeding, now challenges the trustee's avoidance of a preferential transfer under 11 U.S.C. § 547(b), arguing that the payment was made in the ordinary course of business; to prevail on this affirmative defense, the appellant bears the burden of demonstrating, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the transfer was consistent with the prior dealings between the debtor and creditor, a factual determination we review for clear error. See In re Globex Corp., 555 B.R. 12 (S.D.N.Y. 2016).

To sufficiently plead a claim for securities fraud under Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, a plaintiff must allege, with particularity, that the defendant made a material misrepresentation or omission with the requisite state of mind, known as scienter. The voluminous and multifaceted allegations set forth in the consolidated amended complaint must be carefully sifted to determine whether they collectively give rise to a strong inference of fraudulent intent, as opposed to mere corporate mismanagement or negligence.

The defendant's appeal is principally predicated on a Fourth Amendment challenge to the warrantless search of the vehicle, which he argues was not justified by any recognized exception to the warrant requirement; the government, in response, invokes the so-called 'automobile exception,' a long-standing jurisprudential doctrine that permits such a search where probable cause exists to believe the vehicle contains evidence of a crime. See Carroll v. United States, 267 U.S. 132 (1925).

The doctrine of promissory estoppel, as articulated in the Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 90, serves as a substitute for consideration under circumstances where one party's reliance on another's promise makes enforcement necessary to avoid injustice. The trial court's conclusion that the plaintiff-appellee's reliance was both foreseeable and reasonable is a mixed question of law and fact, which we scrutinize less deferentially than a pure factual finding.

The plaintiffs, a consortium of environmental organizations, seek a preliminary injunction to halt construction of the proposed pipeline, alleging non-compliance with the procedural mandates of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). In evaluating this request for extraordinary relief, the Court must balance the likelihood of irreparable harm to the plaintiffs against the potential injury to the defendants should the injunction issue, all while considering the public interest.

At the heart of this appeal lies the question of whether the defendant-manufacturer owed a legal duty to the plaintiff to warn of the product's latent dangers, a determination that constitutes a question of law for the court to decide; the existence of such a duty is not a static concept, but rather is informed by a careful balancing of public policy considerations, including the foreseeability of harm and the social utility of the defendant's conduct. See Gomez v. Apex Manufacturing, 142 Cal. Rptr. 3d 510 (2012).

Defendant now moves for summary judgment on Plaintiff's claim of hostile work environment harassment, contending that the alleged conduct, while perhaps unprofessional or boorish, does not rise to the level of severity or pervasiveness required to alter the conditions of employment. The Court's task is to view the cumulative effect of the incidents described by Plaintiff, rather than parsing each one in isolation, to ascertain whether a reasonable person in the plaintiff's position would have found the environment to be abusive.

The appellant challenges his conviction on the grounds that his confession was obtained in violation of his Fifth Amendment rights as explicated in Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966). Our review of the voluntariness of the confession necessitates a searching examination of the totality of the circumstances surrounding the interrogation to determine whether the appellant's will was, in fact, overborne by coercive police conduct.

The certification of the plaintiff class by the district court under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 is the central issue presented for our review, an issue we consider under an abuse of discretion standard; the defendants-appellants vigorously contest the finding of predominance, arguing that individualized questions concerning causation and damages will inevitably overwhelm the common issues, thereby rendering the class action mechanism an inefficient and inappropriate vehicle for resolving this dispute.

The parties' dispute centers on the interpretation of an easement agreement, the language of which is, to say the least, less than a model of clarity, thereby necessitating judicial construction. It is a fundamental canon of property law that any ambiguity in the grant of an easement is to be construed in favor of the grantee and against the grantor, who was the drafter of the instrument in question.

In evaluating the defendant's motion to suppress evidence seized pursuant to a search warrant, the Court's role is not to conduct a de novo review of the probable cause determination, but rather to afford great deference to the issuing magistrate's finding. The inquiry is confined to whether the magistrate had a substantial basis for concluding that the affidavit, when read in a common-sense and realistic fashion, established a fair probability that contraband would be found in the location to be searched, a standard established in Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213 (1983).

Defendant's argument that it is entitled to judgment as a matter of law rests upon the contention that Plaintiff, by engaging in the sporting activity, impliedly assumed the risks inherent therein, thus negating any duty Defendant may have owed. This Court must therefore delineate the boundary between those risks which are truly inherent and foreseeable aspects of the activity, and those which are the product of a defendant's supervening and distinct negligence.

The plaintiff seeks the remedy of specific performance for an alleged breach of a contract for the sale of a parcel of real property, a form of relief that is not granted as a matter of right but rests within the sound discretion of the Court. It is hornbook law that such extraordinary relief is generally reserved for situations where the subject matter of the contract is unique and the legal remedy of monetary damages would be inadequate to make the non-breaching party whole.

The appellant contends that the trial court committed reversible error by admitting expert testimony that, in his view, did not meet the reliability standards set forth in Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993). Our review of such an evidentiary ruling is for abuse of discretion, and we must therefore determine whether the district court's gatekeeping function was exercised in a manner that was not manifestly erroneous.

The plaintiffs, parents of students in the district, assert that the school board's policy mandating the recitation of a non-denominational prayer constitutes a violation of the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. Notwithstanding the policy's secular purpose as articulated by the board, the Court must scrutinize its primary effect to ensure that it does not, in practice, result in the impermissible governmental endorsement of religious belief.

The petitioner challenges the final order of the Environmental Protection Agency, arguing that the agency's action was arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion within the meaning of the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A). Our task is not to substitute our own judgment for that of the agency, but rather to ensure that the agency has engaged in reasoned decision-making, examined the relevant data, and articulated a satisfactory explanation for its action, including a rational connection between the facts found and the choice made.

In this patent infringement action, the initial and often dispositive step for the Court is to construe the disputed claim terms of the patent-in-suit, a process known as Markman construction; this judicial interpretation of the patent's scope is a matter of law, and it is upon this foundational construction that all subsequent questions of infringement and validity will ultimately depend. See Markman v. Westview Instruments, Inc., 517 U.S. 370 (1996).

The determination of child custody must be guided at all times by the polestar principle of the best interests of the child, a standard that is necessarily broad and fact-intensive. This Court, sitting in equity, must weigh and consider all relevant factors, including the emotional ties between the child and each parent, and the capacity of each parent to provide for the child's physical, emotional, and developmental needs going forward.

The appellant's claim of ineffective assistance of counsel requires him to satisfy the two-pronged test established in Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984), a burden that is notoriously difficult to carry. He must demonstrate not only that his counsel's performance fell below an objective standard of reasonableness, but also that there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel's unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.

We are asked to decide whether the district court correctly granted summary judgment in favor of the defendant-appellee on the plaintiff's public nuisance claim. The jurisprudential concept of public nuisance encompasses a wide spectrum of conduct that unreasonably interferes with a right common to the general public, and the plaintiff's failure to adduce sufficient evidence of a harm distinct from that suffered by the public at large is fatal to its standing to bring such a claim. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 821C.

The gravamen of this appeal is the proper interpretation of the 'bespeaks caution' doctrine, which provides a safe harbor for forward-looking statements when they are accompanied by meaningful cautionary language; the appellants contend that the cautionary statements provided by the company were merely boilerplate and therefore insufficient to insulate the company from liability, a contention that requires us to analyze the specificity and context of the disclosures made. See Patterson v. InnoTech Systems, 211 F.3d 134 (3d Cir. 2000).

Before the Court is Defendant's motion to compel arbitration, which posits that the entirety of Plaintiff's claims fall within the ambit of a broad arbitration clause contained within the parties' service agreement. In resolving this motion, the Court must undertake a two-step inquiry: first, to determine whether a valid agreement to arbitrate exists, and second, to ascertain whether the specific dispute at hand is encompassed by the substantive scope of that agreement.

The state's statutory scheme, which draws a distinction based on the residency of the individuals it affects, is subject to analysis under the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV, § 2. In order for such a discriminatory classification to withstand constitutional muster, the state must demonstrate that it has a substantial reason for the difference in treatment and that the discrimination practiced bears a close and substantial relationship to that reason.

The debtor-in-possession seeks to assume an unexpired lease of nonresidential real property, an action governed by the strictures of 11 U.S.C. § 365. To do so, the debtor must not only cure any existing defaults under the lease but also provide adequate assurance of future performance, a standard that requires more than mere speculative promises and demands a demonstration of a firm commitment and capacity to fulfill the ongoing leasehold obligations.

The appellant argues that the district court erred in its application of the burden-shifting framework articulated in McDonnell Douglas Corp. v. Green, 411 U.S. 792 (1973), for cases involving claims of disparate treatment discrimination. Once the plaintiff establishes a prima facie case, the burden of production—but not persuasion—shifts to the employer to articulate a legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for its employment action, a relatively low threshold to meet.

The sufficiency of the evidence supporting the jury's verdict of guilt is a question of law that we review de novo, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution. The pertinent question for this Court is whether, after viewing all the evidence, any rational trier of fact could have found the essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt, a standard that imposes a very heavy burden on the appellant. See Jackson v. Virginia, 443 U.S. 307 (1979).

In this trademark infringement case, Plaintiff seeks a preliminary injunction, for which it must demonstrate, inter alia, a likelihood of success on the merits of its claim; a central component of this analysis is the likelihood of consumer confusion, which is assessed by weighing a non-exhaustive list of factors, including the similarity of the marks, the proximity of the goods, and the sophistication of the relevant consumer base. See Polaroid Corp. v. Polarad Elecs. Corp., 287 F.2d 492 (2d Cir. 1961).

Plaintiff's cause of action sounds in medical malpractice, and as such, he must adduce expert testimony to establish the applicable standard of care and the defendant's deviation therefrom. Defendant's motion for summary judgment is predicated on the assertion that Plaintiff's designated expert is not qualified to opine on the specific sub-specialty at issue, a threshold determination of admissibility that the Court must resolve before proceeding to the merits.

The defense objects to the introduction of the co-conspirator's statements, arguing they are barred as hearsay, a contention that overlooks the well-established exception codified in Federal Rule of Evidence 801(d)(2)(E). For such statements to be admissible against the defendant, the prosecution must show by a preponderance of the evidence that a conspiracy existed, that the defendant and the declarant were members of it, and that the statements were made during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy.

The district court's denial of the defendants' motion to transfer venue pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1404(a) is reviewed for a clear abuse of discretion, a standard that is highly deferential. The appellants have not, in our considered view, made the requisite strong showing of inconvenience necessary to overcome the plaintiff's choice of a proper forum, especially when the private and public interest factors do not weigh decisively in favor of transfer.

The parol evidence rule, a substantive doctrine of contract law, generally precludes the admission of extrinsic evidence of prior or contemporaneous agreements to contradict or vary the terms of a fully integrated written contract; the trial court's threshold determination that the agreement was, in fact, a complete and exclusive statement of the parties' accord is a finding of law that we review de novo. See Mellon Bank, N.A. v. Aetna Bus. Credit, Inc., 619 F.2d 1001 (3d Cir. 1980).

Plaintiff alleges that the defendant police officer's use of force was excessive and therefore constituted an unreasonable seizure in violation of the Fourth Amendment. The officer's conduct must be evaluated for its objective reasonableness from the perspective of a reasonable officer on the scene, rather than with the 20/20 vision of hindsight, taking into account the tense, uncertain, and rapidly evolving circumstances that police officers frequently confront. See Graham v. Connor, 490 U.S. 386 (1989).

This appeal concerns a dispute over a boundary line, a matter which the trial court resolved by applying the doctrine of acquiescence, a legal principle that can establish a boundary where the true line is unknown or uncertain. For this doctrine to be operative, there must be a showing that the parties have, for a considerable period of time, mutually recognized and accepted a particular line as the demarcation of their respective properties.

Defendant seeks to suppress his post-arrest statements on the basis that there was an undue delay between his arrest and his initial appearance before a magistrate judge, in contravention of Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 5(a). The government contends that any delay was reasonable and necessary for legitimate law enforcement purposes, and that the statements were made voluntarily and not as a product of the passage of time itself.

The jury's substantial award of punitive damages is challenged by the defendant-appellant as being grossly excessive and therefore violative of the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment; our review of this constitutional question is guided by the three guideposts articulated in BMW of North America, Inc. v. Gore, 517 U.S. 559 (1996): the degree of reprehensibility of the defendant's conduct, the disparity between the harm suffered and the punitive award, and the difference between this remedy and comparable civil penalties.

This matter comes before the Court on cross-motions for summary judgment, presenting a purely legal question of statutory interpretation concerning the agency's authority under the Clean Air Act. The plaintiffs argue for a narrow construction of the agency's regulatory power, while the defendant agency proffers a more expansive interpretation, which it asserts is entitled to judicial deference.

Plaintiff’s claim for retaliation requires her to demonstrate that she engaged in a statutorily protected activity, that she suffered a materially adverse employment action, and that a causal link exists between the two. Defendant argues that the temporal proximity between Plaintiff's complaint and her subsequent termination is, by itself and without more, insufficient to establish the requisite causal connection to survive summary judgment.

The appellant challenges the district court’s imposition of sanctions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 11, contending that its legal arguments, while ultimately unsuccessful, were not frivolous and were based on a nonfrivolous argument for the extension or modification of existing law. We review all aspects of a district court's Rule 11 determination for an abuse of discretion, a standard recognizing that the trial court is better situated to marshal the pertinent facts and apply the fact-dependent legal standard. See Cooter & Gell v. Hartmarx Corp., 496 U.S. 384 (1990).

The defendant asserts the affirmative defense of frustration of purpose, a doctrine that excuses performance when a supervening event, not the fault of either party, destroys the primary purpose of the contract, provided that the non-occurrence of such an event was a basic assumption on which the contract was made. The applicability of this defense is contingent upon a showing that the frustrating event was so fundamental that it rendered the value of the counter-performance substantially worthless.

The statute at issue, which criminalizes certain forms of speech, is challenged by the appellants as being unconstitutionally overbroad, insofar as it proscribes a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression in addition to the unprotected speech it legitimately targets; a finding of substantial overbreadth is considered 'strong medicine' and is employed sparingly and only as a last resort, as it invalidates the law in its entirety. See Broadrick v. Oklahoma, 413 U.S. 601 (1973).

In light of the extensive and pervasive pretrial publicity surrounding this case, the defendant moves for a change of venue, arguing that it will be impossible to empanel a fair and impartial jury in this district. The Court must therefore undertake a careful and searching inquiry to determine whether the presumption of prejudice is so great that the defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial, a cornerstone of our criminal justice system, would be unacceptably compromised.

Plaintiff’s seventy-page brief on the doctrine of promissory estoppel is noted, but ultimately unnecessary. The parties had a written contract, and this Court will enforce the plain language of that document. The motion for summary judgment is granted.
The defendant’s intricate argument about the search protocol misses the point. The officer saw contraband in plain view, and that ends the inquiry. See Coolidge v. New Hampshire, 403 U.S. 443 (1971).

Appellant has provided voluminous statistical data, but the dispositive issue is far simpler. The record shows a legitimate, non-discriminatory reason for the termination, and we will not second-guess the employer's business judgment. The district court's grant of summary judgment is therefore affirmed.
Let us be clear, counsel. The hearsay rule has exceptions, but it is not an invitation to back-door every stray comment into evidence. The objection is sustained.

While the petitioner details a lengthy procedural history, the due process question is straightforward. He received notice and an opportunity to be heard; the Constitution requires no more. Accord Franklin v. State Dep't of Licensing, 98 P.3d 112 (Wash. 2004).

The core of this case is not the complex engineering testimony, but a simple question of causation. The plaintiff cannot prove the defendant's breach, rather than his own inattention, was the proximate cause of his injury.

The defense has presented a compelling but ultimately tangential narrative of the defendant's life. My duty, however, is clear: to sentence based on the crime committed and the guidelines prescribed by law.

Appellant urges us to consider the legislative history, but we need not look past the statute's first sentence. Its text is unambiguous, and where the language is plain, our inquiry ends. Accord Apex Logistics v. Crane, 214 F.3d 881 (7th Cir. 2018).
The issue is not, as Plaintiff suggests, a referendum on academic freedom. The issue is whether the university's curriculum constitutes a public forum. It does not.
I will not entertain a motion to compel based on these convoluted interrogatories. Counsel, redraft them to ask for what you actually want, in plain English.

The debtor's multi-layered corporate structure does not obscure the fundamental reality. Assets were transferred to defraud creditors, and this court will unwind those transactions pursuant to 11 U.S.C. § 548.
Despite the defendant's procedural gymnastics, the matter is simple. Service was proper under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 4, and this court has jurisdiction. The motion to dismiss is denied.
Petitioner's writ is a labyrinth of alleged trial errors. However, he fails to demonstrate a clear constitutional violation, which is the only key that unlocks the door to habeas relief.
The parties have submitted thousands of pages on the hydrological impact. The statute, however, requires only a finding that the discharge *could* affect navigable waters. We find that it could.

Plaintiff’s fair use argument is unpersuasive. The defendant copied the heart of the work for a commercial purpose; this is not a close call under the factors established in Harper & Row v. Nation Enterprises, 471 U.S. 539 (1985).
The proposed instructions on contributory negligence are a page long and likely to confuse. We will use the pattern instruction. The jury needs clarity, not a law review article.
The court has reviewed the parties' competing narratives regarding marital assets. The math, however, is simple. The prenuptial agreement is valid and its terms will be enforced.

The insured's attempt to find ambiguity in the policy's 'Act of God' exclusion is unavailing. The contract language is clear, and a hurricane is plainly an act of God. See Northcutt v. Allstate, 345 S.W.3d 456 (Tex. App. 2011).

Even assuming, arguendo, that the evidentiary ruling was erroneous, the error was harmless. The state presented overwhelming evidence of guilt, and one misstep does not require us to unwind a year-long trial.
The petitioner's sophisticated accounting methods cannot hide the ball. The transaction had no economic substance apart from the creation of a tax loss. The deficiency is affirmed.
The defendant claims he was merely present, but the facts speak for themselves. He drove the car, waited for his confederates, and drove the getaway. That is a conspiracy.
Counsel, I have read all 500 pages of deposition testimony you attached. The material facts are not in dispute. This is a matter of law, and I am prepared to rule.
The plaintiffs’ complaint, when stripped of its conclusory allegations, fails to state a claim. It does not plead fraud with the particularity required by the PSLRA. The motion to dismiss is granted.

The zoning ordinance may have diminished the plaintiff's property value, but a diminution in value is not a taking. The case law on this point is settled and clear. See Penn Central Transp. Co. v. New York City, 438 U.S. 104 (1978).
The agency's reasoning is not a model of clarity, but our standard of review is deferential. We need only find a rational path from the evidence to the conclusion, and we find one here.
Let’s simplify the matter. The plaintiff cannot show a likelihood of success on the merits. The rest of the injunctive relief factors are irrelevant if the core claim is weak.

The plaintiff's expert offers a complex alternative design theory. But the simple fact remains that the product was not defective; it was misused by the plaintiff in a manner the manufacturer could not have reasonably foreseen.
Defendant's argument about the subjective coercion of the police presence is speculative. The body camera footage shows a simple, verbal consent to search. We take the record as we find it.

The parties now dispute the meaning of the term 'commercially reasonable efforts.' The court finds that its meaning is its plain one. The defendant’s efforts were, by any common-sense measure, reasonable.

To succeed on an ineffective assistance claim, the prejudice must be more than conceivable; it must be demonstrable. Petitioner has failed to make this showing. See Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).
I need not delve into the finer points of Rule 11. This filing was frivolous, it wasted the Court's time, and it was brought for an improper purpose. Sanctions are warranted.
Appellant asks us to re-weigh the evidence, but that is the jury's role, not ours. Our job is simply to determine if any rational trier of fact could have reached this verdict. They could.

The display of the monument does not, as plaintiffs contend, establish a state religion. To the reasonable observer, it is a historical artifact, not a religious command. This is the simple test from Lynch v. Donnelly, 465 U.S. 668 (1984).

The question is not whether the officers’ conduct was ideal; it is whether it violated clearly established law. As no prior case, such as Miller v. City of Austin, 8 F.4th 390 (5th Cir. 2021), presents these exact facts, the law was not clearly established. Immunity is granted.
Dr. Evans, I will ask you one more time to answer the question directly. This court is not interested in a lecture on your field, but in a simple answer to a simple question.

The claim construction arguments are intricate, but the infringement analysis is not. The accused device simply does not contain a 'resilient connecting member' as that term is plainly understood. There is no literal infringement.
For all the talk of historical usage and riparian surveys, the doctrine of prior appropriation is king in this jurisdiction. The senior water rights holder must be satisfied first; it's that simple.
The parties have briefed this case extensively, but a simple fact has rendered the entire dispute moot. The contested policy was rescinded last month. We therefore dismiss the appeal.

Plaintiff alleges a complex scheme to restrain trade, but offers no direct evidence of an agreement. Parallel conduct alone does not equal conspiracy, and we will not infer one from ambiguous evidence. See Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544 (2007).
Counsel, your time is nearly up. Please get to the point. The jury has heard the evidence.
The Plan Administrator's denial of benefits may seem harsh, but our review is for abuse of discretion. The administrator gave a reason, and it was not an irrational one. We must affirm.
The petitioner's argument for asylum is a compelling story, but it does not fit the narrow legal definition of persecution. This court is bound by the statute, not by sympathy.
Plaintiff is a public figure and must therefore prove actual malice with convincing clarity. He has failed to produce any direct evidence of such, and the case must be dismissed.

The undisclosed evidence, while potentially useful to the defense, was not material. It does not create a reasonable probability of a different outcome, and that is the only test that matters. See United States v. Bagley, 473 U.S. 667 (1985).
Having heard the evidence in this bench trial, the court finds the plaintiff's testimony to be credible and the defendant's to be evasive. The case is as simple as that. Judgment for the plaintiff.
Appellants challenge the zoning board's decision with a multi-pronged constitutional attack. However, the board's decision is owed deference so long as it is not arbitrary. It was not.
The defendant now raises a complex constitutional issue for the first time on appeal. Our rules are simple: arguments not raised below are waived. We decline to consider it.

The historical analysis presented by the state is interesting, but ultimately beside the point. The challenged law flatly prohibits conduct protected by the plain text of the Second Amendment. It is therefore unconstitutional under N.Y. State Rifle & Pistol Ass'n v. Bruen, 597 U.S. 1 (2022).
Let's cut to the chase, counsel. Has this expert's theory been peer-reviewed and published? The answer appears to be no, which simplifies my Daubert analysis considerably.

Defendant's arguments about impossibility and frustration of purpose are inventive. But the facts are basic: he promised to deliver the goods by a certain date and failed to do so. This is a straightforward breach of contract.

While Defendant correctly identifies a technical deficiency in the summons, the record is clear that Defendant received actual notice of this suit. In the interests of justice and judicial economy, we construe the service as effective under the doctrine of substantial compliance. See Franklin v. City of Delmont, 987 F.2d 112 (3d Cir. 2011).

Defendant moves to dismiss based on Plaintiff's failure to plead with the specificity required under Twombly and Iqbal. However, in pro se civil rights cases, pleadings are to be liberally construed, and this Court finds Plaintiff's allegations, while imperfect, are sufficient to put Defendant on notice of the claims against it. A more developed factual record is necessary before such claims can be dismissed.

The statute of limitations is not an insurmountable bar where equity demands otherwise. Given the complex nature of Plaintiff's injury and the latent manifestation of her symptoms, we find it reasonable to toll the statute from the date of discovery, not the date of the initial tortious act. To hold otherwise would be to reward a defendant's concealment and punish a victim's blameless ignorance.

Although Plaintiff's expert disclosures were filed three days past the court-ordered deadline, there is no evidence of bad faith or willful misconduct. The prejudice to Defendant is minimal and can be cured by granting a brief continuance for a deposition. The Court prefers to decide this matter on its merits rather than on a de minimis procedural infraction.

The district court dismissed Plaintiff's claim for failure to exhaust administrative remedies. We find, however, that the administrative process available to Plaintiff was so opaque and confusing that her failure to navigate it perfectly is excusable. Therefore, we reverse and remand, as a rigid application of the exhaustion doctrine here would lead to a manifest injustice.

Defendant argues that Plaintiff's response to its motion for summary judgment relies on an affidavit that contradicts his earlier deposition testimony. While a 'sham affidavit' may be disregarded, the alleged contradiction here is more of a clarification or an ambiguity. Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-movant, this creates a genuine issue of material fact for the jury to resolve.

The Government seeks to amend the indictment to include a related, but distinct, statutory violation discovered late in the pre-trial process. While such late amendments are disfavored, the Court finds no substantial prejudice to the Defendant, whose core defense theory would remain unchanged. Leave to amend is therefore granted.

Plaintiff's failure to include the required certificate of merit with his initial complaint is a procedural error, but not a fatal one. The subsequent filing of the certificate, though tardy, cures the defect nunc pro tunc. A dismissal without prejudice, only to have the case immediately refiled, would be a pointless elevation of form over substance, a practice disfavored by this Court.

Defendant asserts this Court lacks personal jurisdiction, as its only contact with this forum was through its interactive website. In the modern era of e-commerce, however, a single purposeful transaction directed at a resident of this state is sufficient to hale a defendant into our courts. See Albright v. Global Innovations, Inc., 142 F. Supp. 3d 910 (N.D. Cal. 2019).

The motion to compel is granted in part; while Defendant's objections to the scope of discovery are not entirely without merit, the requested documents are reasonably calculated to lead to the discovery of admissible evidence. Doubts regarding relevance are, at this stage, generally resolved in favor of the discovering party. See Oppenheimer Fund, Inc. v. Sanders, 437 U.S. 340 (1978).

Whereas Plaintiff technically violated the page limit for her appellate brief set by Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 32, the overage is minor and the arguments contained therein are essential to our review. We exercise our discretion to consider the brief as filed. Dismissal of an appeal is a drastic sanction reserved for more serious infractions.

Defendant seeks to strike Plaintiff's complaint as an improper 'shotgun pleading.' While the complaint could be a model of clarity, it nevertheless provides a 'short and plain statement of the claim showing that the pleader is entitled to relief.' The proper remedy is not dismissal, but rather a more definite statement, should the Defendant choose to so move.

We are asked to review the district court's denial of Plaintiff's motion for leave to amend her complaint to add a new defendant after the statute of limitations had run. Because the proposed defendant shared counsel and was intimately involved in the litigation from its inception, the amendment should relate back under Rule 15(c). The lower court's crabbed reading of the rule was an abuse of discretion.

The issue is whether Plaintiff's notice of appeal, filed by her former counsel after he had been formally discharged, is valid. Given that Plaintiff clearly intended to appeal and acted promptly to secure new counsel, we will treat the notice as sufficient to invoke our jurisdiction. The right to appeal should not be lost on a hyper-technicality stemming from the confusion of a transition in representation.

Defendant's motion for summary judgment is denied; Plaintiff's declaration, while self-serving, is based on personal knowledge and creates a triable issue of fact regarding Defendant's discriminatory intent. Credibility determinations are the province of the jury, not the Court at this juncture. See Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242 (1986).

The Magistrate Judge recommended sanctioning Plaintiff for spoliation of evidence. This Court declines to adopt that recommendation, as there is insufficient evidence that the data was destroyed in bad faith, rather than as part of a routine document retention policy. A curative instruction to the jury will suffice to remedy any potential prejudice.

Plaintiff seeks to proceed in forma pauperis, but her affidavit of indigency is incomplete. Rather than dismissing the case, the Court will grant Plaintiff 30 days to file an amended affidavit. The privilege of access to the courts should not be denied to the indigent for correctable procedural missteps.

While the arbitration clause in the employment agreement is broad, it is also ambiguous as to whether it covers post-employment tort claims. It is a bedrock principle that ambiguities in a contract are construed against the drafter—in this case, the Defendant. Therefore, the motion to compel arbitration is denied.

Defendant argues that Plaintiff lacks standing because his alleged injury is a generalized grievance shared by the public at large. However, Plaintiff has demonstrated a 'concrete and particularized' harm by showing that the challenged policy affects his business operations directly, even if it also affects others. See Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555 (1992).

The trial court excluded Plaintiff's key witness as a sanction for a discovery violation. We find this sanction was too severe; lesser sanctions were available and the exclusion was tantamount to a dismissal of Plaintiff's case. It is the long-standing policy of the law to favor the disposition of litigation on the merits.

The Government's failure to provide certain Jencks Act material until the morning of trial is concerning, but not grounds for a mistrial. The Court will grant a recess to allow defense counsel to review the material and cross-examine the witness accordingly. This remedy is sufficient to protect the Defendant's due process rights.

Defendant removed this case, asserting federal question jurisdiction. Plaintiff's complaint, however, makes only passing reference to federal law, and the 'well-pleaded complaint rule' dictates that the plaintiff is the master of the claim. Because a plausible state-law claim exists, any doubt about federal jurisdiction should be resolved in favor of remand.

Plaintiff's request for equitable tolling of the filing deadline for this Title VII action is granted. She has provided evidence of her mental incapacitation during the filing period, which presents the 'extraordinary circumstances' necessary to justify such a remedy. See Holland v. Florida, 560 U.S. 631 (2010).

The defendant corporation argues service on its regional sales manager was improper. However, service on an individual whose position is 'of sufficient responsibility' to make it likely he will inform his superiors is adequate. Given the manager's role, the Court finds he fits within the spirit, if not the exact letter, of the rule.

In reviewing this grant of summary judgment de novo, we find the district court failed to draw all reasonable inferences in favor of the plaintiff. The circumstantial evidence, though not overwhelming, is sufficient for a reasonable jury to find for the plaintiff. The judgment is therefore reversed.

Plaintiff moves to voluntarily dismiss her case without prejudice under Rule 41(a)(2). Defendant objects, arguing it has expended significant resources in discovery. However, as no dispositive motion is pending, and a mere risk of future litigation is not plain legal prejudice, the motion is granted.

Defendant's Daubert motion seeks to exclude Plaintiff's expert testimony. While the expert's methodology is novel, the Federal Rules of Evidence favor admissibility. The jury can and should be trusted to weigh the credibility of the expert's conclusions after vigorous cross-examination.

The class certification question before us is a close one. However, Rule 23 is to be construed liberally, and in borderline cases, the Court should err in favor of allowing the class to be certified. See Corliss v. Medtronic, Inc., 789 F.3d 101 (2d Cir. 2017).

The Court must decide whether to permit the late designation of a rebuttal witness by the Plaintiff. Given that the need for this witness was not apparent until after the Defendant's primary expert report was served, the Court finds the delay constitutes excusable neglect. To deny the request would unfairly hamper Plaintiff's ability to present her case.

Defendant argues for dismissal based on forum non conveniens. While the alternative forum is adequate, the Plaintiff's choice of forum is entitled to great deference, especially when the Plaintiff is a resident of this district. The balance of private and public interest factors does not strongly favor dismissal.

Plaintiff's failure to post the required security bond for costs within the time allotted is not a jurisdictional defect. The Court will exercise its inherent power to manage its docket and grant Plaintiff a final extension to comply. Justice is not served by dismissals on such grounds.

The State's evidence was obtained pursuant to a warrant that may have a stale probable cause affidavit. However, the officers relied on the warrant in good faith, and the preference for warranted searches requires us to resolve marginal cases in favor of upholding the search. The motion to suppress is denied.

Defendant contends Plaintiff's complaint is barred by res judicata from a prior state court action. Yet, the current claim involves a distinct theory of liability not actually litigated in the prior case. A cramped application of claim preclusion would unfairly deny plaintiff her day in court on this federal question.

This Court must interpret an ambiguous term in the insurance policy provided by the Defendant. It is axiomatic that such ambiguities are construed in favor of the insured—the Plaintiff here. The policy was drafted by the Defendant, who had the power to make its meaning clear.

Although the plaintiff did not formally move to amend, her arguments in her opposition to summary judgment effectively put the defendant on notice of an alternative theory of negligence. Pursuant to Rule 15(b), we will treat the pleadings as if they had been amended to include this claim. See Whitaker v. Town of Ticonderoga, 889 F.3d 121 (2d Cir. 2018).

The district court denied class certification based on a perceived conflict of interest among putative class members. We view this conflict as speculative at this stage. The court should have considered the use of subclasses before resorting to the drastic step of denying certification outright.

Defendant's motion in limine seeks to exclude evidence of subsequent remedial measures. While Rule 407 generally prohibits such evidence to prove negligence, it is admissible for other purposes, such as proving control or feasibility. The Court finds the Plaintiff's proffered reason for admission to be plausible and will allow it with a limiting instruction.

The question of whether plaintiff's 'John Doe' complaint may relate back to the original filing date is a complex one. Given the diligence plaintiff's counsel has shown in attempting to identify the officer, equity favors allowing the relation back. The officer was surely aware that he would be a party to this action.

Plaintiff, a prisoner proceeding pro se, mailed his notice of appeal on the final day for filing, but it was not received by the clerk's office until two days later. Under the 'prison mailbox rule,' the notice is deemed filed on the day it was handed to prison officials for mailing. We construe the rule broadly to ensure incarcerated litigants are not disadvantaged.

Defendant's argument for abstention under the Younger doctrine is unpersuasive. The pending state administrative proceeding does not provide an adequate forum for the plaintiff's constitutional claims. Therefore, this Court will not relinquish its jurisdiction to hear these important federal questions.

The jury's verdict in favor of the Plaintiff is substantial, and Defendant moves for remittitur. While the award is generous, it does not 'shock the conscience' of the court. The jury was in the best position to assess the plaintiff's pain and suffering, and we will not substitute our judgment for theirs without a compelling reason.

Plaintiff's counsel missed the pre-trial conference, citing a calendaring error. While such lapses are not to be encouraged, the sanction of striking Plaintiff's witness list is disproportionate to the offense. The conference will be rescheduled, with costs assessed to Plaintiff's counsel.

We are called upon to determine the timeliness of a habeas petition under AEDPA's strict one-year statute of limitations. The petitioner has made a colorable, if not definitive, claim of actual innocence. In such cases, the procedural requirements of the Act must yield to prevent a fundamental miscarriage of justice.

Defendant argues the plaintiff's demand for a jury trial was untimely. However, the waiver of this fundamental right must be knowing and voluntary. Given the ambiguity in the scheduling order, the Court will resolve the doubt in favor of preserving the plaintiff's Seventh Amendment rights.

The plaintiff's response to the defendant's requests for admission was served one day late. Under Rule 36, these matters are deemed admitted. The Court, however, will exercise its discretion under Rule 36(b) to permit the withdrawal of these admissions, as doing so serves the presentation of the merits and does not prejudice the defendant.

In this ERISA case, the plan administrator's decision to deny benefits is reviewed for abuse of discretion. However, where, as here, the administrator is also the entity that pays the benefits, a conflict of interest exists. This conflict will be weighed as a factor, and the Court will not be a mere rubber stamp for a decision that appears to be procedurally irregular.

The government's forfeiture complaint against the defendant property was not verified as required by the supplemental rules. This is a procedural defect that the government can, and will be permitted to, cure by amendment. Dismissing the action on this basis would be an unduly harsh penalty for a technical pleading error.

Defendant seeks summary judgment, arguing the plaintiff has produced no direct evidence of retaliation. This Court recognizes, however, that 'smoking gun' evidence is rare in employment cases. The temporal proximity between plaintiff's complaint and his termination is, by itself, sufficient to create an inference of retaliation and defeat the motion.

Plaintiff's complaint fails to name the correct corporate entity, instead suing its parent corporation. As the parent and subsidiary are closely related and share a legal department, notice to the parent can be imputed to the subsidiary. Leave to amend to name the proper defendant will be freely given and will relate back to the original filing date.

The lower court found plaintiff's appeal to be frivolous and awarded sanctions to the defendant. While plaintiff's legal arguments were weak, they were not wholly without a plausible basis. Sanctions are reserved for truly egregious conduct, and we must be careful not to chill zealous advocacy, especially from a party with limited resources.

The warrant authorized a search for 'financial records,' a term too nebulous to satisfy the Fourth Amendment's particularity requirement. While the executing officers acted in good faith, the defect in the warrant itself is a structural error that cannot be excused, as it risks transforming a specific authorization into a general warrant. See Groh v. Ramirez, 540 U.S. 551 (2004); United States v. Calloway, 911 F.3d 121 (2d Cir. 2018).

Plaintiff’s reliance on service by publication was premature, as the record does not reflect a truly diligent effort to locate and personally serve the defendant. The rules governing service are not mere suggestions; they are the formal requisites for the exercise of jurisdiction over a party. See Blackwell v. Titan Corp., 345 P.3d 118 (Nev. 2015).

Although the 'discovery rule' can toll the statute of limitations in certain fraud cases, plaintiff’s own pleadings indicate they were aware of potential discrepancies more than three years before filing suit. A party cannot sit on its rights and then claim ignorance when the clock has run. Franklin Credit Mgmt. v. Henderson, 452 S.W.3d 87 (Tex. App. 2014).

The 14-month delay between indictment and trial, largely attributable to prosecutorial docket management, triggers a presumption of prejudice under the Barker test. The government's justification of 'ordinary institutional delay' is insufficient to overcome the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial. Vermont v. Brillon, 556 U.S. 81 (2009).

Plaintiff's complaint, alleging a conspiracy to defraud, fails to plead with the particularity required by Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b). The allegations must specify the 'who, what, when, where, and how' of the alleged fraud for each defendant; lumping defendants together in a generalized accusation is procedurally fatal. See Ambler v. Sterling Partners, 211 F. Supp. 3d 788 (E.D. Pa. 2016).

The government failed to account for the whereabouts of the evidence bag for a 48-hour period between its seizure and its arrival at the forensics lab. Without a complete chain of custody, the court cannot be assured that the evidence has not been tampered with or altered, and it must therefore be excluded. See United States v. Mejia, 597 F.3d 1329 (D.C. Cir. 2010).

Defendant's operation of a passive website, accessible to residents of this forum, does not constitute the 'minimum contacts' necessary to subject it to personal jurisdiction here. To hold otherwise would render any entity with an online presence amenable to suit in every state, a result inconsistent with the principles of due process. See Zippo Mfg. Co. v. Zippo Dot Com, Inc., 952 F. Supp. 1119 (W.D. Pa. 1997).

We find that the trial court's failure to give the defendant's requested instruction on the accomplice witness rule was not harmless error. The conviction rested almost entirely on the testimony of a single, interested witness, and the jury must be properly guided on how to weigh such testimony. See Collins v. State, 876 S.E.2d 444 (Ga. 2022).

Plaintiff’s expert report was served three days after the court-ordered deadline, without a motion for extension or a showing of excusable neglect. The rules of discovery are designed to prevent trial by ambush, and this court will not hesitate to enforce them by excluding the untimely report. See Santiago v. AMR Services Corp., 2017 WL 429699 (E.D.N.Y. 2017).

While the defendant did not explicitly state 'I want a lawyer,' his question, 'Should I have a lawyer here for this?' was a sufficiently clear, albeit equivocal, invocation of his right to counsel. At that point, all questioning should have ceased until counsel was present. See Davis v. United States, 512 U.S. 452 (1994); State v. Norris, 244 P.3d 1199 (Kan. 2011).

Plaintiff opposes summary judgment with a declaration based 'on information and belief,' which is insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact. The non-movant must set forth specific facts showing a triable issue, not mere conclusory allegations. See Lujan v. National Wildlife Federation, 497 U.S. 871 (1990).

The plaintiffs, a citizens' group, have failed to demonstrate an injury-in-fact that is concrete and particularized; a generalized grievance about government action is not enough to confer Article III standing. This court is not a forum for the resolution of public policy debates, but a court of limited jurisdiction. Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins, 578 U.S. 330 (2016).

The indictment charges the defendant with conspiracy 'from on or about January 1 to June 30,' but fails to allege a single overt act in furtherance of that conspiracy. Such a bare-bones charge fails to provide the defendant with adequate notice to prepare a defense and is therefore dismissed. See Russell v. United States, 369 U.S. 749 (1962).

The proposed class of 'all consumers who purchased the product' lacks the cohesiveness required by Rule 23(b)(3), as individual questions of reliance and causation will inevitably predominate over common questions. The procedural vehicle of a class action cannot be used to paper over essential differences in each plaintiff's claim. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. v. Dukes, 564 U.S. 338 (2011).

The trial court erred in admitting the victim's statement to a bystander under the 'excited utterance' exception to the hearsay rule. The record shows a full five minutes passed between the event and the statement, providing sufficient time for reflection and fabrication, thus removing it from the ambit of the exception. See Commonwealth v. Santiago, 980 N.E.2d 899 (Mass. 2013).

Defendant removed this case on the basis of diversity jurisdiction, yet one of the named defendants is a citizen of this forum state, rendering removal improper under 28 U.S.C. § 1441(b)(2). The so-called 'forum defendant rule' is a clear statutory command, not a discretionary guideline, and requires remand. See Goodwin v. Reynolds, 757 F.3d 1216 (11th Cir. 2014).

The search of the defendant's locked briefcase, conducted after he had already been handcuffed and secured in the patrol car, exceeded the permissible scope of a search incident to arrest. The briefcase was no longer within the defendant's 'immediate control,' and thus the search was not justified by officer safety or evidence preservation concerns. See Arizona v. Gant, 556 U.S. 332 (2009).

While leave to amend should be freely given, Plaintiff waited until after the close of discovery and the filing of dispositive motions to seek this amendment. Such a delay is undue and would be plainly prejudicial to the Defendant, who has structured its entire litigation strategy around the original complaint. See Foman v. Davis, 371 U.S. 178 (1962).

The introduction of the non-testifying co-defendant's confession, even with a limiting instruction, violated the defendant's Sixth Amendment right to confront his accuser. The risk of prejudice is so great in this context that the 'legal fiction' of a limiting instruction is insufficient to cure the constitutional defect. Bruton v. United States, 391 U.S. 123 (1968).

This case has languished on the docket for over two years with no meaningful activity from the plaintiff. A court's inherent power to manage its docket includes the authority to dismiss a case for want of prosecution, and we exercise that power here. See Link v. Wabash R. Co., 370 U.S. 626 (1962).

The prosecution's failure to disclose the lead detective's history of disciplinary actions for untruthfulness constitutes a violation of its duties under Brady v. Maryland. The credibility of the detective was central to the case, and this impeachment evidence was therefore material. See Kyles v. Whitley, 514 U.S. 419 (1995).

Defendant moves for sanctions due to Plaintiff's spoliation of evidence, and the court must grant the motion. Plaintiff's 'accidental' deletion of relevant emails after a litigation hold was in place demonstrates, at a minimum, gross negligence warranting an adverse inference instruction. See Pension Comm. of Univ. of Montreal Pension Plan v. Banc of Am. Sec., 685 F. Supp. 2d 456 (S.D.N.Y. 2010).

Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the prosecution, no rational trier of fact could have found the essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. The prosecution's case was built on a series of inferences stacked upon one another, which is insufficient to sustain a criminal conviction. Jackson v. Virginia, 443 U.S. 307 (1979).

Plaintiff's attempt to join two separate and distinct tort claims against two unrelated defendants in a single action is improper under Rule 20. The claims do not arise from the same transaction or occurrence, and forcing the defendants to litigate them together would be fundamentally unfair and prejudicial. See Bridgeport Music, Inc. v. 11C Music, 202 F.R.D. 229 (M.D. Tenn. 2001).

The defendant, held in an interrogation room for eight hours without food or water and subjected to relentless questioning, did not give a voluntary confession. A confession must be the product of a rational intellect and a free will, not one overborne by police coercion. See Mincey v. Arizona, 437 U.S. 385 (1978).

Plaintiff, a resident of California, brought suit in this district against a Delaware corporation whose principal place of business is in Texas, for an incident that occurred in Florida. This district is an improper venue under 28 U.S.C. § 1391; the mere fact that defendant's products are sold here is not dispositive. The case is therefore dismissed without prejudice.

The State's second indictment, charging the defendant with felony murder, is barred by the Double Jeopardy Clause following his acquittal on the underlying felony charge. The doctrine of collateral estoppel, embedded in the Fifth Amendment, prevents the State from relitigating an issue of ultimate fact that has already been decided in the defendant's favor. Ashe v. Swenson, 397 U.S. 436 (1970).

Defendant's motion to exclude Plaintiff's expert testimony under Daubert is granted. The expert's methodology, a novel theory created for the purposes of this litigation, has not been subjected to peer review, has no known error rate, and has not gained general acceptance in the scientific community. See Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals, Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993).

The rule of lenity requires that we resolve any ambiguity in this criminal statute in favor of the defendant. If the legislature wishes to criminalize this specific conduct, it must do so with clarity, not through a vague prohibition that fails to provide fair warning. See United States v. Santos, 553 U.S. 507 (2008).

Defendant made a timely and proper offer of judgment under Rule 68, which Plaintiff rejected. Because the final judgment obtained by Plaintiff is less favorable than the unaccepted offer, Plaintiff must now pay the costs incurred by the Defendant after the offer was made. See Marek v. Chesny, 473 U.S. 1 (1985).

Defense counsel's failure to investigate and call a known alibi witness falls below the objective standard of reasonableness required by Strickland. This was not a strategic decision, but a complete abdication of the duty to conduct a thorough investigation, and it was prejudicial to the defendant. Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668 (1984).

Plaintiff seeks to compel the deposition of Defendant's in-house counsel, arguing the communications fall under the crime-fraud exception. However, the plaintiff has not made a prima facie showing that the legal advice was sought in furtherance of an ongoing crime or fraud; a mere allegation is insufficient to pierce the sanctity of the attorney-client privilege. See United States v. Zolin, 491 U.S. 554 (1989).

The physical evidence discovered in defendant's apartment was a direct result of a confession obtained in violation of his Miranda rights. As such, the evidence is 'fruit of the poisonous tree' and must be suppressed, as there was no intervening act to purge the primary taint of the unlawful interrogation. Wong Sun v. United States, 371 U.S. 471 (1963).

The employment agreement contains a clear and unambiguous arbitration clause, compelling the plaintiff to arbitrate this dispute rather than litigate it in court. This court's duty is to enforce the contract as written, and federal policy strongly favors arbitration. See AT&T Mobility LLC v. Concepcion, 563 U.S. 333 (2011).

While any single one of the procedural errors at trial might be considered harmless, their cumulative effect was to deprive the defendant of a fair trial. The constant evidentiary missteps and improper prosecutorial comments created a pervasive atmosphere of prejudice. See Parle v. Runnels, 505 F.3d 922 (9th Cir. 2007).

Plaintiff's claim for damages totals $74,500, which is below the $75,000 amount-in-controversy requirement for diversity jurisdiction. This court is one of limited jurisdiction, and the requirements of 28 U.S.C. § 1332 must be strictly construed. Therefore, this action is dismissed for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.

The trial court committed reversible error by conducting a portion of voir dire in the judge's chambers without the defendant present. A defendant has a constitutional right to be present at every critical stage of the proceedings, and his physical absence during jury selection cannot be deemed harmless. See United States v. Al-Kassar, 660 F.3d 108 (2d Cir. 2011).

Plaintiff's state-law tort claims are expressly pre-empted by the comprehensive federal regulatory scheme governing medical devices. To allow a patchwork of state-law duties would undermine the uniform standards established by Congress. See Riegel v. Medtronic, Inc., 552 U.S. 312 (2008).

The anonymous 911 call reporting 'a man with a gun' lacked sufficient indicia of reliability to justify the subsequent stop and frisk of the defendant. The caller provided no predictive information that could be corroborated by the police, rendering the tip little more than an unverified accusation. Florida v. J.L., 529 U.S. 266 (2000).

Service upon a low-level administrative assistant who was not authorized to accept service of process is invalid under Rule 4(h). Strict compliance with the rules for serving a corporate defendant is a prerequisite to this court's exercise of personal jurisdiction. See Larsen v. Mayo Medical Center, 218 F.3d 863 (8th Cir. 2000).

The prosecutor's closing argument, which repeatedly referred to the defendant's failure to testify and characterized it as evidence of guilt, was a flagrant violation of the defendant's Fifth Amendment rights. Such misconduct requires reversal of the conviction and a new trial. Griffin v. California, 380 U.S. 609 (1965).

Plaintiff's current lawsuit for property damage is barred by the doctrine of res judicata, as he previously brought a personal injury claim arising from the same auto accident. A plaintiff may not split his cause of action and sue for different elements of damages in successive lawsuits. See Frier v. City of Vandalia, 770 F.2d 699 (7th Cir. 1985).

The officer's detention of the defendant extended beyond the time reasonably necessary to effectuate the purpose of the initial traffic stop. Once the citation was written, the continued detention and questioning constituted a second, unlawful seizure, tainting the subsequent discovery of contraband. Rodriguez v. United States, 575 U.S. 348 (2015).

This litigation cannot proceed in the absence of the parent corporation, which is an indispensable party under Rule 19. The parent corporation has a direct and significant interest in the outcome of this contract dispute, and a judgment rendered in its absence would be prejudicial. See Pulitzer-Polster v. Pulitzer, 784 F.2d 1305 (5th Cir. 1986).

The photo array shown to the witness was impermissibly suggestive, as the defendant's photograph was the only one that matched the witness's initial description. This procedural flaw created a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification, violating the defendant's due process rights. See Foster v. California, 394 U.S. 440 (1969).

The defendant's motion to dismiss this declaratory judgment action is granted, as there is no live 'case or controversy' between the parties. Plaintiff is essentially seeking an advisory opinion on a hypothetical future dispute, which this court lacks the constitutional authority to issue. See MedImmune, Inc. v. Genentech, Inc., 549 U.S. 118 (2007).

The trial record demonstrates that the prosecutor used a disproportionate number of peremptory strikes against minority jurors, and the proffered race-neutral reasons were pretextual. The trial court's failure to sustain the defendant's Batson challenge was clear error and requires a new trial. Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).

Plaintiff seeks discovery of notes prepared by defendant's counsel in anticipation of litigation. This material lies at the core of the work-product doctrine, and the plaintiff has failed to show the substantial need and inability to obtain the information by other means required to overcome the protection. See Hickman v. Taylor, 329 U.S. 495 (1947).

The state has not met its heavy burden of showing that the 17-year-old defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his Miranda rights without a parent or attorney present. The procedural safeguards for juveniles must be scrupulously observed to ensure the voluntariness of any statement. See J.D.B. v. North Carolina, 564 U.S. 261 (2011).

Defendant’s Rule 12(e) motion for a more definite statement is granted, as the plaintiff's complaint is so vague and ambiguous that the defendant cannot reasonably prepare a response. The complaint fails to identify which of the defendant's many products is at issue or the nature of the alleged defect. See Thomas v. Independence Twp., 463 F.3d 285 (3d Cir. 2006).

Plaintiff's claim for personal injury, filed two years and one day after the incident, is barred by the state's strict two-year statute of limitations. The doctrine of equitable tolling is applied sparingly and is inappropriate here, as the text of the statute provides for no such exception. Defendant's motion for summary judgment is therefore granted.

We affirm the district court's dismissal of Petitioner's habeas corpus petition as untimely. The Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act's one-year limitation period is a strict jurisdictional bar, and as held in *Fuller v. Daniels*, 345 F.3d 118 (7th Cir. 2008), claims of actual innocence do not automatically toll the statutory deadline. Petitioner had his year, and the statute does not permit us to grant him another.

Plaintiff's First Amendment retaliation claim fails to meet the plausibility standard set forth in *Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544 (2007)*. The complaint offers only conclusory allegations of retaliatory animus without pleading specific facts from which such a motive could be inferred. Accordingly, the complaint is dismissed for failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.

Appellant now challenges the admission of expert testimony, yet the record reflects no contemporaneous objection during trial as required by Federal Rule of Evidence 103(a). Our precedent in *Gibbons v. Sterling Corp.*, 501 F. App'x 334 (4th Cir. 2013), is clear that failure to object constitutes a waiver. We decline to review for plain error where counsel had ample opportunity to raise the issue below.

The warrant authorized a search for 'financial records,' a term Defendant argues is overly broad. However, the Fourth Amendment requires particularity, not prescience; the description was sufficient for the executing officers to ascertain the items to be seized. Therefore, the motion to suppress is denied.

It is undisputed that Plaintiff served the summons and complaint upon an administrative assistant not authorized to receive service on behalf of the corporate defendant. As strict compliance with Rule 4 is mandatory for this court to exercise personal jurisdiction, the case is dismissed without prejudice. See *Omni Capital Int'l, Ltd. v. Rudolf Wolff & Co.*, 484 U.S. 97 (1987).

The appellant urges this court to consider extrinsic evidence of prior negotiations to interpret an allegedly ambiguous term in the contract. The parol evidence rule, however, bars the admission of such evidence where the contract contains a clear integration clause, as this one does. We are bound by the four corners of the document, as was the trial court.

Defendant argues for a downward variance based on his difficult upbringing, but the District Court properly calculated the Guideline range and sentenced him within it. While a court *may* consider such factors under 18 U.S.C. § 3553(a), it is not required to grant a variance, and we find no procedural error in its decision to adhere to the recommended range. The sentence is affirmed.

Plaintiff, a concerned citizen, lacks Article III standing to challenge the zoning variance granted to the Defendant developer. Plaintiff has alleged only a generalized grievance shared by the public at large, not a particularized and concrete injury as required by *Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555 (1992)*. The case is dismissed.

Petitioners challenge the agency's interpretation of an ambiguous statutory provision. Under the framework of *Chevron, U.S.A., Inc. v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc.*, 467 U.S. 837 (1984), where a statute is silent on an issue, we must defer to a reasonable agency interpretation. Whether a different interpretation might be 'better' is not a question for this court to decide.

Defendant moves for a new trial, alleging the prosecution failed to disclose exculpatory evidence in violation of *Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963)*. However, the evidence in question was not material, as there is no reasonable probability that its disclosure would have changed the outcome of the trial. The motion is denied.

Plaintiff's fraud allegations are dismissed for failure to comply with the heightened pleading standard of Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 9(b). The complaint does not state with particularity the 'who, what, when, where, and how' of the alleged fraud. Merely reciting the elements of the cause of action is insufficient.

The ordinance in question is a content-neutral time, place, and manner restriction on speech in a public forum. Because it is narrowly tailored to serve a significant governmental interest and leaves open ample alternative channels for communication, it passes constitutional muster under the standard of *Ward v. Rock Against Racism, 491 U.S. 781 (1989)*. The plaintiff's as-applied challenge is therefore without merit.

The district court did not abuse its discretion in denying plaintiff's motion for leave to amend the complaint, filed after the court-ordered deadline had passed. A scheduling order 'is not a frivolous piece of paper, idly entered,' and plaintiffs failed to show the 'good cause' required by Rule 16(b) to modify it. *See Cortez v. Acuity, Inc., 912 F. Supp. 2d 1089 (D. Colo. 2012)*.
